Title: Angiostrongylus Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Adult worms of A. cantonensis live in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Females lay eggs that hatch into larvae (first-stage).

    • 2. First-stage larvae migrate to the pharynx, are swallowed, and are passed in the feces.

    • 3. First-stage larvae penetrate or are ingested by an intermediate host (snail or slug) and develop into 3rd-stage larvae.

    • 4. When an intermediate host is ingested by the definitive host, the 3rd-stage larvae migrate to the brain, where they develop into young adults. The young adults return to the venous system and then to the pulmonary arteries, where they mature.

    • 5. Humans can acquire the infection by eating raw or undercooked infected snails or slugs, raw produce that contains a small snail or slug or part of one, or a transport host such as certain land crabs, frogs, toads, or freshwater prawns or shrimp.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Anisakis Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Adult Anisakis worms reside in the stomach of marine mammals. The adults live in clusters, embedded in the mucosa. Adult females produce unembryonated eggs that are passed in feces of the marine mammals.

    • 2a. The eggs become embryonated in water, and first-stage, then 2nd-stage larvae form in the eggs.

    • 2b. After the larvae hatch from the eggs, they become free-swimming.

    • 3. Free-swimming larvae are ingested by crustaceans. The larvae develop into 3rd-stage larvae and migrate from the intestine to tissues in the peritoneal cavity.

    • 4. When the host is eaten by fish or squid, larvae migrate to the muscle tissues, and through predation, larvae are transferred from fish to fish.

    • 5. Third-stage larvae, which are infective to humans and marine mammals, reside in fish and squid.

    • 6. When such a fish or squid is ingested by marine mammals, the larvae develop into adult worms. Adult females produce eggs that are shed by marine mammals.

    • 7. Humans become infected by eating raw or undercooked infected marine fish. After ingestion, the larvae penetrate the gastric and intestinal mucosa, causing symptoms.
Copyright: Image from the Centers of Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Ascaris lumbricoides Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Adult Ascarisworms live in the lumen of the small bowel.

    • 2. A female may produce about 200,000 eggs/day; the eggs are excreted with feces. Unfertilized eggs may be ingested but are not infective.

    • 3. In the environment, fertile eggs, depending on the conditions, embryonate and become infective after 18 days to several weeks; optimal conditions are moist, warm, shaded soil.

    • 4. Infective eggs are swallowed.

    • 5. In the small bowel, the eggs hatch into larvae.

    • 6. Larvae penetrate the wall of the small bowel and migrate via the portal circulation through the liver, then via the systemic circulation to the lungs, where they mature further (in 10 to 14 days).

    • 7. The larvae penetrate the alveolar walls, ascend the bronchial tree to the throat, and are swallowed. They then return to the small bowel, where they develop into adult worms.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Bacillus anthracis
Description: Gram-positive bacilli that are characteristic of Bacillus anthracis are shown.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Candida albicans
Description: This image shows direct detection of Candida albicans from blood culture using calcofluor white stain.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Paschalis Vergidis, MD, MSc.

Title: Candida Esophagitis
Description: Diffuse whitish plaques are typical of Candida esophagitis.
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Candida Esophagitis
Description: Diffuse whitish plaques are typical of Candida esophagitis.
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Candida Esophagitis
Description: Diffuse whitish plaques are typical of Candida esophagitis.
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Clonorchis sinensis Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. In the human host, the adult worm releases embryonated eggs through the biliary ducts into the intestine. They are excreted in feces.

    • 2. Eggs are ingested by a snail (the intermediate host); > 100 species of snails can act as intermediate hosts. Each egg releases a miracidium (the first larval stage), which develops into a sporocyst, then a redia, then a cercaria.

    • 3. Cercariae are released from the snail, and after a short period of free swimming in water, they come in contact with and penetrate the flesh of freshwater fish, where they encyst as metacercariae.

    • 4. Humans are infected by eating undercooked, salted, pickled, or smoked freshwater fish, or sometimes freshwater shrimp.

    • 5. After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst in the duodenum.

    • 6. They then enter the common bile duct through the ampulla of Vater and migrate to smaller intrahepatic ducts (or occasionally the gallbladder and pancreatic ducts), where they mature into adults in about 1 month.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Cryptosporidium Life Cycle
Description:
Cryptosporidium are transmitted mainly through contact with contaminated water (eg, drinking water, swimming pools) and occasionally through contaminated food.

    1. Sporulated oocysts are excreted by the infected host in stool and possibly other routes (eg, respiratory secretions). Oocysts are infective when excreted; thus, direct and immediate fecal-oral transmission is possible.

    2–3 (a–k). Oocysts are ingested (or possibly inhaled) and excyst. Sporozoites are released and parasitize epithelial cells of the gastrointestinal tract or other tissues (eg, respiratory tract). In these cells, the parasites transform into trophozoites and multiply asexually then sexually, producing microgamonts (male) and macrogamonts (female), which mate and produce oocysts. The oocysts sporulate in the infected host. Two types of oocysts are produced: thick-walled oocysts, which are commonly excreted by the host, and thin-walled oocysts, which are involved primarily in autoinfection.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library.

Title: Cyclospora Life Cycle
Description:
Cyclospora oocysts are not sporulated (ie, infective) when passed in stool. Thus, direct fecal-oral transmission does not occur.

    1. Unsporulated oocysts are excreted from the infected host in stool.

    2–3. The oocysts sporulate in the environment after 1 to 2 weeks at temperatures between 22 to 32° C.

    4. The sporulated oocysts contaminate food or water. The mechanism for contamination has not been established.

    5. The sporulated oocysts are ingested in contaminated food or water.

    6. The oocysts excyst in the gastrointestinal tract, releasing the sporozoites, which invade the epithelial cells of the small intestine.

    7. Inside the cells, they multiply asexually and develop sexually to mature into oocysts, which are shed in stool.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Cystoisospora belli Life Cycle
Description:
Cystoisospora belli oocysts are not sporulated (ie, infective) when passed in stool. Thus, direct fecal-oral transmission does not occur.

    1. Immature oocysts are excreted in stool. Each oocyst usually contains one sporoblast. The sporoblast divides in two and secretes a cyst wall, becoming 2 sporocysts. The sporocysts divide and produce sporozoites.

    2. Oocysts are ingested and excyst. Sporozoites are released and invade the epithelial cells.

    3-5. Inside the cells, they multiply asexually. After at lwww one week, male and female gametocytes develop. Fertilization results in oocysts, which are shed in stool.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library.

Title: Dracunculus Life Cycle
Description:
• 1a and 1b. Humans become infected by drinking water containing microcrustaceans (copepods) that are infected with larvae of D. medinensis or eating undercooked fish harboring the larvae.

    • 2. After ingestion, the copepods die and release larvae, which penetrate the stomach and intestinal wall and enter the abdominal cavity and retroperitoneal space.

    • 3. After larvae mature into adults and copulate, the male worms die, and the females migrate in the subcutaneous tissues toward the skin surface. About 1 year after infection, the female worm induces an indurated papule (blister) on the skin, usually on the distal lower extremity. The papule eventually ulcerates.

    • 4. When this lesion comes into contact with water (patients typically immerse the affected extremity in water to relieve the intense discomfort), the female worm emerges and releases larvae.

    • 5. Larvae are ingested by a copepod.

    • 6. After 2 weeks, larvae become infective. When humans ingest the copepods, the cycle is completed.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Echinococcus Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. The adult Echinococcus granulosus worm resides in the small intestine of the definitive hosts (dogs, other canines).

    • 2. Proglottids release eggs, which are passed in the feces.

    • 3. After ingestion by an intermediate host (usually, sheep, goats, swine, cattle, horses, camels, or humans), the egg hatches in the small intestine and releases an oncosphere, which penetrates the intestinal wall and migrates through the circulatory system into various organs, especially the liver and lungs.

    • 4. In these organs, the oncosphere develops into a cyst, which enlarges gradually; protoscolices and daughter cysts form within the cyst. The definitive host becomes infected by ingesting the cyst-containing organs of the infected intermediate host.

    • 5. After ingestion, protoscolices evaginate and attach to the intestinal mucosa.

    • 6. They develop into adult stages in 32 to 80 days.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Enterobius Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Eggs are deposited on perianal folds.

    • 2. Eggs may be ingested when people touch their mouth after they scratch their perianal area (autoinfection) or after handling contaminated clothes or other objects (eg, bed linens, curtains, carpeting); handling contaminated objects may also cause a few eggs to become airborne and thus ingested.

    • 3. After eggs are ingested, they travel to the small intestine, where they hatch, releasing larvae.

    • 4. The adult worms establish themselves in the cecal lumen.

    • 5. At night, gravid females migrate outside the anus and lay eggs as they crawl on the skin of the perianal area.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Fasciola hepatica Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Unembryonated eggs are discharged into the biliary ducts and excreted in feces.

    • 2. Eggs become embryonated in water.

    • 3. Eggs release miracidia, which invade a snail (intermediate host).

    • 4. In the snail, the parasites progress through several developmental stages (sporocysts, rediae, and cercariae).

    • 5. The cercariae are released from the snail and encyst as metacercariae on aquatic vegetation or other surfaces.

    • 6. Fascioliasis is acquired by eating plants, especially watercress, containing metacercariae.

    • 7. After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst in the duodenum.

    • 8. They migrate through the intestinal wall, peritoneal cavity, and liver parenchyma into the biliary ducts, where they develop into adults.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Fasciolopsis buski Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. In the human host, unembryonated eggs are discharged into the intestine and pass out of the body with the feces.

    • 2. Eggs become embryonated in water.

    • 3. The eggs release miracidia, which penetrate a snail (intermediate host).

    • 4. In the snail, the miracidia develop into sporocysts, then rediae, and then cercariae.

    • 5. The cercariae are released from the snail.

    • 6. They encyst as metacercariae on aquatic plants and may be ingested by a mammalian host (human or pig).

    • 7. After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst in the duodenum and attach to the intestinal wall.

    • 8. There, they develop into adult flukes in about 3 months.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library.

Title: Heterophyes heterophyes Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. In the host, the adult worm releases embryonated eggs; each egg contains a fully developed miracidium. The eggs are passed in the host's feces.

    • 2. After ingestion by a snail (first intermediate host), the eggs hatch and release miracidia, which penetrate the snail's intestine. Miracidia develop into sporocysts, then rediae, and then cercariae. Many cercariae are produced from each redia.

    • 3. Cercariae are released from the snail.

    • 4. The cercariae encyst as metacercariae in tissues of a freshwater or brackish-water fish (2nd intermediate host).

    • 5. The definitive host becomes infected by ingesting raw, undercooked, or salted fish containing metacercariae.

    • 6. After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst and attach to the mucosa of the small intestine.

    • 7. There, they mature into adults.

    • 8. In addition to humans, various fish-eating mammals (eg, cats, dogs) and birds can be infected by Heterophyes heterophyes.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library.

Title: Ixodes scapularis
Description: This image shows an adult deer tick, Ixodes scapularis, which transmits Borrelia burgdorferi, a causative agent of Lyme disease.
Copyright: Image courtesy of James Gathany via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Ixodes scapularis
Description: This image shows an adult deer tick, Ixodes scapularis, which transmits Borrelia burgdorferi, a causative agent of Lyme disease.
Copyright: Image courtesy of James Gathany via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Ixodes scapularis (Adult Deer Tick)
Description: Tick-borne relapsing fever can be transmitted by the deer tick, Ixodes scapularis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of James Gathany via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Leishmania Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sand flies. During a blood meal, the sand flies inject metacyclic promastigotes (the infective stage) from their proboscis.

    • 2. Promastigotes are phagocytized by macrophages and other mononuclear phagocytic cells.

    • 3. In these cells, promastigotes transform into amastigotes (the tissue stage).

    • 4. Amastigotes multiply by simple division and infect other mononuclear phagocytic cells.

    • 5–6. During a blood meal on an infected host, sand flies become infected by ingesting macrophages infected with amastigotes.

    • 7. In the midgut of the sand flies, amastigotes transform into promastigotes.

    • 8. There, they multiply, develop, and migrate to the proboscis.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Loa loa Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. When an infected fly bites a person, it deposits Loa loa larvae onto the person's skin, and the larvae enter the bite wound.

    • 2. The larvae mature into adults in tissues under the skin (in subcutaneous tissue).

    • 3. Adults produce immature worm larvae (called microfilariae), which circulate in the bloodstream during the day and stay in the lungs at night. Microfilariae may be present in spinal fluid, urine, and sputum.

    • 4. A fly ingests microfilariae when it bites the person.

    • 5. In the fly, the microfilariae travel to the middle part of the fly's gut (midgut), then to muscles in its midsection (thoracic muscles).

    • 6–7. There, the microfilariae develop into larvae.

    • 8. Larvae travel to the fly's mouth parts (proboscis) and can be transmitted to other people when the fly bites them.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Onchocerca volvulus Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. During a blood meal, an infected blackfly transmits filarial larvae onto the skin of the human host, where the larvae enter the bite wound.

    • 2. The larvae migrate to subcutaneous tissues.

    • 3. There, the larvae develop into adult filariae, which commonly reside in subcutaneous nodules for up to about 15 years.

    • 4. After mating, female worms produce unsheathed microfilariae, which are typically present in the skin and the lymphatics of connective tissues but are occasionally present in peripheral blood, urine, and sputum.

    • 5. A blackfly ingests the microfilariae during a blood meal.

    • 6. After ingestion, the microfilariae penetrate the blackfly's midgut and migrate to the thoracic muscles.

    • 7–8. There, the microfilariae go through 3 stages (L1-L3) of larval development.

    • 9. Larvae migrate to the blackfly's proboscis and can infect another human when the fly takes a blood meal.
Copyright: Image from the Centers of Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Opisthorchis Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. In the human host, the adult fluke releases embryonated eggs that are passed in feces.

    • 2. After ingestion by a snail (first intermediate host), eggs release miracidia, which develop into sporocysts, then rediae, and then cercariae.

    • 3. Cercariae are released from the snail and penetrate freshwater fish (2nd intermediate host).

    • 4. The cercariae encyst as metacercariae in muscles or under the scales of the fish. The mammalian primary (definitive) host (cats, dogs, various fish-eating mammals including humans) becomes infected by ingesting undercooked fish containing metacercariae.

    • 5. After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst in the duodenum.

    • 6. They ascend through the ampulla of Vater into the biliary ducts, where they attach and develop into adults. They lay eggs after 3 to 4 weeks.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library.

Title: Ornithodoros turicata
Description: Tick-borne relapsing fever can be transmitted by soft ticks of the genus Ornithodoros.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Jim Occi, BugPics, Bugwood.org.

Title: Paragonimus westermani Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. In the human host, unembryonated eggs pass out of the body in sputum, or they are swallowed and passed with stool.

    • 2. In the external environment, eggs become embryonated, and miracidia hatch.

    • 3. Miracidia seek a snail (first intermediate host), and penetrate its soft tissues.

    • 4. Inside the snail, miracidia develop into sporocysts, then rediae, and then many cercariae, which emerge from the snail.

    • 5. Cercariae invade a crustacean such as a crab or crayfish (2nd intermediate host), where they encyst and become metacercariae (the infective stage for mammalian hosts).

    • 6. Humans are infected with P. westermani by eating inadequately cooked or pickled freshwater crab or crayfish that contain metacercariae.

    • 7. The metacercariae excyst in the duodenum.

    • 8. They then penetrate the intestinal wall and move into the peritoneal cavity, then through the abdominal wall and diaphragm into the lungs; there, they become encapsulated and develop into adults, which produce eggs. The eggs exit the body in sputum that is coughed up and spit out or swallowed and passed in stool. The worms can also reach other organs and tissues, but in such sites, the life cycle cannot be completed because the eggs cannot exit the body.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library.

Title: Plasmodium Life Cycle
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Image Library.

Title: Schistosoma Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. In the human host, eggs containing miracidia are eliminated with feces or urine into water.

    • 2. Under appropriate conditions, the eggs hatch and release miracidia.

    • 3. The miracidia swim and penetrate a snail (intermediate host).

    • 4 and 5. Within the snail, the miracidia progress through 2 generations of sporocysts to become cercariae.

    • 6. The free-swimming cercariae are released from the snail and penetrate the skin of the human host.

    • 7. During penetration, the cercariae lose their forked tail, becoming schistosomula.

    • 8 and 9. The schistosomulae migrate via venous circulation to lungs, then to the heart, and then develop in the liver, exiting the liver via the portal vein system when mature.

    • 10. The paired (male and female) adult worms migrate (depending on their species) to the intestinal veins in the bowel or rectum or to the venous plexus of the genitourinary tract, where they reside and begin to lay eggs.

    •  S. japonicum is more frequently found in the superior mesenteric veins draining the small intestine (see A).

    • S. mansoni occurs more often in the inferior mesenteric veins draining the large intestine (see B).

    • However, both species can occupy either location and are capable of moving between sites.

    • S. intercalatum and S. guineensis also inhabit the inferior mesenteric plexus but lower in the bowel than S. mansoni.

    • S. haematobium most often inhabits in the vesicular and pelvic venous plexus of the bladder (see C), but it can also be found in the rectal venules.

    • The females (size ranges from 7 to 28 mm, depending on species) deposit eggs in the small venules of the portal and perivesical systems. The eggs are moved progressively toward the lumen of the intestine (S. mansoni, S. japonicum, S. mekongi, S. intercalatum/guineensis) and of the bladder and ureters (S. haematobium), and are eliminated with feces or urine, respectively.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Strongyloides Life Cycle
Description:
The Strongyloides life cycle is more complex than that of most nematodes with its alternation between free-living and parasitic cycles, and its potential for autoinfection and multiplication within the host.

    • 1. Rhabditiform larvae are excreted in the stool into the soil.

    • 2. There, the rhabditiform larvae can become free-living adults or become infective filariform larvae that penetrate human skin (6).

    • 3. Adult worms mate, and the females produce eggs.

    • 4. Rhabditiform larvae hatch from the eggs.

    • 5. These larvae can develop into free-living adults (2) or into infective filariform larvae (6).

    • 6. The filariform larvae penetrate human skin.

    • 7. The larvae migrate by various routes to the small intestine, where they mature into adults.

    • 8. In the small intestine, the adult female worms produce eggs.

    • 9. Eggs hatch into rhabditiform larvae. Most of the larvae are excreted in stool.

    • 10. Some larvae become filariform larvae in the large intestine, penetrate the intestinal wall (internal autoinfection) or perianal skin (external autoinfection), and follow the normal infective cycle.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Toxocara canis Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. The Toxocara canis life cycle normally involves dogs; humans are infected only accidentally. Unembryonated eggs are passed in feces of dogs (the definitive host).

    • 2. In the environment, eggs embryonate and become infective.

    • 3. After eggs are ingested by a dog, they hatch and release larvae, which penetrate the intestinal wall.

    • 4. In younger dogs, the larvae migrate through the lungs and bronchial tree; larvae are coughed up, swallowed, and returned to the small intestine, where they mature. Adult female worms deposit eggs in the small intestine. Although older dogs may be infected in the same way, larvae are more likely to encyst in tissues.

    • 5. Encysted stages are reactivated in female dogs during late pregnancy and infect the puppies via the transplacental or transmammary route.

    • 6. As a result, adult worms become established in the small intestine of the puppies (a major source of environmental contamination).

    • 7. T. canis can also be transmitted through ingestion of transport hosts. Eggs ingested by small mammals (eg, rabbits) hatch into larvae, which penetrate the intestinal wall and migrate into various tissues where they encyst.

    • 8. The life cycle is completed when dogs eat these hosts, and the larvae develop into egg-laying adult worms in the small intestine.

    • 9–10. Humans are accidental hosts who become infected by ingesting infective eggs in contaminated soil or infected transport hosts. After ingestion, the eggs hatch into larvae.

    • 11. The larvae penetrate the intestinal wall and are circulated to various tissues (eg, liver, heart, lungs, brain, muscle, eyes).
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Trichinella spiralis Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Animals that are fed (eg, pigs) or eat (eg, bears, foxes, boars) other animals acquire trichinosis by ingesting meat containing cysts (encysted larvae) of Trichinella species. Humans may be accidentally infected when they eat raw, undercooked, or underprocessed meat from infected animals.

    • 2. After exposure to gastric acid and pepsin, the larvae are released from the cysts in the small intestine and penetrate the mucosa.

    • 3. There, they develop into adult worms.

    • 4. After 1 week, the females release larvae that migrate to the striated muscles where they encyst.

    • 5. The cycle continues only if encysted larvae are ingested by another carnivore.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Trichuris trichiura Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. The unembryonated eggs are passed in feces.

    • 2. In the soil, the eggs develop into a 2-cell stage.

    • 3. The cells continue to divide (advanced cleavage stage).

    • 4. Then the eggs embryonate and become infective in 15 to 30 days. They may be ingested when hands or food are contaminated with feces or feces-containing soil.

    • 5. The eggs hatch in the small intestine and release larvae.

    • 6. Larvae mature and establish themselves as adults in the cecum and ascending colon.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Trypanosoma brucei gambiense and Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. During a blood meal on a mammalian host, an infected tsetse fly injects metacyclic trypomastigotes into skin tissue. The parasites enter the lymphatic system and pass into the bloodstream.

    • 2. Inside the host, they transform into bloodstream trypomastigotes, are carried to other sites throughout the body, and enter other body fluids (eg, lymph, spinal fluid).

    • 3. The trypomastigotes multiply by binary fission.

    • 4. They circulate in the bloodstream.

    • 5. During a blood meal from an infected mammalian host, a tsetse fly becomes infected with bloodstream trypomastigotes.

    • 6. In the fly's midgut, the parasites transform into procyclic trypomastigotes and multiply by binary fission.

    • 7. The procyclic trypomastigotes leave the midgut and transform into epimastigotes.

    • 8. The epimastigotes reach the fly's salivary glands, multiply by binary fission, and develop into metacyclic trypomastigotes.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

TopicLocations.Title: Trypanosoma brucei gambiense and Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense Life Cycle

Title: Trypanosoma cruzi Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. During a blood meal, an infected Triatominae insect vector (or kissing bug) releases trypomastigotes in its feces near the site of the bite wound.

    • 2. Trypomastigotes enter the host through the wound or through intact mucosal membranes (eg, conjunctiva). Inside the host, the trypomastigotes invade cells near the site of inoculation, where they differentiate into intracellular amastigotes.

    • 3. The amastigotes multiply by binary fission.

    • 4. They differentiate into trypomastigotes, then burst out of the cell and enter the bloodstream. Bloodstream trypomastigotes can infect cells in various tissues; there, they transform into intracellular amastigotes and cause symptomatic infection. In the bloodstream, trypomastigotes, unlike African trypanosomes, do not multiply. Multiplication resumes only when the parasites enter another cell or are ingested by another vector.

    • 5. The kissing bug becomes infected by feeding on human or animal blood that contains circulating parasites.

    • 6. The ingested trypomastigotes transform into epimastigotes in the vector's midgut.

    • 7. The parasites multiply in the midgut.

    • 8. In the hindgut, they differentiate into infective metacyclic trypomastigotes, which are excreted in feces.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: 4:3 Mobitz Type I Second-Degree Atrioventricular Block
Description: A 12-lead ECG with a simultaneously recorded lead II rhythm strip. The downward arrows show the P waves of a regular sinus rhythm with a rate of 58 beats/minute. The QRS complexes show group beating with three QRS complexes for every 4 P waves. The numbers below Lead II are the corresponding RR intervals. The numbers above Lead II are the corresponding PR intervals. The duration of the RR interval spanning the QRS complex pause (1920 milliseconds) is less than twice the duration of any other RR interval. The durations of the PR intervals in each group gradually increase (300 milliseconds then 380 milliseconds then 420 milliseconds). The durations of the RR intervals after the pause get progressively shorter (1080 milliseconds then 1040 milliseconds) because the increments by which the PR intervals get longer are progressively less (80 milliseconds then 40 milliseconds).
Copyright: Image courtesy of L. Brent Mitchell, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: 4:3 Mobitz Type I Second-Degree Atrioventricular Block

Title: Abdominal Hernia

Title: Abdominal Imaging (Gallstones)

Title: Acanthosis Nigricans
Description: Acanthosis nigricans is skin thickening and pigmentation most typically developing in the axillae and nape of the neck (top); in people with dark skin, the skin may have a leathery appearance (bottom). It is most often a skin manifestation of impaired glucose tolerance, but it may reflect internal cancer, especially if onset is rapid and distribution is widespread.
Copyright: Photos provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Acanthosis Nigricans
Description: Acanthosis nigricans is skin thickening and pigmentation most typically developing in the axillae and nape of the neck (top); in people with dark skin, the skin may have a leathery appearance (bottom). It is most often a skin manifestation of impaired glucose tolerance, but it may reflect internal cancer, especially if onset is rapid and distribution is widespread.
Copyright: Photos provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Acanthosis Nigricans
Description: Acanthosis nigricans is skin thickening and pigmentation most typically developing in the axillae and nape of the neck (top); in people with dark skin, the skin may have a leathery appearance (bottom). Title: Achilles Tendon Stretch
Description: While seated, place an elastic band around the ball of the foot, and passively stretch the Achilles with the foot in dorsiflexion while the knee is extended.
Copyright: Photos courtesy of James C. Connors, DPM.

Title: Achilles Tendon Xanthomas
Description: Achilles tendon xanthomas are diagnostic of familial hypercholesterolemia.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael H. Davidson, MD.

Title: Acid-Fast Stain (Mycobacterium tuberculosis)
Description: This image is a light micrograph of an acid-fast–stained sputum sample containing M. tuberculosis bacteria. Their red color remaining after acid alcohol treatment indicates they are acid-fast.

Title: Acne (Papules and Pustules)
Description: Acne most commonly manifests as comedones (whiteheads or blackheads) and also as papules (blue arrow) and pustules (black arrow).
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Acne Affecting the Body
Description: Papules and comedones are present.

Title: Acne Conglobata (Conglobate Acne) on the Face
Description: This photo shows acne conglobata, the most severe form of acne vulgaris, on the face. Abscesses and keloidal scars are visible.

TopicLocations.Title: Acne Conglobata (Conglobate Acne) on the Face

Title: Acne Fulminans
Description: This photo shows confluent and nonconfluent ulcerations resulting from acne fulminans.

Title: Acne Keloidalis Nuchae
Description: This photo shows typical acneiform lesions and deep keloidal scarring alopecia in a young male with acne keloidalis nuchae.

Title: Acne With Multiple Pustules
Description: Papules and crusts are also visible.

Title: Acneiform Eruption
Description: This photo shows acneiform rash on the chest caused by corticosteroid treatment.

Title: Acral-Lentiginous Melanoma
Description: This photo shows acral-lentiginous melanoma on the great toe. This melanoma occurs on palmar, plantar, or subungual skin.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Gregory L. Wells, MD.

Title: Acral-Lentiginous Melanoma
Description: This photo shows longitudinal pigmentation of the nail (melanonychia striata; blue arrow) and hyperpigmentation extending across the lunula to the proximal nail fold (Hutchinson sign; red arrow) of the middle finger. Acral-lentiginous melanoma, the most common type of melanoma among people with dark skin, occurs on palmar, plantar, or subungual skin. This patient was diagnosed with acral-lentiginous melanoma (a form of malignant melanoma). (The dark area on the thumbnail is a subungual hematoma.)
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Carl Washington, MD and Mona Saraiya, MD, MPH, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Acral-Lentiginous Melanoma (Hutchinson Sign)
Description: Longitudinal pigmentation of the nail (melanonychia striata; blue arrow) and hyperpigmentation extending across lunula to proximal nail fold (Hutchinson sign; red arrow) of the middle finger with rounded pigmented lesion of the thumbnail. This patient was diagnosed with acral-lentiginous melanoma (a form of malignant melanoma).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Carl Washington, MD, and Mona Saraiya, MD, MPH, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Acrocyanosis in a Hand
Description: This photo shows the contrast between the digital cyanosis in a hand of a patient with acrocyanosis and a normal hand.

Title: Acrodermatitis Continua of Hallopeau
Description: This photo shows pustular lesions on the tip of a finger in a patient with acrodermatitis continua of Hallopeau (a localized form of pustular psoriasis).

Title: Acrodermatitis Enteropathica in a Child
Description: Visible characteristic findings include hair loss and facial psoriasiform dermatitis.

Title: Acrodermatitis Enteropathica With Paronychia
Description: Dermatitis can involve the nail folds and progress to paronychia.

Title: Acrodermatitis Enteropathica With Perianal and Perineal Dermatitis
Description: Psoriasiform dermatitis can develop.

Description: Psoriasiform dermatitis has progressed to local erythroderma.

Title: Acromegaly
Description: This photo shows a patient with frontal bossing, prognathism, nasal bone hypertrophy, and thickened skin.

Title: Acromegaly (Facial Changes)
Description: Left image shows a 64-year-old woman who presented with acromegaly due to a pituitary adenoma. Right image shows the same patient 11 years earlier. Note the change in facial features compared with the left image.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Newman C. In Atlas of Clinical Endocrinology: Neuroendocrinology and Pituitary Disease. Edited by SG Korenman (series editor) and ME Molitch. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2000.

Title: Acromegaly (Frontal and Lateral Views of Facial Changes)
Description: Frontal and lateral images of a patient with acromegaly. Coarse facial features are evident, including prognathism and prominence of the malar eminences and supraorbital ridges.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Conrad C, Pro B, Prabhu S, et al. In Atlas of Cancer. Edited by M Markman and MR Gilbert. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Acromegaly (Hand Findings)
Description: This photo shows a normal hand (on the left) compared to the enlarged hand (on the right) of a patient with acromegaly.

Title: Acromioclavicular Joint Sprain
Description: Normally, the lower ends of the acromion and clavicle align. In this x-ray, the clavicle is displaced upward but the 2 bones still overlap, suggesting a type II subluxation.
Copyright: LIVING ART ENTERPRISES, LLC/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Actinic Keratosis (Scalp)
Description: This photo shows an irregular erythematous patch with adherent yellowish tan scale.

Title: Actinomycetoma
Description: Actinomycetoma due to nocardiosis is a slowly progressive, destructive infection of the cutaneous and subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and, as seen here, bone. Actinomycetoma starts as a nodule, suppurates, spreads along fascial plains, and drains through chronic fistulas.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Libero Ajello via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Actinomycotic Mycetoma
Description: This photo shows nocardiosis infection of the upper extremity with swelling and multiple subcutaneous nodules.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Libero Ajello via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Acute Appendicitis
Description: This image shows a dilated, thick-walled appendix (arrows) measuring 15.31 mm in diameter with surrounding inflammatory changes.
Copyright: Image provided by Parswa Ansari, MD.

Title: Acute Atopic Dermatitis with Secondary Infection
Description: In this patient, acute dermatitis lesions were complicated by secondary infection (superinfection) with Staphylococcus aureus (impetiginization).

TopicLocations.Title: Acute Atopic Dermatitis with Secondary Infection

Title: Acute Blepharitis
Description: In this patient, eyelid margins have become edematous and erythematous, and eyelashes are crusted with dried serous fluid.

Title: Acute Conjunctival Chemosis
Description: This photo shows gross edema with ballooning of the conjunctiva known as chemosis.
TopicName: Overview of Conjunctival and Scleral Disorders

TopicLocations.Title: Acute Conjunctival Chemosis
TopicLocations.TopicName: Overview of Conjunctival and Scleral Disorders

Title: Acute Dacryocystitis with Fistula
Description: In acute dacryocystitis, the lacrimal sac is red, swollen, and painful. This photo shows an abscess that has formed and ruptured through the skin, creating a fistula.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of James Garrity, MD.

Title: Acute Febrile Neutrophilic Dermatosis (Sweet Syndrome)
Description: This photo shows classic erythematous plaques with vesicular borders on the neck and face in a woman with acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis (Sweet syndrome). The cutaneous lesions consist of excruciatingly tender red to violet papules or nodules that may coalesce to plaques and are distributed asymmetrically over the upper extremities, face, and neck.

Title: Acute Gastritis
Description: This image show acute gastritis caused by Helicobacter pylori infection.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke (MRI)
Description: This MRI scan shows an area of restricted diffusion consistent with an acute ischemic stroke in the left insular and frontal lobes.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Ji Y. Chong, MD.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in the Left Insular and Frontal Lobes (MRI)
Description: This MRI scan shows an area of restricted diffusion consistent with an acute ischemic stroke in the left insular and frontal lobes.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Ji Y. Chong, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in the Left Insular and Frontal Lobes (MRI)

Title: Acute Necrotizing Collection
Description: This CT scan with IV and oral contrast shows a large acute necrotizing collection (arrows) replacing most of the pancreatic tissue < 4 weeks from initial presentation of necrotizing pancreatitis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Sonam Rosberger, MD.

Title: Acute Necrotizing Ulcerative Gingivitis (ANUG)
Description: This rapidly progressing infection is characterized by acute fiery-red gingivitis, soft-tissue necrosis with formation of a necrotic surface layer (referred to as a pseudomembrane), and cratering of the interproximal papillae, referred to as "punched-out papillae."
Copyright: Image courtesy of Craig Fowler, DDS.

Title: Acute Otitis Media
Description: The left tympanic membrane in acute otitis media (bottom) is bulging and erythematous and has indistinct landmarks, obscured because of the bulging tympanic membrane.

Title: Acute Paronychia on the Finger
Description: In this photo, acute paronychia is characterized by extensive inflammation around the fingernail and purulence.

Title: Acute Pityriasis Lichenoides
Description: Acute pityriasis lichenoides is characterized by small erythematous or purpuric macules and papules; lesions can be centrally vesiculated or have hemorrhagic crusting.

Title: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome
Description: This upright chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral opacities characteristic of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Herdegen J, Bone R. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Pleuropulmonary and Bronchial Infections. Edited by G Mandell (series editor) and MS Simberkoff. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1996.
TopicName: Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure AHRF, ARDS

TopicLocations.Title: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome
TopicLocations.TopicName: Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure AHRF, ARDS

Title: Acute Retronychia
Description: This photo shows acute retronychia, with proximal nail fold inflammation and yellow discoloration of the nail plate (xanthonychia). Granulation tissue formation is suggested by swelling of the proximal nail fold without purulence. The lateral nail folds are not significantly affected because the trauma is primarily to the proximal nail fold and underlying nail matrix. Acute paronychia often involves the lateral nail folds.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Chris G. Adigun, MD.

Title: Acute Retronychia (Big Toe)
Copyright: Image courtesy of Chris G. Adigun, MD.

Title: Acute Tonsillitis
Description: This photo shows acute tonsillitis with exudate and erythema.
Copyright: Photo provided by Clarence T. Sasaki, MD.

Title: Acute Tubular Necrosis
Description: Tubular injury in acute tubular necrosis may be manifest histologically as regenerating flattened tubular epithelium without necrosis, as seen to the right of the glomerulus, blebbing and individual cell degeneration, as in the top left, or frank necrosis, as in the middle of the image (periodic acid-Schiff stain, ×100).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Acute Tubulointerstitial Nephritis
Description: Biopsy specimen in acute tubulointerstitial nephritis demonstrates interstitial edema with infiltration by eosinophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells (hematoxylin-eosin stain, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Acute Ulcerative Tinea Pedis
Description: In this photo, maceration and scaling are visible in the 4th interdigital space. Erythema and edema on the 5th toe suggest secondary bacterial infection.

Title: Adamantinoma
Description: This lateral x-ray of right tibia shows a large anterior intracortical adamantinoma (arrows).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus
Description: This image shows an ulcerated, constricting tumor located in the distal esophagus, which is highly suggestive of an adenocarcinoma arising from metaplastic columnar changes (Barrett esophagus).
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Advanced Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: This photo shows squamous cell carcinoma manifesting as a large, ulcer-like area that, in its later stages, spread to other parts of the body.
Copyright: DR M.A. ANSARY / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Advanced Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: This photo shows squamous cell carcinoma manifesting as a large, ulcer-like area that, in its later stages, spread to other parts of the body.

Description: Over time, some eyes develop central atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium and photoreceptors. This can result in significant central vision loss, which is characteristic of advanced AMD.

Title: AIDS-Defining Illness: Coccidioidomycosis
Description: This chest CT’s coronal view shows multiple micronodular opacities throughout both lung parenchyma in a patient in Southern California, a known endemic region where Coccidioides immitis, a soil fungus that causes coccidioidomycosis, is commonly found. The lesions resemble miliary tuberculosis. In endemic areas, disseminated coccidioidomycosis produces similar lesions.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Edward R. Cachay.

Title: Albinism (Cutaneous Findings)
Description: Oculocutaneous albinism is an inherited defect in melanin production that causes diffuse hypopigmentation of skin, hair, and eyes. Melanin deficiency may be partial, as in this image, or total. This girl has a form of albinism known as Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome, characterized by melanin deficiency, platelet abnormalities, and ceroid-lipofuscin lysosomal storage disease.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Noah S. Scheinfeld, MD, and the Dermatology Online Journal.

Title: Albinism (Ocular Findings)
Description: Ocular involvement is characterized by iris hypopigmentation or translucency, reduced retinal pigmentation, reduced visual acuity, strabismus, and nystagmus.

Title: Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis
Description: Posteroanterior chest x-ray shows "gloved finger" shadows (arrows), appearing as branched tubular densities that represent intrabronchial exudates with bronchial wall thickening.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Groll A, Walsh T. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Fungal Infections. Edited by GL Mandell and RD Diamond. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2000.

Title: Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (Bronchiectasis)
Description: A contrast-enhanced CT of the chest shows severe bronchiectasis in the midlung zones with grossly dilated and ectatic airways and cystic changes. Airway ectasia dis characterized by a ratio of airway to adjacent vessel > 1.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Coakley R, Boucher R, Fiel S, et al. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Allergic Conjunctivitis
Description: This photo shows bilateral periorbital edema with mild blepharitis mostly of the lower eyelids and conjunctival erythema, in a patient with allergic conjunctivitis. Itching and clear discharge may also be present.

Title: Alopecia Areata
Description: This photo shows patchy loss of scalp hair in alopecia areata.

Title: Alport Syndrome (Hereditary Nephritis)
Description: Glomerular basement membranes show irregular thinning and thickening with a lamellated basket-weave appearance under transmission electron microscopy. The changes are caused by injury and remodeling (×6000).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Alveolar Hemorrhage
Description: This chest x-ray shows bilateral alveolar opacities in a patient with alveolar hemorrhage.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Cohen A, Glassock R. In Atlas of Diseases of the Kidney: Glomerulonephritis and Vasculitis. Edited by R Schrier (series editor), RJ Glassock, and AH Cohen. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1999.

Title: Alveolar Hemorrhage
Description: This chest x-ray shows bilateral alveolar opacities in a patient with alveolar hemorrhage.

Description: Bilateral alveolar opacities in a patient with alveolar hemorrhage due to Goodpasture syndrome.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Cohen A, Glassock R. In Atlas of Diseases of the Kidney: Glomerulonephritis and Vasculitis. Edited by R Schrier (series editor), RJ Glassock, and AH Cohen. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1999.

Description: This T2-FLAIR MRI scan shows a white signal in the posterior temporal lobe. The signal is not enhanced by contrast. It is an anaplastic (grade III) astrocytoma.

Description: This photo shows angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) on the face of a patient with tuberous sclerosis complex.

Title: Angiokeratomas in Fabry Disease
Description: This photo shows painless, small red papules (angiokeratomas) on the abdomen of a patient with Fabry disease.

Title: Angular Cheilitis
Description: Angular cheilitis (perlèche) produces painful cracks at the corners of the mouth. Erythema and crusting at the labial angles also is seen in this photo.

Title: Anisocoria Due to Horner Syndrome
Description: This photo shows anisocoria, which is a visible inequality in pupil diameter. In this case, the anisocoria is due to Horner's syndrome. In physiologic anisocoria, the most common cause of anisocoria, the difference between pupil size is much smaller, typically ≤ about 1 mm.

Title: Ankle Fracture of Both Malleoli
Description: This ankle fracture involves the medial malleolus (of the tibia) and lateral malleolus (of the fibula).

Title: Ankle Sprain With Instability
Description: If the ankle is stable, the intra-articular surfaces of the talus and tibia should be parallel. Here, they are widely misaligned, indicating gross joint instability. Instability would have been clearly evident clinically, and instability is normally assessed clinically without need for x-rays.

Title: Ankylosing Spondylitis
Description: This x-ray shows sclerosis between lumbar vertebrae, loss of lordosis, and fusion of lumbar vertebrae, a finding indicating advanced ankylosing spondylitis.

Title: Ankylosing Spondylitis (Bamboo Spine)
Description: In this x-ray of the spine of a patient with ankylosing spondylitis, extra bone (bright white) has been laid down between the vertebrae. In places this fusion is complete, giving the appearance of a "bamboo spine."

Title: Ankylosing Spondylitis (Sacroiliitis)
Description: This x-ray of the pelvis and sacral spine of a person suffering from ankylosing spondylitis shows fusion of both sacroiliac joints.
Copyright: ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S HOSPITAL, LONDON/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Ankylosing Spondylitis (Severe Kyphosis)
Description: This photo shows severe kyphosis (outward curvature) of the spine due to fusion of the vertebrae in a patient with ankylosing spondylitis.
Copyright: ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S HOSPITAL, LONDON/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Anophthalmia
Description: This patient has multiple congenital abnormalities including right-sided anophthalmia, deformed pinna, and hemifacial microsomia.

Title: Anterior Chamber Hemorrhage (Hyphema)
Description: This patient has a traumatic hyphema (arrow) and conjunctival erythema after a traumatic injury to the eye.

Title: Anterior Glenohumeral (Shoulder) Dislocation
Description: An anteroposterior plain x-ray shows the humeral head out of its usual location within the glenoid fossa, suggesting an anterior dislocation.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Jacobs P: Current Orthopedic Diagnosis and Treatment. Edited by JD Heckman, RC Schenck, and A Agarwal. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Anteroposterior (AP) Radiograph of Foot with Bunion
Description: This anteroposterior view of the foot shows radiographic findings consistent with hallux valgus, with medial deviation of the first metatarsal. There is also lateral subluxation of the base of the first proximal phalanx with respect to the head of the first metatarsal.
Copyright: Image courtesy of James C. Connors, DPM.

Title: Anthrax (Cutaneous)
Description: Cutaneous anthrax begins as a painless, reddish brown papule. The papule enlarges and is surrounded with erythema and edema (top); it then undergoes central ulceration, and a black eschar forms (bottom).
Copyright: Images courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Anthrax (Inhalation)
Description: Typical findings of inhalation anthrax on chest x-ray include a widened mediastinum caused by hemorrhagic necrotizing mediastinal lymphadenitis and bilateral pleural effusions. Pneumonic infiltrates are uncommon.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Antiglomerular Basement Membrane Antibody Disease
Description: Antiglomerular basement membrane antibody disease is characterized by smooth, linear staining of glomerular basement membranes with antibody to IgG. The left glomerulus demonstrates crescent formation (immunofluorescence with anti-IgG, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Description: Widened mediastinum seen on chest x-ray (left) with corresponding type B aortic dissection (arrow) on CT image (right).

Title: Arterial Switch Operation
Description: The arterial switch (Jatene) operation is typically done during the first week of life. The proximal portions of the aorta and pulmonary arteries are transected, the aorta is connected to the left ventricle, and the pulmonary artery is connected to the right ventricle. The procedure also involves reconnecting the coronary arteries so that the heart muscle receives oxygenated blood.
TopicName: Transposition of the Great Arteries TGA

Description: This photo shows the typical appearance of a child with four-limb arthrogryposis. Note adduction and internal rotation at the shoulders, extension at the elbows and flexion of the wrists, fixed flexion of the knees, and severe equinovarus feet.

Title: Ash-Leaf Spots in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex
Description: Ash-leaf spots are depigmented areas present in > 90% of patients with tuberous sclerosis complex. The areas are 1 to 3 cm in length and may be more easily seen under ultraviolet light (Wood light).
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Puduvalli V: Atlas of Cancer. Edited by M Markman and R Gilbert. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Atelectasis and Left Lung Collapse (X-Ray)
Description: This chest x-ray shows collapse of the left lung due to a mucus plug.

Title: Atherosclerotic Plaque
Description: Cross-section of an artery with atheroma visible in the upper section.

Title: Atherosclerotic Plaque in Descending Aorta
Description: This CT scan with contrast shows atherosclerotic plaque in descending aorta (arrow).

Title: Atlantoaxial Subluxation
Description: X-rays of the cervical spine showing atlantoaxial subluxation and subaxial subluxation in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis. The lateral views of the cervical spine were taken in neck extension (on left) and flexion (on right). In flexion, the anterior arch of C1 is far anterior to the dens of C2 (posterior to the black arrow), indicating anterior subluxation. This finding is not evident in extension (black arrow), indicating that atlantoaxial subluxation is dynamic. Subaxial subluxation (white arrowheads) is also present at C2-C3 and C3-C4 in extension and at C3-C4 and C4-C5 in flexion.

Title: Atlantoaxial Subluxation
Description: X-rays of the cervical spine showing atlantoaxial subluxation and subaxial subluxation in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis. The lateral views of the cervical spine were taken in neck extension (on left) and flexion (on right). In flexion, the anterior arch of C1 is far anterior to the dens of C2 (posterior to the black arrow), indicating anterior subluxation. This finding is not evident in extension (black arrow), indicating that atlantoaxial subluxation is dynamic. Subaxial subluxation (white arrowheads) is also present at C2-C3 and C3-C4 in extension and at C3-C4 and C4-C5 in flexion.

Title: Atlantoaxial Subluxation (CT Scan)
Description: Multiplanar reformations of a CT scan of the cervical spine in the axial (1), coronal (2), and sagittal (3) planes show marked widening of the anterior atlantodental interval (ADI) secondary to pannus formation as occurs in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) (1, arrow; 3, long arrow), causing posterior subluxation and basilar impression of the C2 odontoid process (3, short arrow). The odontoid process is markedly eroded (2, arrow), a typical finding in RA.
Copyright: Image courtesy of A. John Tsiouris, MD.

Title: Atopic Dermatitis (Acute)
Description: Atopic dermatitis usually develops in infancy. In the acute phase, lesions appear on the face and then spread to the neck, scalp, and extremities.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Description: This cardiac MRI shows a left atrial myxoma (arrow).

Description: This image shows an atrial myxoma (indicated by the asterisk) in the right atrium (RA). Also visible on this echocardiographic image are the left atrium (LA) and a biopsy bioptome (indicated by the arrow) in the superior vena cava (SVC).

Description: This endoscopic view shows atrophic lining of the gastric fundus.

Description: This photo shows a rounded mole with irregular borders.

Title: Atypical Nevus
Description: This image shows an atypical nevus, with the characteristic irregular border and variable coloration.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Marie Schreiner, PA-C.

Title: Bacillary Angiomatosis (in an HIV-Infected Patient)
Description: This photo shows bright red, berry-like, friable, protuberant nodules in a man with bacillary angiomatosis.

Title: Bacterial Conjunctivitis
Description: This photo shows periorbital erythema and edema and purulent discharge (visible on the temporal eyelashes) in a patient with bacterial conjunctivitis. Itching is not usually a feature.

Title: Bacterial Tracheitis (Endoscopy)
Description: This image shows an endoscopic view of the trachea that shows inflammatory exudate characteristic of bacterial tracheitis.

Title: Bacterial Tracheitis (X-Ray)
Description: This image shows a lateral x-ray of the neck that shows diffuse irregularity of the trachea characteristic of bacterial tracheitis.

Title: Balanitis in Chlamydial Reactive Arthritis
Description: A small number of patients with chlamydial reactive arthritis experience a syndrome of arthritis accompanied by skin changes on their feet (keratoderma blennorrhagicum), conjunctivitis, uveitis, urethritis, or balanitis in reaction to chlamydial infection.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Drs. Weisner and Kaufman via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans
Description: The area around the urethral meatus is indurated and blanched. Scratching and rubbing have resulted in irritation and petechiae.

Title: Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans With Meatal Occlusion

TopicLocations.Title: Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans With Meatal Occlusion

Title: Balloon Atrial Septostomy (Rashkind Procedure)
Description: In the balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind procedure), a balloon-tipped catheter is advanced into the left atrium through the patent foramen ovale. The balloon is inflated and abruptly withdrawn to the right atrium thereby enlarging the opening in the atrial septum. The procedure immediately improves systemic arterial oxygen saturation.
TopicName: Transposition of the Great Arteries TGA

TopicLocations.Title: Balloon Atrial Septostomy (Rashkind Procedure)

Title: Bamboo Spine in Ankylosing Spondylitis
Description: This lateral view of the cervical spine shows a rigid cervical spine in a patient with severe, long-standing ankylosing spondylitis. The spine is completely ankylosed (“bamboo spine”) due to syndesmophytes, fused facet (apophyseal) joints, and paraspinal ligamentous calcification.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Asim Khan M: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Barium Enema Showing Mucosal Pseudopolyps
Description: This image of a patient with granulomatous colitis shows 2 clusters of large pseudopolyps in the descending colon.

Title: Barium Enema Showing Ulceration of the Colon Wall
Description: The left image shows aphthous ulcers. There are discrete erosions with a lucent halo on a background of normal mucosa. The right image shows pseudopolyps demonstrated by contrast defects (blue arrows) and also a deep ulcer (red arrow).
TopicName: X Ray and Other Imaging Contrast Studies of the Gastrointestinal Tract

Title: Barium Swallow Showing Dilated Esophagus with Narrow and Beaklike Appearance at Lower Esophageal Sphincter
Description: This image shows achalasia with proximal esophageal dilatation and incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. Note the inhomogeneous appearance of the material within the dilated esophagus due to undigested food that did not pass into the stomach (long arrows). In severe achalasia, only small quantities of contrast medium are able to pass through a beaklike esophagogastric junction (short arrows).

TopicLocations.Title: Barium Swallow Showing Dilated Esophagus with Narrow and Beaklike Appearance at Lower Esophageal Sphincter

Description: This image shows a Schatzki ring (arrow).

Description: This image shows a sliding hiatus hernia measuring 5 centimeters (5 cm) in axial length (dashed line indicates the diaphragmatic border).

Title: Barrett Esophagus
Description: In this image of Barrett esophagus, red-appearing bands of metaplastic epithelium can be seen extending proximally.
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Barrett Esophagus
Description: Most esophageal adenocarcinomas arise from Barrett esophagus. Barrett esophagus is replacement of normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus with metaplastic columnar epithelium during the healing phase of acute esophagitis. In this image, red-appearing bands of metaplastic epithelium can be seen extending proximally.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Bartholin Cyst
Description: Cysts are usually palpable near the vaginal orifice. They can distend the affected labia majora, causing vulvar asymmetry.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Kaufman R, Brown D. In Atlas of Clinical Gynecology: Gynecologic Pathology. Edited by M Stenchever (series editor) and B Goff. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1998.
TopicName: Bartholin Gland Cyst and Bartholin Gland Abscess

Title: Basal Cell Carcinoma
Description: This photo shows an advanced basal cell carcinoma on the cheek of a patient.

Title: Basal Cell Carcinoma of Eyelid
Description: This photo shows a rounded, erythematous, and ulcerated basal cell carcinoma on the lower eyelid. The loss of lashes of the lower lid is common in patients with eyelid cancers.
Copyright: RALPH C. EAGLE, JR/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Basilar Invagination (MRI)
Description: These figures (including the MRI scan) show basilar invagination. The odontoid process extends from the body of C2 and into the foramen magnum; as a result, the brain stem may be compressed.

Title: Basilar Invagination and Congenital Assimilation (CT)
Description: In this coronal view of a CT scan, C1 is fused to the skull base (congenitally). The odontoid process (indicated by arrow) extends into the skull base (basilar invagination).

Title: Beau Lines
Description: The transverse depression of the nail plate is easily appreciated looking at the nail from the side.

Title: Beau Lines Due to Chemotherapy
Description: This image shows Beau lines in a patient undergoing multiple cycles of chemotherapy. Each line corresponds to a cycle of treatment.

Title: Bedbug
Description: The bedbug depicted has the typical oval, reddish brown body. Its flatness suggests that it has not recently eaten.

Title: Bedbug (Frontal View)
Description: The bedbug depicted has the typical oval, reddish brown body.
Copyright: Image courtesy of CDC/Harvard University, Dr. Gary Alpert, Urban Pests–Integrated Pest Management (IPM); Dr. Harold Harlan; and Richard Pollack via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Bedbug Bites
Description: Papules with a central punctum suggest an arthropod bite. The bites in a line, as in this photo, are most indicative of bedbug bites ("breakfast, lunch, and dinner").

Title: Behçet Disease (Hypopyon)
Description: This photo shows pus (or hypopyon) in the anterior chamber of the eye in a patient with Behçet disease. A fine sediment of white blood cells is seen at the bottom of the iris (at lower center) between the iris and cornea. The pupil is enlarged, and the sclera is red with blood vessels.
TopicName: Uveitis Caused by Connective Tissue Disease

Title: Behçet Disease (Oral Lesions)
Description: This image shows aphthous-like lesions on the inner lower lip resulting from Behçet disease.

Title: Behçet Disease (Pathergy)
Description: This image shows an erythematous papular response to local skin injury characteristic of Beçhet disease.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Behçet Disease (Scrotal)
Description: This image shows a severe ulcer on the scrotum resulting from Beçhet disease.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Bell Palsy
Description: This patient has paralysis of his right facial muscles, which may be due to Bell palsy or to facial nerve (7th cranial nerve) paralysis due to another disorder.

Title: Benign Hypertensive Arteriolar Nephrosclerosis
Description: Benign hypertensive arteriolar nephrosclerosis is characterized histologically by arteriolar hyalinosis caused by insudation of plasma proteins and medial thickening caused by both hypertrophy and hyperplasia of vascular smooth muscle cells (periodic acid-Schiff stain, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Benign Laryngeal Tumor (Fibrolipoma)
Description: This endoscopic view of the larynx shows a fibrolipoma, a very rare benign tumor. A fibrolipoma is a growth of fibro-fatty tissue along a nerve.

Title: Benign Oral Growth (Irritation Fibroma)
Description: This photo shows an oral growth caused by chronic irritation. In this case, a fibroma on the inside of the cheek formed due to rubbing from orthodontic braces.

Title: Bezoar (Imaging Study Findings)
Description: In the x-ray image on the left, the bezoar is indicated by the midline upper abdominal large soft-tissue mass with a mottled pattern of intralesional gas (asterisks). In the coronal CT scan image on the right, the bezoar is indicated by the heterogenous mass (arrow). In both images, there is inferior displacement of the bowel loops.

Title: Bitot Spots
Description: This image shows discrete, foamy-appearing areas (Bitot spots, circled) on the conjunctiva.

Title: Black Widow Spider
Description: A black widow spider is typically one-half to one inch long. The female, which is more common, has a reddish hourglass marking (shown) on the abdomen.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Mike Cardwell (Extreme Wildlife Photography, Sacramento, CA).

Title: Bladder Cancer (CT Scan)
Description: This CT scan shows a right-sided bladder cancer.

Title: Bladder Diverticulum
Description: This image shows a cystogram with right-sided bladder diverticulum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Drs. Ronald Rabinowitz and Jimena Cubillos.

Title: Bladder Exstrophy
Description: This image shows a neonate with bladder exstrophy and complete epispadias.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Drs. Ronald Rabinowitz and Jimena Cubillos.

Title: Blastomycosis
Description: The left x-ray shows a right lower lobe consolidation that was mistaken for bacterial pneumonia. The right x-ray, taken three weeks later, shows disease progression with patchy bilateral airspace opacities and dense consolidation in the right lower lung.
Copyright: Images courtesy of Paschalis Vergidis, MD, MSc.

Title: Bleeding Esophageal Varix
Description: Hemorrhage from a ruptured varix (arrow).
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Blood Pressure Measurement
Description: The patient's arm should rest comfortably and the cuff should be approximately level with the heart.

Title: Blue Nevus
Description: This photo shows a blue nevus composed of dark pigmented cells (melanocytes).

Title: Body Louse (Pediculus humanus var. corporis)
Description: Louse-borne relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia recurrentis, which is transmitted to humans by body lice.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the World Health Organization and the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Body Louse (Pediculus humanus var. corporis)
Description: Louse-borne relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia recurrentis, which is transmitted to humans by body lice.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the World Health Organization and the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Bohler Angle
Description: The Bohler angle is formed by the intersection of a line drawn from the superior aspect of the posterior calcaneal tuberosity to the superior subtalar articular surface and a line drawn from the superior subtalar articular surface to the superior aspect of the anterior calcaneal process. Normally, the angle is 20 to 40°. An angle of < 20° suggests a fracture.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Bone Scintigraphy of the Whole Body
Description: Delayed whole-body technetium-99m bone scintigraphic image shows multiple foci of increased uptake consistent with metastatic disease.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Bones of the Hand
Description: In this view, the triquetrum overlaps (dorsal to) the pisiform and is not labeled.

Title: Bouchard Nodes
Description: Bouchard nodes are hard-tissue (bony) prominences of proximal interphalangeal joints, which in this photo are seen best on the digits of the right hand and the 1st and 2nd digits of the left hand.

Title: Boutonnière Deformity in Rheumatoid Arthritis
Description: There are multiple boutonnière deformities of the fingers and thumbs in this patient with advanced rheumatoid arthritis. Boutonnière deformity is characterized by flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joint and hyperextension at the distal interphalangeal joint. There also are multiple rheumatoid nodules over the knuckles and interphalangeal joints.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Matteson E, Mason T: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Bowenoid Papulosis
Description: Bowenoid papulosis is sometimes considered a premalignant lesion. It can manifest as brown to red papules on the genitalia, in this case the penile shaft.

Title: Bowing of the Tibia in Paget Disease
Description: This photo shows bowing of the tibia of the right leg (seen at left) in a patient with Paget disease.

TopicLocations.Title: Bowing of the Tibia in Paget Disease

Description: P = pressure; V = volume
TopicName: Airflow, Lung Volumes, and Flow Volume Loop

Description: This MRI scan shows multiple brain lesions, representing metastatic tumors. Over 80% of brain metastases are multiple.

Description: This image shows mural irregularity and narrowing (white arrows) in several branches of the ascending aorta.

Description: This photo shows a large, erythematous mass on the upper aspect of the right brwww. The mass was later diagnosed as cancer.

Description: This photo shows a small lump above the nipple. The lump was later diagnosed as a fibroadenoma.

Description: Muscle flap transfer using the lower rectus abdominis.

Title: Bronchiectasis (Computed Tomography)
Description: A chest CT in a patient with cystic fibrosis shows severe bronchiectasis in the upper lung zones with dilated airways and cystic changes. Arrows show the signet ring sign, where a dilated airway (the ring) is adjacent to a smaller artery (the top of the ring). Normally, airways are the same size as, or smaller than, the adjacent arteries.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Başak Çoruh, MD.

Title: Bronchiectasis (X-Ray)
Description: A chest radiograph in a patient with cystic fibrosis demonstrating upper lung zone predominant bronchiectasis. The white arrows are outlining the “tram-track sign,” a dilated airway with thickened walls that are parallel to one another (similar to a tram track).
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Başak Çoruh, MD.

Title: Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia (X-Ray and CT Findings)
Description: The infant in these images has a history of prematurity and bronchopulmonary dysplasia. The frontal chest x-ray on the left shows coarse reticular pulmonary opacities and hyperinflation in both lungs. The CT image on the right shows coarse reticular pulmonary opacities and disordered lung aeration caused by underlying alveolar septal fibrosis and hyperinflated lung parenchyma.

Title: Brown Recluse Spider
Description: The body of an adult brown recluse spider may be up to one-half inch long; adults may have a characteristic fiddle marking on the thorax (the part of the body where the legs are attached).
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Mike Cardwell (Extreme Wildlife Photography, Sacramento, CA).

Title: Brown Recluse Spider Bite
Description: This photo shows a necrotic lesion on the inner thigh resulting from brown recluse bite.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Thomas Arnold, MD.

Title: Bullous Impetigo (Abdomen)
Description: This photo shows bullous impetigo on an infant's abdomen. The infection begins as an erythematous patch, which develops into small pustules that join together, eventually forming crusty yellow blisters (bullae).

Title: Bullous Impetigo (Fingers)
Description: Bullous impetigo is a superficial skin infection that manifests as clusters of vesicles or pustules that enlarge rapidly to form bullae. The bullae burst and expose larger bases, which become covered with honey-colored varnish or crust.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Bullous Keratopathy
Description: This photo shows bullous keratopathy in a patient with Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy. The arrows show multiple medium-sized epithelial bullae. The light reflex is irregular, demonstrating multiple small bullae (showing microcystic edema). There is also general cloudiness of the cornea, which can be seen by the blurring of the iris border, for example, at the 6 o'clock position.

Title: Bullous Pemphigoid on the Arm
Description: This photo shows tense bullae, erosions, and crusts on the arm of a patient with bullous pemphigoid.

Title: Bullous Pemphigoid on the Arm and Hand
Description: This photo shows tense bullae, erosions, and hyperpigmentation on the arm of a patient with bullous pemphigoid.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Bullous Pemphigoid on the Arm and Hand

Title: Bullous Pemphigoid on the Foot
Description: This photo of a patient with bullous pemphigoid shows erythematous plaques with intact bullae and erosions on the lateral and dorsal foot.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Bullous Pemphigoid on the Legs
Description: This photo shows ruptured and unruptured bullous lesions on an erythematous base.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Daniel M. Peraza, MD.

Title: Bullous Pemphigoid on the Thigh
Description: This photo shows ruptured bullae and erosions on the thigh of a person with bullous pemphigoid.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Bunion with Hammertoe Radiographs
Description: Anteroposterior and lateral views of a bunion with a hammertoe of the second toe are shown. The anteroposterior view shows severe hallux valgus with medial deviation of the first metatarsal bone. There is abutment of the hallux to the second toe. The second digit is deviated laterally with narrowing of the second metatarsophalangeal joint (left). The lateral view shows the second toe is dislocated at the metatarsophalangeal joint. There is hyperflexion at the proximal interphalangeal joint with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint of the second toe (right).
Copyright: Images courtesy of James C. Connors, DPM.

Title: Burkitt Lymphoma
Description: This photo shows a large tumor of the jaw in a patient with Burkitt lymphoma.

Title: Bursitis of the Prepatellar Bursa
Description: This photo shows a side view of a red and inflamed knee in a patient with prepatellar bursitis (housemaid's knee).

Title: Button Batteries in Cecum (Endoscopy)
Copyright: Image courtesy of Zubair Malik, MD.

Title: Calcaneal Fracture
Description: This x-ray shows a comminuted fracture of the calcaneus.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Calciphylaxis (Trunk)
Description: This image shows early skin changes of ischemia and necrosis in localized areas resulting from calciphylaxis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Calcium Pyrophosphate Dihydrate Crystals
Description: This image shows calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals extracted from synovial fluid viewed under polarized light microscopy. (The red arrow in the upper right indicates the axis of a red compensator, a device used to determine the alignment of the crystals. The positively birefringent CPPD crystals appear blue when parallel to the optical axis of the compensator and yellow when perpendicular to it.)
