Title: Callus (Heel)
Description: A callus is a toughened area of skin that has become relatively thick and hard in response to repeated friction, pressure, or other irritation.

Title: Candidal Stomatitis
Description: Denture-induced stomatitis is a candidal infection and overgrowth that affects both mucosal and denture surfaces.
Copyright: Image provided by Jonathan A. Ship, DMD.

Title: Candidiasis (Chronic Mucocutaneous)
Description: Patients with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis are anergic to Candida. They develop red, pustular, thickened, crusted plaques that may appear psoriatic. Plaques may appear on the nose, forehead, and elsewhere.

Title: Candidiasis (Nail Infection)
Description: Candidal nail infections can involve the full thickness of the nail plate (onychomycosis), the edges of the nail (paronychia), or both.

Description: Candidal nail infections can involve the full thickness of the nail plate (onychomycosis), the edges of the nail (paronychia), or both.
Copyright: Image courtesy of CDC/Sherry Brinkman via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Candidiasis (Oral)
Description: Oral candidiasis takes many forms, including angular cheilitis and pseudomembranous plaques on the oral mucosae, which can be associated with dentures, as in this image (top), or develop on the tongue (bottom) or pharynx.
Copyright: Images courtesy of Jonathan Ship, MD.

Title: Candidiasis (Oral)
Description: Oral candidiasis takes many forms, including angular cheilitis and pseudomembranous plaques on the oral mucosae, which can be associated with dentures, as in this image (top), or develop on the tongue (bottom) or pharynx.
Copyright: Images courtesy of Jonathan Ship, MD.

Title: Candidiasis Infection of the Intertriginous Areas of Abdomen and Groin
Description: This photo shows erythema and superficial ulceration in intertriginous areas of abdomen and groin caused by overgrowth of Candida.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Hardin via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

TopicLocations.Title: Candidiasis Infection of the Intertriginous Areas of Abdomen and Groin

Title: Capillaroscopy
Description: This image shows dilated capillary loops (arrowheads), a dropout area (asterisk), which means the capillary ends prematurely and drops out and therefore looks shorter than the others, and periungual hemorrhages (circles) in the nail fold of a patient with systemic sclerosis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Sanjeev Patil, MD.

Title: Carbuncle
Description: This photo shows a carbuncle found on the back of the neck. It is formed by a cluster of interconnected furuncles, which are painful, pus-filled, inflamed hair follicles.

Title: Carcinoid Syndrome (Facial Flushing)
Description: This photo shows flushing due to carcinoid syndrome.

Title: Cardiac Action Potential
Description: This schema shows a single cardiac action potential cycle as described in the text.

Title: Cardiac CT (3D Scan of Prosthetic Heart Valve)
Description: This is an oblique view of the left side, looking toward the front of the chest (left). The prosthetic heart valve (white) is visible at center, where the aorta (upper center) meets the heart (lower center). The stitches used to close the chest are visible at upper left.

TopicLocations.Title: Cardiac CT (3D Scan of Prosthetic Heart Valve)

Title: Cardiac CT Angiogram
Description: Cross sectional view of a cardiac CT angiogram shows the left ventricle and the left anterior descending artery.
Copyright: LIVING ART ENTERPRISES, LLC/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Cardiac MRI Showing Normal Cardiac Anatomy
Description: This image shows a normal left ventricle (red arrow), right ventricle (blue arrow), and myocardium (green arrow). Papillary muscles (purple arrow) are also visible.

TopicLocations.Title: Cardiac MRI Showing Normal Cardiac Anatomy

Description: New and recurrent dental caries in a patient with dry mouth.
Copyright: Image provided by Jonathan A. Ship, DMD.

Copyright: Image provided by James Ubertalli, DMD.

Title: Casal Necklace
Description: This photo shows hyperpigmented scaly rash in the shape of a necklace in a patient with pellagra.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Cataract
Description: This patient has a large cataract in the right eye (left on the screen). The cataract is the light-blue opaque mass behind the darker iris.

Description: This photo shows deformed cartilage in the superior aspect of the pinna.

Title: Cavernous Hemangioma
Description: In this image, the axial (top) and coronal (bottom) CT scans show a well-demarcated intraconal mass behind the left globe. The mass is a cavernous venous malformation.
Copyright: Images courtesy of James Garrity, MD.

Title: Cecal Volvulus (Abdominal X-Ray)
Description: In this abdominal x-ray, the cecum has twisted around its mesentery, causing a dilated "coffee bean" to project toward the left upper quadrant.
Copyright: Image provided by Parswa Ansari, MD.

Title: Cellulitis
Description: This example of cellulitis at the site of a previous vaccination shows warm, erythematous, edematous skin with formation of bullae.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Allen W. Mathies, MD, California Emergency Preparedness Office, Immunization Branch, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Centipede
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion
Description: In acute central retinal artery occlusion, diffuse retinal edema makes the retina appear pale and the arteries become attenuated. The underlying perfused choroid shows through the thin fovea giving the classic cherry-red spot appearance.
TopicName: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion and Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion

TopicLocations.Title: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion
TopicLocations.TopicName: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion and Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion

Title: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion
Description: In central retinal vein occlusion, retinal veins appear dilated and tortuous. The fundus may appear congested and edematous. Numerous retinal hemorrhages are also characteristic.
TopicName: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion and Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion

TopicLocations.Title: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion

Title: Cerebellar Abscess
Description: This gadolinium-enhanced MRI scan shows a cerebellar abscess, which appears as a large, rim-enhancing cavitary lesion in the left cerebellar hemisphere.
Copyright: Courtesy of John E. Greenlee, MD.

Title: Cerebellar Hemangioblastoma (MRI)
Description: This sagittal T1-weighted magnetic resonance image without contrast shows a partially cystic and solid mass in the inferior cerebellum with associated mass effect. This is the most common appearance of a hemangioblastoma. This tumor is seen with increased frequency in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.

Title: Cervical Cancer
Description: Colposcopy of a cervix (center) in a patient with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 1. The affected precancerous area is slightly puffy with a discolored area around the os (cervical opening) at center.

Title: Cervical Osteoarthritis
Description: The upper cervical vertebrae are healthy, well spaced, and smooth edged. The arthritic lower vertebrae are closer together and have rough and ragged edges.

Title: Cervical Polyp
Description: A cervical polyp (bright red and round at center) is seen through a cervical speculum.

Title: Cervical Spine Involvement in Rheumatoid Arthritis
Description: These flexion and extension x-rays of the cervical spine show widening of the atlantoaxial distance measuring up to 5 mm on the flexion view, which reduces with extension.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Kinanah Yaseen, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Cervical Spine Involvement in Rheumatoid Arthritis

Title: Cervical Vertebral Body Fracture
Description: This lateral view of the cervical spine shows a fracture of the inferior, anterior aspect of the 6th vertebral body (arrow).

Title: Cervicofacial Actinomycosis
Description: Drainage from a preaural lesion originating from sinus tract is shown.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Thomas F. Sellers, Emory University, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Cervicothoracic Syringohydromyelia
Description: Sagittal post-contrast T1-weighted MRI shows a large T1 hypointense intramedullary spinal cord cavity characteristic of a syrinx (yellow arrow). It extends from the C2-C3 cervical level inferiorly in a child with a known Chiari I malformation (pink arrow). This finding is defined as syringohydromyelia because syringomyelia (an eccentric spinal cord cavity) cannot be differentiated from hydromyelia (a central spinal cord cavity) by imaging.
Copyright: Courtesy of John Tsiouris, MD, Division of Neuroradiology, New York–Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center.
TopicName: Syrinx of the Spinal Cord or Brain Stem

TopicLocations.Title: Cervicothoracic Syringohydromyelia
TopicLocations.TopicName: Syrinx of the Spinal Cord or Brain Stem

Title: Chalazion
Description: In its initial stages, a chalazion is clinically indistinguishable from a hordeolum.

Title: Chancroid
Description: Painful penile papules or pustules are characteristic of chancroid. Many patients have accompanying tender (and sometimes fluctuant, suppurative) inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Pirozzi via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Chemotherapy-Induced Anagen Effluvium
Description: Anagen effluvium is a physiologic disruption of the anagen (growing) phase. It typically occurs several weeks after chemotherapy or radiation therapy. This photo shows an abrupt loss of hairs in the anagen phase along with sparse broken anagen hairs.

Title: Chest CT Scan in Pulmonary Sarcoidosis
Description: This high-resolution CT of the chest of a patient with pulmonary sarcoidosis shows thickening of the bronchovascular bundles and beading of the interlobular septa.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Birendra P. Sah, MD, FCCP.

TopicLocations.Title: Chest CT Scan in Pulmonary Sarcoidosis

Title: Chest X-Ray (Prosthetic Heart Valve)
Description: Signs of left atrial enlargement include a visible density of the left atrium in the right hemithorax (blue arrow, double-density sign), increased (> 7 cm) distance between the left atrial edge in the right hemithorax and the left mainstem bronchus, a convexity along the upper left heart border caused by enlargement of the left atrial appendage (red arrow), and widening of the carina with increased separation between the left and right mainstem bronchi. Signs of left ventricular enlargement include an enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and leftward and inferior displacement of the left heart border.

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient After Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery
Description: Frontal and lateral chest x-ray of a patient post coronary artery bypass surgery showing sternal sutures (black arrow) and surgical clips (red arrow).

TopicLocations.Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient After Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with a Biventricular (bi-V) Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD)
Description: This patient has a biV ICD in the left upper chest with leads in the right atrium (1), left ventricle (2) and right ventricle (3).

TopicLocations.Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with a Biventricular (bi-V) Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD)

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with an Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator
Description: This patient has an ICD with a single lead in right ventricle (1). Note also the sternal sutures denoting a history of thoracic surgery.

TopicLocations.Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with an Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Bilateral Pleural Effusions
Description: This patient has bilateral pleural effusions (arrows). The normally sharp costophrenic angles are obscured by fluid in this patient.

TopicLocations.Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Bilateral Pleural Effusions

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Cardiomegaly and Cephalization
Description: This patient has cardiomegaly (width of cardiac silhouette is > 50% of thoracic cage on a posterior-anterior chest x-ray). The patient also has cephalization (black arrows) whereby upper lobe pulmonary vessels become more prominent. These findings are often seen in patients with heart failure.

TopicLocations.Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Cardiomegaly and Cephalization

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Constrictive Pericarditis
Description: This patient with constrictive pericarditis has significant pericardial calcification (white arrows).

TopicLocations.Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Constrictive Pericarditis

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Fluid in Minor and Major Fissures
Description: Lateral chest x-ray in a patient with fluid in major (1) and minor (2) fissures as well as a loculated effusion (3) seen along right posterior chest wall.

TopicLocations.Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Fluid in Minor and Major Fissures

Description: This x-ray shows a patient with a pacemaker in the left upper chest with leads in the right atrium (1) and right ventricle (2).

Title: Chest X-Ray of a Patient with Pericardial Effusion
Description: This x-ray shows enlarged cardiac silhouette in a patient with a pericardial effusion.

Description: This x-ray shows bilateral perihilar patchy opacities in a "bat-wing" or "butterfly" pattern consistent with cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

Title: Chickenpox (Back)
Description: This photo shows the back of a boy with a chickenpox rash.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Ann Cain via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Chickenpox (Face)
Description: This photo shows round, fluid-filled blisters caused by chickenpox affecting the face.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Renelle Woodall via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Chilblains (Pernio) (Finger)
Description: In this photo of chilblains, the middle phalanx has areas of localized erythema and appears swollen.

Title: Chilblains (Toes)
Description: This image shows the swelling and erythema of chilblains.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Chillblains (Pernio) (Toes)
Description: This image shows swelling and blistering on the pads of the toes resulting from repeated cold exposure without freezing.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Cholesteatoma
Description: In this image, the view along the external ear canal shows a large cholesteatoma (white mass on left superior to the short process of the malleus), resulting in a perforation of the tympanic membrane.
Copyright: PROFESSOR TONY WRIGHT, INSTITUTE OF LARYNGOLOGY & OTOLOGY/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Cholesterol Crystal Embolization
Description: This patient developed painful blue toes and ulceration 6 weeks after coronary angiography and stenting. Aortofemoral angiography revealed diffuse atherosclerosis of the aorta and femoral and popliteal arteries, suggesting that cholesterol emboli caused ischemia of the toes.

Title: Chondroblastoma
Description: This shoulder x-ray shows a chondroblastoma in the humerus at the end of the bone (arrows).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Chondromyxoid Fibroma
Description: This x-ray of the knee shows a chondromyxoid fibroma in the tibia below the knee (arrows), expanding the bone in the front.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Chondrosarcoma of the Humerus
Description: This shoulder x-ray shows a long calcified lesion in the humerus (arrows) with thickening of the bone surface, as well as loss of trabecular bone inside replaced by sarcomatous semi-calcified matrix. The cortex shows significant scalloping; some areas of destruction through the cortex.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Chordoma
Description: This MRI shows a tumor near the end of the spine and coccyx with bone destruction and soft tissue mass (arrows), typical of a chordoma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Choroidal Melanoma
Description: This image shows choroidal melanoma with overlying subretinal fluid.

Title: Chromoblastomycosis
Description: This photo shows extensive chromoblastomycosis involving the right lower extremity. Multiple verrucous and tumorous lesions can be seen.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Chromoblastomycosis (Chronic)
Description: In chronic chromoblastomycosis, hard, dull, red or grayish, cauliflower-shaped nodular projections develop over years and extend to cover the extremities.

Title: Chromoblastomycosis (Early)
Description: In chromoblastomycosis, small papules initially extend to form dull red or violaceous, sharply demarcated patches with indurated bases.

Title: Chronic Blepharitis
Description: This patient has chronic blepharitis (inflammation with mild edema and erythema) of the eyelids, in this case due to atopic dermatitis (eczema). Note the inversion of the lower eyelid (entropion), which hides those lashes from view.

Title: Chronic Dacryocystitis
Description: Chronic dacryocystitis, often due to longstanding nasolacrimal duct obstruction, can manifest as bulging of the skin over the lacrimal sac. When pressure is applied, the bulge may not be painful, but a puslike material often comes out of the punctum.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of James Garrity, MD.

Title: Chronic Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
Description: This photo shows chronic discoid lupus erythematosus with characteristic hyperkeratotic and erythematous plaques.

Title: Chronic Gastritis
Description: Notice the atrophic appearance, which is consistent with chronic gastritis.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Chronic Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis
Description: High-resolution CT shows findings of fibrosis, including irregular reticulation and traction bronchiectasis. Areas of decreased lung density are compatible with regions of airway obstruction. This combination of findings is suggestive of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Harold R. Collard, MD.

Title: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (Chest X-ray)
Description: Chest x-ray of a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The lungs are hyperinflated, the diaphragm is flattened, vascular markings are increased, and the heart size is marginally increased.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Barnes P. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Chronic Paronychia of Second (Index) Fingernail
Description: Signs of chronic paronychia in this patient include absent cuticle, swollen proximal nail fold, and Beau lines of the nail plate.

Title: Chronic Paronychia With Nail Plate Swelling, Absence of the Cuticle, and Abnormalities of the Nail Plate

TopicLocations.Title: Chronic Paronychia With Nail Plate Swelling, Absence of the Cuticle, and Abnormalities of the Nail Plate

TopicLocations.Title: Chronic Paronychia With Swollen Proximal Nail Fold and Loss of Cuticle

Title: Chronic Periodontitis
Description: This photo shows chronic plaque-induced inflammation of the soft tissues resulting in loss gum tissue, supporting bone, tooth movement, and loss of teeth.
Copyright: Image provided by Jonathan A. Ship, DMD.

Title: Chronic Radiodermatitis
Description: Chronic radiodermatitis on the mastectomy site due to postoperative radiotherapy. Note the associated radiation hyperkeratotic plaques overlying an area of the skin consisting of hypopigmentation, hyperpigmentation, telangiectasias, and atrophy (a condition known as poikiloderma).

Title: Chronic Retronychia
Description: This photo shows a chronic retronychia. The redness, swelling, and tenderness of the nail fold help differentiate it from uncomplicated onycholysis. The cuticle is absent.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Chris G. Adigun, MD.

Title: Chronic Retronychia (Big Toes)
Description: Findings characteristic of chronic retronychia in this photo include the layered appearance of the nail plate and absent cuticle.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Chris G. Adigun, MD.

Title: Chronic Urate Nephropathy
Description: Biopsy specimen demonstrates microtophi comprising needle-shaped crystals within the tubule, with tubular degeneration and surrounding inflammatory reaction and fibrosis. Tophus formation is now rare, and biopsy findings are typically nonspecific and include arteriolosclerosis, interstitial fibrosis, and tubular atrophy (hematoxylin-eosin stain, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Circinate Balanitis Secondary to Reactive Arthritis
Description: The ulcers in this photo are shallow and relatively painless.

TopicLocations.Title: Circinate Balanitis Secondary to Reactive Arthritis

Title: Cirrhosis (Palmar Erythema)
Description: This photo shows the crimson color of the palms, fingertips, thenar, and hypothenar eminences in a patient with cirrhosis.
TopicName: Evaluation of the Patient With a Liver Disorder

TopicLocations.TopicName: Evaluation of the Patient With a Liver Disorder

Title: Classic Scabies
Description: A pruritic, pustular rash in the webbing between fingers is the hallmark of classic scabies.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Clavicle Fracture
Description: This anteroposterior x-ray view shows a displaced fracture of the middle third of the clavicle (class A fracture).

Title: Clenched Fist in Trisomy 18
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Public Health Image Library.

Title: Clenched Fist With Polydactyly
Description: This photo shows the hand of an infant with trisomy 18. Note the clenched fist and postaxial polydactyly.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Nina Powell-Hamilton, MD, FAAP, FACMG.

Title: Clostridial Myonecrosis (Spontaneous)
Description: This image shows tissue hemorrhage and hemorrhagic bullae involving the buttocks and perineum in a patient with clostridial myonecrosis.

Title: Clostridial Myonecrosis of Gas Gangrene (Traumatic)
Description: The skin over the infected area develops a bronze appearance. The skin is edematous, tense, and exquisitely tender with overlying bullae on the dorsum of the wrist and hand.

Title: Clostridial Myonecrosis of Gas Gangrene (Traumatic)
Description: The skin over the infected area develops a bronze appearance. The skin is edematous, tense, and exquisitely tender with overlying bullae on the dorsum of the wrist and hand.

Title: Clue Cells
Description: Clue cells are epithelial cells with bacteria adhering to their surface and sometimes obscuring their borders. Clue cells indicate bacterial vaginosis.
Copyright: Image obtained from the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Coccidioidomycosis
Description: Hypersensitivity to Coccidioides immitis antigens may manifest as erythema nodosum, arthritis, conjunctivitis, or erythema multiforme. This image is an example of erythema multiforme due to coccidioidomycosis.

Title: Cochlear Implant
Description: This illustration of a cochlear implant in the ear shows how sound travels to the brain. The transmitter is worn behind the ear (shown here next to the ear), linked to a transmitting antenna placed under the scalp, which transmits sound to a receiver placed under the skin, to the electrode array rolled up in the inner ear duct (in the cochlea). Sound is transmitted to the auditory nerve and to the brain.

Title: Cochlear Implant (Child)
Description: The implant consists of the sound processor that fits behind the ear, which passes sound signals to the transmitter (circular) attached to the scalp. The transmitter sends the information to electrodes implanted in the cochlea of the inner ear. The electrical impulses from the cochlea are passed to the brain, allowing the person to hear.

Title: Cold-Induced Urticaria
Description: This photo shows a positive ice cube test in a patient with idiopathic cold-induced urticaria. This photo was taken 5 minutes after the ice cube was removed.

Title: Collapsing Glomerulopathy
Description: Wrinkling or collapse of the glomerular tuft, accompanied here by microcystic dilation of tubules, may occur with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis or HIV-associated nephropathy and is a marker of unfavorable prognosis (Jones silver stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Coloboma
Description: This photo shows bilateral coloboma with enlarged pupils extending to the lower edge of the iris of each eye.

Title: Color Doppler Ultrasonography
Description: Color Doppler ultrasonography of the left carotid artery shows normal arterial flow without significant stenosis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Colorectal Cancer
Description: This image shows a colonoscopic view of adenocarcinoma of the colon.

Title: Combined Laryngocele
Description: This coronal CT scan shows a combined laryngocele that begins inside the larynx and extends through the thyrohyoid membrane, causing a mass in the neck.
Copyright: Image provided by Clarence T. Sasaki, MD.

Title: Comet Tail Artifact
Description: Sonographic "comet tail artifact" (white arrow) inferior to rib (black arrows) on thoracic ultrasonography. Comet tail artifact corresponds to the x-ray finding of Kerley B lines.

Title: Comminuted Fracture of the Great Toe
Description: This anteroposterior view shows a comminuted fracture of the great toe distal phalanx. This finding suggests a crush mechanism.

TopicLocations.Title: Comminuted Fracture of the Great Toe

Title: Common Wart
Description: This photo shows a large common wart (sharply demarcated, firm, rough, round nodule) on the finger.

Title: Complications of Leprosy (Hands)
Description: This photo shows severe mutilation and degeneration of digits in a patient with leprosy.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Arthur E. Kaye via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Complications of Leprosy (Nose)
Description: This photo shows a depressed nasal bridge due to disintegration of the nasal cartilage.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Andre J. Lebrun via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Compound Nevus
Description: A compound nevus is a well-demarcated brown papule.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Marie Schreiner, PA-C.

Title: Compression Fracture of a Lumbar Vertebra
Description: This coronal (frontal) view from a CT shows a fracture through the superior aspect of the body of the 2nd lumbar vertebra.
Copyright: Living Art Enterprises, LLC /SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Compressive Myelopathy
Description: Sagittal T2-weighted MRI shows spinal cord compression at the C4-5, C5-6, and C6-7 intervertebral levels secondary to multilevel posterior disk herniations (pink arrows). The intramedullary T2 signal is abnormally increased, representing spinal cord edema (yellow arrow). The normal spinal cord signal is seen at the C2 level (blue arrow).
Copyright: Courtesy of John Tsiouris, MD, Division of Neuroradiology, New York–Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center.

Title: Congenital Hydrocele
Description: This photo shows marked scrotal swelling caused by a hydrocele. Note the absence of inflammation.

Title: Congenital Melanocytic Nevus
Description: Congenital melanocytic nevus (giant congenital nevus) is a risk factor for malignant melanoma. Note the large size (> 20 cm), irregular border, and heterogeneous color.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Carl Washington, MD and Mona Saraiya, MD, MPH via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Congenital Syphilis (Rash)
Description: This photo shows vesiculobullous rash on the palm, axilla, and face of a newborn with congenital syphilis.

Title: Congenital Toxoplasmosis
Description: This CT scan shows scattered intracranial calcifications.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Demmler G: Congenital and perinatal infections. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Pediatric Infectious Diseases. Edited by CM Wilfert. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1998.

Title: Conjunctivitis in Chlamydial Reactive Arthritis
Description: A small number of patients with chlamydial reactive arthritis experience a syndrome of arthritis accompanied by skin changes on their feet (keratoderma blennorrhagicum), conjunctivitis, uveitis, urethritis, or balanitis in reaction to chlamydial infection.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Joe Miller via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Contact Dermatitis (Allergic)
Description: Skin manifestations of allergic contact dermatitis range from erythema through vesiculation to edema with bullae. Changes often occur in a pattern or distribution that suggests a specific exposure. In this image, linear streaking on an extremity suggests plant contact (eg, poison ivy or poison sumac).
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: COPD with Bullae
Description: This chest x-ray shows a large bulla in the upper right lung and 2 large bullae in the left lung.

Title: Cor Pulmonale (Echocardiogram)
Description: Short-axis view demonstrating a markedly enlarged right ventricle (RV) with RV hypertrophy. Abnormal bowing of the interventricular septum into the left ventricle (LV) gives a characteristic D configuration of the LV, consistent with volume and pressure overload of the RV.

Title: Coral Snake
Description: The repeating pattern of alternating red, yellow (cream), black, and yellow (cream) bands distinguishes the coral snake in the US.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Mike Cardwell (Victorville, CA).

Title: Corn (Little Toe)
Description: The corn (center of the little toe) is a disk of hardened tissue, often surrounded by reddened skin.

Title: Corneal Abrasion
Description: This photo shows a corneal abrasion seen on fluorescein stain. This patient's corneal abrasion was due to bamboo scratching the eye.

Title: Corneal Transplant
Description: Postoperative view of a corneal transplant held in place with extremely fine sutures.
Copyright: RALPH C. EAGLE, JR./SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Corneal Ulcer
Description:
The top image shows a bacterial corneal ulcer with opacity (usually just a gray-white opacity, but yellowish green in this photo because it was stained with fluorescein dye), demonstrating a corneal epithelial defect. The patient also has conjunctival hyperemia. A hypopyon (accumulation of WBCs in the anterior chamber) is layered in the inferior anterior chamber (arrow). The bottom image shows improvement after 1 week of intensive topical antibiotic treatment.

    Images courtesy of Sadeer Hannush, MD.

Title: Coronal Reconstruction CT Pulmonary Angiography
Description: Coronal reconstruction CT pulmonary angiogram shows an extensive pulmonary embolus in both pulmonary arteries (arrows).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Coronary Angiography
Description: A catheter (upper left) is placed at the os of the left main coronary artery. Contrast is then injected into the coronary arteries under fluoroscopy to detect any anomalies such as stenoses.

Description: This photo shows diffuse scaling and hyperkeratotic plaques in a patient with HIV and crusted scabies.

Title: Cryoglobulinemia

Title: Cryptococcosis (Central Nervous System)
Description: In an immunosuppressed host, cryptococcal infection may manifest as focal brain lesions called cryptococcomas.

Title: Cryptococcosis (Disseminated)
Description: Disseminated cryptococcosis may manifest as pustular, papular, nodular, or ulcerated skin lesions. Lesions can resemble those of acne, molluscum contagiosum, or basal cell carcinoma.

Title: Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia
Description: High-resolution CT shows patchy airspace consolidation, ground-glass opacities, small nodular opacities, and bronchial wall thickening and dilation (air bronchograms).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Talmadge E. King, MD.

Title: Cryptorchidism (Undescended Testis)
Description: In this photo, the patient has cryptorchidism of the left testis, which is not palpable on physical examination. The left hemiscrotum is hypoplastic.

Title: CT Angiography Showing Gastrointestinal Bleed
Description: These images show CT angiography aspects of acute lower gastrointestinal bleeding originating from a right colonic diverticula. The top left image shows an unenhanced view. The top right image shows the arterial phase with extravasated contrast medium inside the diverticulum (arrow). The bottom left image shows the portal phase with an increase in the blush within the colonic lumen (arrows). The bottom right image shows the corresponding coronal maximum intensity projection (MIP) view (arrow).

Title: Dermatitis Herpetiformis Caused by Celiac Disease
Description: Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized by clusters of intensely pruritic, erythematous, urticarial lesions, as well as vesicles, papules, and bullae, usually distributed symmetrically on extensor surfaces.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

TopicLocations.Title: Dermatitis Herpetiformis Caused by Celiac Disease

Title: Dermatitis Herpetiformis on the Elbows
Description: This photo shows dermatitis herpetiformis (with a symmetric pruritic papulovesicular rash) on the extensor surface of the elbows.

Description: This photo shows dermatitis herpetiformis (with a symmetric pruritic papulovesicular rash) on the extensor surface of the elbows.

Title: Dermatofibroma
Description: This photo shows a small hyperpigmented lesion consistent with dermatofibroma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Marie Schreiner, PA-C.

Title: Dermatographism
Description: Dermatographism, or skin-writing, may occur when the skin is lightly scratched and results in raised red lines.

Title: Dermatomyositis
Description: Dermatomyositis may manifest with a dusky, erythematous rash on the dorsum of the hand, including the radiodorsal aspects of the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints (Gottron papules). Dermatomyositis has an increased risk of brwww, lung, ovarian, and gastrointestinal cancers in adults over age 40.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Dermatomyositis (Hand Findings)
Description: This photo shows Gottron papules (on metacarpophalangeal joints), subcutaneous calcifications (on metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints), and periungual erythema and thickening.

Title: Dermatomyositis (Neck)
Description: This image shows dusky, erythematous skin changes resulting from dermatomyositis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Dermatomyositis (Resulting From Colon Cancer)
Description: This photo shows the cutaneous manifestation dermatomyositis in a patient with colon cancer. The dusky, erythematous rash in the V of the neck and shoulders is characteristic of dermatomyositis.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Dermatophytid Reaction
Description: This dermatophytid (identity, or id) reaction manifests as copious vesicles on the fingers.
Copyright: Image courtesy of CDC/Dr. Lucille K. Georg via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Dermatosis Papulosa Nigra
Description: This photo shows multiple, small seborrheic keratoses on the cheekbones and forehead of a person with dark skin.

Title: Diabetic Nephropathy (Hyalinosis)
Description: Hyalinosis of both afferent and efferent arterioles.
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Diabetic Nephropathy (Mesangial Cell Proliferation and Matrix Expansion)
Description: Mesangial cell proliferation and matrix expansion with endothelial damage are manifest here as thickened glomerular basement membranes without evident immune complex deposits (periodic acid-Schiff stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

TopicLocations.Title: Diabetic Nephropathy (Mesangial Cell Proliferation and Matrix Expansion)

Title: Diabetic Nephropathy (Nodules)
Description: Formation of acellular nodules within mesangial matrix is a distinctive feature of diabetic nephropathy (periodic acid-Schiff stain, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Diabetic Retinopathy (Nonproliferative)
Description: Funduscopic features of nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy include retinal hemorrhages and hard exudates (yellow patches).

Title: Diabetic Retinopathy (Proliferative)
Description: The key funduscopic feature of proliferative diabetic retinopathy is neovascularization, seen here around the optic disk.

Title: Diaper Dermatitis With Papulopustules
Description: These photos show infants with diaper dermatitis and satellite papulopustules, characteristic of superinfection.

Title: Diaphragmatic Hernia
Description: This x-ray shows congenital diaphragmatic hernia in a newborn. The intestines (white coils) are protruding into the left chest (right side of x-ray).
Copyright: DU CANE MEDICAL IMAGING LTD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Dieulafoy Lesion
Description: Dieulafoy lesion is a large artery that penetrates the gastric wall. It is significant because it can erode through the mucosa and cause massive hemorrhage.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage
Description: High- resolution CT image of 28-year-old female with antiphospholipid syndrome with recurrent diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Image shows bilateral and patchy alveolar ground glass opacities with subpleural sparing. Bronchoalveolar lavage confirmed alveolar hemorrhage.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Joyce Lee, MD.

Title: Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (CT Scan)
Description: This CT scan of the lumbar spine in a patient with diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis shows normal vertebral body heights with diffuse anterior flowing osteophytes with maintained disc spaces.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Kinanah Yaseen, MD.

Title: Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (X-Ray)
Description: Characteristic x-ray changes include large ossifications anterior to vertebral bodies (the calcification appears as if someone poured candle wax in front and on the sides of the vertebrae), bridging several vertebrae.
Copyright: Image provided by Roy Altman, MD.

Title: Digital Subtraction Angiography
Description: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) of the left vertebral artery shows a focal area of stenosis (arrow).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Dilated Capillary Loops
Description: This image shows dilated capillary loops (arrowheads) in the nail fold of a patient with systemic sclerosis. Also seen is a dropout area (asterisk), which means the capillary ends prematurely and drops out and therefore looks shorter than the others.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Sanjeev Patil, MD.

Title: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (Chest X-Ray)
Description: This x-ray shows severe cardiomegaly in a patient with dilated cardiomyopathy.

Title: Diphtheria (Cutaneous)

Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Diphtheria (Nasopharyngeal Membrane)

Copyright: Image courtesy of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Diphtheria (Nasopharyngeal With Bull Neck)
Description: In acute nasopharyngeal diphtheria, local edema may cause a visibly swollen neck (bull neck).
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Double-Bubble Effect
Description: This x-ray shows the typical double-bubble effect seen with complete duodenal obstruction. The smaller bubble represents the proximal, dilated duodenum (white arrow); the larger bubble represents the stomach (black arrow). This effect can be seen with duodenal atresia, duodenal web, annular pancreas, and preduodenal portal vein. Rarely, it can also be seen with complete duodenal obstruction resulting from Ladd bands in a patient with malrotation.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Langer J: Gastroenterology and Hepatology: Pediatric Gastrointestinal Problems. Edited by M Feldman (series editor) and PE Hyman. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1997.

Title: Dyshidrotic Dermatitis
Description: This photo shows vesicles and hyperkeratosis on the sole of a patient with dyshidrotic foot dermatitis. A small blister on the base of the fifth toe and a ruptured bullous lesion at the base of the fourth toe indicate initial progression to pompholyx affecting the foot (podopompholyx).

Title: Dysplastic Nevi (Atypical Moles)
Description: This photo shows the back of a patient with numerous pigmented atypical moles.
Copyright: MID ESSEX HOSPITAL SERVICES NHS TRUST / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa
Description: This photo shows hypopigmented scarring overlying bony prominences.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Ear Pit
Description: This photo shows a child with two ear pits. The black arrow points to the more common preauricular pit, and the white arrow points to a less common helical pit adjacent to the notch in the helix.

Title: Ear Tag
Description: An ear tag (arrow) is a congenital abnormality.

Title: Early Laryngeal Cancer
Description: This patient had an early glottic laryngeal cancer, here visible on one vocal cord on endoscopy (left image, white arrow) as excrescences, and on CT (right image, white arrow) as an abnormal soft tissue density.

Title: Early Venous Stasis Ulcer
Description: Venous stasis includes lichenification and hyperpigmentation. A shallow ulcer is developing superior to the medial malleolus.
TopicName: Chronic Venous Insufficiency and Post Thrombotic Syndrome

Title: Ecchymoses
Description: Ecchymoses are the large purple bruises seen on the leg of this patient.

Title: Ecchymoses in Immune Thrombocytopenia
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Deitcher S. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Echocardiogram (4-Chamber View)
Description: This image shows all 4 cardiac chambers and the tricuspid and mitral valves. 1 = right ventricle; 2 = left ventricle; 3 = left atrium; 4 = right atrium.

Title: Ecthyma
Description: This photo shows small, purulent, shallow, punched-out ulcers with thick, brown-black crusts, and surrounding erythema.

Title: Ecthyma (Contagious)
Description: Contagious ecthyma is a focal skin lesion caused by orf virus infection, usually occurring on a finger and transmitted to animal workers from sheep or goats. The lesion passes through 6 stages; this image shows the 2nd stage (target), characterized by a large nodule with a red center surrounded by a white ring and a red periphery.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.

Title: Ectropion
Description: Ectropion is eversion of the eyelid that most commonly affects the lower eyelid of older adults.
Copyright: MID ESSEX HOSPITAL SERVICES NHS TRUST/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Eczema Herpeticum
Description: This photo shows diffuse herpes simplex infection with grouped vesicles in a patient with atopic dermatitis.

Title: Eczema Vaccinatum
Description: Eczema vaccinatum is vaccinia that develops in patients with eczematous skin. Active eczema may not be clinically apparent in affected sites. Patients may develop eczema vaccinatum after receiving the vaccine themselves or from physical contact with someone who received the vaccine.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Arthur E. Kaye via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Effects of Thrombectomy After Stroke (Arteriogram)
Description: This cerebral angiogram shows an occlusion of the proximal left middle cerebral artery (MCA) on anteroposterior and lateral views (1, 2). After mechanical thrombectomy, the angiogram shows restored blood flow in the left MCA on anteroposterior and lateral views (3, 4).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Ji Y. Chong, MD.

Title: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
Description: Abnormal elasticity of the skin is seen in this patient with an Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
Copyright: ST MARYS HOSPITAL MEDICAL SCHOOL/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Elbow Contracture in Systemic Sclerosis
Description: Flexion contracture of the elbow is seen in this image of a patient with diffuse systemic sclerosis.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Marder W, Lath V, Crofford L, Lowe L, McCune WJ: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Encephalocele
Description: This image shows a baby girl with an encephalocele. The brain tissue in the hernia is often abnormal, and the brain is often damaged. Most encephaloceles, like this one, are found extending from the rear of the head.

Title: Enchondroma
Description: This x-ray of the femur shows lobulated calcium deposits inside the bone (arrows), which are typical of enchondroma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Endophthalmitis
Description: This image shows the intense conjunctival hyperemia, anterior chamber inflammation (with hypopyon), and loss of the red reflex characteristic of endophthalmitis.

Title: Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
Description: This radiograph shows the endoscope in place with the end in the duodenum. The radiopaque contrast agent fills the pancreatic duct (horizontal white duct) and the bile ducts (vertical duct with extension into the gallbladder).
TopicName: Imaging Tests of the Liver and Gallbladder

Description: This photo shows an endoscopic view of a normal stomach fundus with characteristic gastric folds.

Description: The white arrow shows an endovascular stent graft within an abdominal aneurysm (red arrow).

Description: This x-ray shows large adenoids (white star) causing narrowing of the airway (black star).

Description: These images show a single-contrast enteroclysis examination using diluted barium suspension. Spot view of the jejunum (left), spot view of the ileum (center), and spot view of the terminal ileum (right).

Title: Entropion
Description: This photo shows entropion, inversion of the eyelid that most commonly affects the lower eyelids of older adults. The lower eyelid margin is rolled in and the lashes are hidden.

Title: Eosinophilic Granuloma of the Skull
Description: Radiographic appearance of typical monostotic eosinophilic granuloma of the skull is shown in a patient with Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The lesion is sharply marginated but not beveled.

Title: Epidermal Inclusion Cyst
Description: The photo at left shows a blackhead-like punctum on an epidermal inclusion cyst on the chin of a patient. The photo at right shows a protrusion of cheese-like material from the cyst after compression.

Description: This photo shows epithelial fragility of nails and high-friction sites on the hand and knee resulting from epidermolysis bullosa.

Title: Epidermolysis Bullosa (Hands)
Description: This photo shows the hands of a 5-year-old child with scars, bullae, and loss of fingernails.

Title: Epididymo-Orchitis
Description: Epididymo-orchitis can result in painful, swollen, erythematous testes and epididymis, as shown in this photo.

Description: CT scan shows an epidural hematoma (opacity at bottom right).

Title: Epiglottitis
Description: This image shows epiglottitis in an intubated patient. Note the stiff, edematous epiglottis in the upper part of the photo. The vocal cords are visible below and distal to the epiglottis.
Copyright: Image provided by Clarence T. Sasaki, MD.

Title: Epiglottitis (Adult)
Description: This x-ray shows the enlarged epiglottis (thumb sign—see arrow) characteristic of epiglottitis and distention of the hypopharynx. Note the posteriorly displaced, thickened epiglottis.
Copyright: Image provided by Clarence T. Sasaki, MD.

Title: Episcleritis
Description: Episcleritis mimics conjunctivitis in appearance but causes much less tearing and no discharge. The ocular hyperemia of episcleritis involves only a segment of the globe (lateral aspect in this example), not the whole bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva as occurs in conjunctivitis.

Title: Epispadias (Male)
Description: In this photo, the urethra opens on the dorsum of the penis.

Title: Erb Palsy in an Infant
Description: This photo shows internal rotation of the shoulder, extension of the elbow, and flexion of the wrist and digits in obstetric Erb palsy.

Title: Erosive Gastritis
Description: This photo shows eroded and erythematous areas in the stomach lining resulting from prolonged nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use.
Copyright: DAVID M. MARTIN, MD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Eruptive Xanthoma
Description: Patients with severe elevations of TGs can have eruptive xanthomas over the trunk, back, elbows, buttocks, knees, hands, and feet.

Title: Eruptive Xanthoma (Skin)
Description: Eruptive xanthomas are skin manifestations of elevated triglyceride levels.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Eruptive Xanthoma (Skin)
Description: Eruptive xanthomas are skin manifestations of elevated triglyceride levels.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erysipelas (Bullous)
Description: This image shows the bullous form of erysipelas.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Erysipelas (Face)
Description: Erysipelas is characterized by shiny, raised, indurated, and tender plaque-like lesions with distinct margins.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erysipelas (Face)
Description: Erysipelas is characterized by shiny, raised, indurated, and tender plaque-like lesions with distinct margins.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erysipelas (Limb)
Description: Note the sharp line of demarcation and bright red color, features that distinguish erysipelas from cellulitis.

Title: Erysipeloid
Description: This image shows the characteristic purplish red, indurated rash of erysipeloid infection.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erythema Annulare Centrifugum
Description: This photo shows annular and arcuate lesions of erythema annulare centrifugum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Erythema Gyratum Repens
Description: This photo shows erythema gyratum repens, which is a rare eruption consisting of concentric erythematous lesions resembling wood grain.

Title: Erythema Infectiosum
Description: This photo shows confluent erythematous rash on the face ("slapped-cheek" appearance) with a maculopapular rash on the trunk and arms.

Title: Erythema Infectiosum (Arm)
Description: This image shows a maculopapular rash resulting from erythema infectiosum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Erythema Infectiosum (Slapped Cheek)
Description: This image shows an erythematous rash on the face ("slapped-cheek" appearance) resulting from erythema infectiosum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Erythema Marginatum in Rheumatic Fever
Description: Erythema marginatum is a serpiginous rash seen in patients with rheumatic fever.

Title: Erythema Migrans
Description: Erythema migrans is the characteristic physical finding of early Lyme disease. It begins as a red macule at the site of the Ixodes tick bite. Classically, the macule expands with central clearing, as in this image, but, in many patients, no central clearing occurs. Some patients have central erythema surrounded by a pale ring, and a few develop vesicular or ulcerated centers.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erythema Migrans in Lyme Disease (Bull's Eye Rash)
Description: Erythema migrans can resemble a bull's eye, with central erythema surrounded by a pale ring and outer erythematous halo.

TopicLocations.Title: Erythema Migrans in Lyme Disease (Bull's Eye Rash)

Title: Erythema Multiforme (Abdomen)
Description: This image shows characteristic target or iris lesions of erythema multiforme.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Erythema Multiforme (Back)
Description: Erythema multiforme is characterized by target or iris lesions, which are annular lesions with a violaceous center and pink halo separated by a pale ring.

Title: Erythema Multiforme (Palm)
Description: This image shows target lesions (sometimes called iris lesions). Such lesions, which are typical of erythema multiforme, can appear on the palms.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Julia Benedetti, MD.

Title: Erythema Nodosum
Description: Erythema nodosum is a form of panniculitis characterized by palpable, tender, red or violet subcutaneous nodules most typically appearing on the shins. It most often accompanies systemic diseases, including streptococcal infection, sarcoidosis, and inflammatory bowel disease.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erythema Nodosum
Description: Erythema nodosum is a form of panniculitis characterized by palpable, tender, red or violet subcutaneous nodules most typically appearing on the shins. It most often accompanies systemic diseases, including streptococcal infection, sarcoidosis, and inflammatory bowel disease.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erythema Nodosum (Leg)
Description: This image shows characteristic erythematous, tender plaques of erythema nodosum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Erythema Nodosum in Behçet Disease
Description: This photo shows lesions, usually multiple, characterized by tender, warm, red, subcutaneous nodules on the pretibial region of the lower extremities.

Title: Erythema Toxicum
Description: This photo shows erythema toxicum, a benign rash with an erythematous base and a white or yellow papule.

Title: Erythrasma
Description: Erythrasma in the groin manifests as irregular but sharply marginated patches with fine scaling.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Erythroderma
Description: This photo shows erythroderma with diffuse erythema and desquamation of the skin.

Title: Erythrodermic Psoriasis
Description: This photo shows a diffuse erythematous rash on the torso of a patient with erythrodermic psoriasis.

Title: Erythroplakia and Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: Erythroplakia is a general term that can describe red, flat, or eroded velvety lesions that develop in the mouth. In this image, an exophytic squamous cell carcinoma on the tongue is surrounded by a margin of erythroplakia.
Copyright: Image provided by Jonathan A. Ship, DMD.

Title: Erythroplakia and Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Title: Esophageal Diverticulum
Description: This image shows a small diverticulum (arrow) in the upper esophagus.
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Esophageal Food Impaction (Endoscopy)
Copyright: Image courtesy of Zubair Malik, MD.

Title: Esophageal Ring
Description: Esophageal rings (also called Schatzki rings) are smooth, concentric, mucosal folds that narrow the esophagus at the esophogastric junction. A hiatus hernia can be seen through the lumen of this ring.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Esophageal Stricture
Description: This image shows esophageal stricture caused by longstanding reflux disease and also shows superficial ulcerations.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Esophageal Varices
Description: Varices are dilated, submucosal esophageal veins caused by portal hypertension, most commonly in the setting of cirrhosis.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Esophageal Web
Description: This image shows an esophageal web, a thin membrane that grows across the lumen in the middle or upper esophagus.

Title: Esophagography with Water-Soluble Contrast
Description: These fluoroscopic esophagograms show frank extravasation of contrast material from the distal esophagus consistent with an esophageal perforation. The blue arrows highlight contrast material within the lumen of esophagus. The red circles highlight contrast material that has extravasated out of the esophagus.

Title: Ethmoid Sinusitis With Subperiosteal Abscess
Description: This CT shows a left ethmoid sinusitis with adjacent subperiosteal abscess along the medial wall and roof of the orbit.
Copyright: CT courtesy of James Garrity, MD.

Title: Ewing Sarcoma of Bone
Description: This shoulder x-ray shows a destructive tumor inside the humerus, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Ewing Sarcoma of the Radius
Description: This Ewing sarcoma of the radial shaft shows subperiosteal reactive new bone formation and some lytic destruction.

Title: Extensive Birth Injuries in a Newborn (CT Scan)
Description: This axial (cross-sectional) CT of the head in a newborn shows extensive extracranial and intracranial injury secondary to severe birth-related injury. There is bilateral swelling/hematoma formation in the scalp. There is a very large isodense (subacute) subdural hematoma along the right cerebral hemisphere, causing brain herniation across the midline. The hematoma results in enlargement of the left lateral ventricle. Acute blood layering in the bottom of the left lateral ventricle (white material with a straight line) is seen at the lower right aspect of the image.
Copyright: Living Art Enterprises, LLC/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

TopicLocations.Title: Extensive Birth Injuries in a Newborn (CT Scan)

Title: Extrapulmonary Blastomycosis (Bullae)
Description: Extrapulmonary blastomycosis may manifest in the skin or genitals. Skin lesions manifest as papules, pustules, or bullae. This photo shows a bullous skin lesion.

Title: Extrapulmonary Blastomycosis (Ulcerative with Microabscesses)

Title: Extrapulmonary Blastomycosis (Verrucous Appearance)
Description: Extrapulmonary blastomycosis may occur in the skin or genitals. Skin lesions may develop wartlike papillae or a verrucous appearance. This photo shows a verrucous skin lesion.

Title: FDG-PET Showing Viable Myocardium
Description: Decreased myocardial perfusion of the interventricular septum (green arrows), inferior (red arrows) and apical (blue arrow) walls at rest (left) in the setting of intact fluorine-18–labeled deoxyglucose (FDG) uptake on viability PET-CT scan (right). This is consistent with hibernating (viable) myocardium (yellow arrow), which is not receiving adequate blood flow.

Title: Fibrillary Glomerulopathy (Fibrils)
Description: Randomly arranged fibrils in mesangial and capillary loops are seen on transmission electron microscopy (left). Negative Congo red stains are necessary to exclude renal amyloidosis (×25,625). The right image shows a high-power view of fibrils, which are coarser in diameter than amyloid deposits (×98,000).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Fibrillary Glomerulopathy (IgG Deposition)

Title: Fibrillary Glomerulopathy (Mesangial Proliferation)
Description: Mesangial proliferation is suggestive of fibrillary glomerulopathy; however, the diagnosis requires negative Congo red stain, IgG staining by immunofluorescence, and demonstration of fibril on electron microscopy (Jones silver stain, ×400).

Title: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis
Description: The top image shows the right side of the glomerulus. The glomerulus, which is segmentally sclerotic, is composed of obliterated capillary lumens and an increased amount of mesangial matrix. The rest of the glomerulus is normal (Jones silver stain, ×400). In the bottom image, hyalin, defined as smooth, glassy-appearing material, results from insudation (the opposite of exudation) of plasma proteins. It occurs frequently and is not diagnostic (Jones silver stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (Blunting and Effacement of Foot Processes)
Description: Extensive blunting and effacement of foot processes can be seen on transmission electron microscopy (×3000).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

TopicLocations.Title: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (Blunting and Effacement of Foot Processes)

Title: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (Global Sclerosis)
Description: The central glomerulus in this biopsy specimen demonstrates global sclerosis. The finding is nonspecific and may develop in response to injury or aging (Jones silver stain, ×100).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (IgM in Mesangium)
Description: Immunofluorescence staining with anti-IgM demonstrates IgM in mesangium or in areas of hyalinosis (smooth, globular staining on right). IgM is thought to become trapped in areas of expanded mesangium and sclerosis (×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (Tip Lesion)
Description: A tip lesion is segmental sclerosis localized to the glomerular pole where the tubule originates. It may be a marker of improved prognosis (Jones silver stain, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Folliculitis
Description: Folliculitis manifests as superficial pustules or inflammatory nodules surrounding hair follicles.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Foot Ulcer
Description: A patient with diabetes often develops microvascular disease, which may impair skin healing, so that even minor breaks in skin integrity can develop into deeper ulcers and easily become infected, particularly in the lower extremities.

Title: Frontal Bossing in Paget Disease
Description: This photo shows an abnormally prominent forehead (frontal bossing) in a patient with Paget disease.

Title: Frostbite of the Foot
Description: This photo shows pale nail beds, edematous gray toes, and blisters on the foot. Absence of blood in blisters suggests that frostbite is superficial and that residual tissue loss is unlikely after healing.

Title: Frostbite of the Hands
Description: This photo shows frostbite of the hands. Blisters (hemorrhagic at right ring and small fingers) are evident, and cyanotic fingertips may portend necrosis. The ring should be removed before swelling occurs.

Title: Full-Thickness (3rd-Degree) Burn
Description: Most of the third finger has a full-thickness burn, where the skin is dark and leathery. The base of the finger has vesicles, bullae, and redness, indicating that this part of the finger has a partial-thickness burn.
Copyright: Image provided by Steven E. Wolf, MD.

Description: This photo shows a large gastroschisis. Note the lack of membranous covering and the umbilical cord to the left of the gastroschisis.

Title: Geographic Tongue
Description: This photo shows some elevated white borders surrounding smooth, red areas of atrophy and loss of papillae. Other areas have a rough white or yellow surface (psoriaform changes). The lesions occur in multiple locations on the tongue and may coalesce to form a maplike appearance.

Title: Geographic Tongue (With Fissured Tongue)
Description:
Benign migratory glossitis (geographic tongue) in which the normal projections (papillae) on the tongue surface are lost and surrounded by raised white-yellow areas. The tongue also shows fissuring (deep grooves on the top and sides of the tongue), which often coexists with geographic tongue.

    © Springer Science+Business Media

Title: Giant Cell Tumor
Description: This x-ray of the knee shows a lucent hole (arrows) in the femur above the knee, which is consistent with a giant cell tumor.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Giant Cell Tumor (CT Scan)
Description: This axial CT scan (left) shows a lytic lesion of the sacrum (red arrow) with anterior soft tissue mass (white arrow). A biopsy showed giant cell tumor of bone. After 4 years of denosumab treatment, the follow-up CT scan (right) shows progressive ossification of the tumor (green arrow) without an increase in size.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Gigantism
Description: The patient on the right was diagnosed with gigantism as an infant. She is several feet taller than her mother on the left.

Title: Gingival Hyperplasia
Description: This photo shows hyperplasia of the gingiva of the upper teeth, a consequence of long-term use of the drug phenytoin in treating epilepsy.

Title: Gingival Recession
Description: Recession of the gingivae exposes the root surfaces.
Copyright: Image provided by Jonathan A. Ship, DMD.

Title: Gingivitis
Description: This image of gingivitis in a young person shows inflammation of the marginal gingiva, with swelling of the interdental papillae and inflammation observed along the upper canines.
Copyright: Image courtesy of James T. Ubertalli, DMD.

Title: Glaucoma (Advanced)
Description: This image shows signs of advanced glaucoma, including marked enlargement of the cup (total cupping) and peripapillary atrophy mimicking a neuroretinal rim.

Title: Glaucoma (Moderate)
Description: Moderate glaucoma in the right eye shows thinning of the neuroretinal rim with an increased cup:disk ratio, vertical elongation of the cup (cupping), pitting or notching of the rim, and wedge-shaped dark areas that reflect retinal nerve fiber layer damage.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Douglas Rhee, MD.

Title: Glaucoma (Optic Disk Hemorrhage)
Description: This photo shows a Drance (splinter) hemorrhage that crosses the optic disk margin at about 4:00.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Douglas Rhee, MD.

Title: Glioblastoma
Description: The T2-FLAIR MRI scan (top) shows a large, bilateral white (hyperdensity) signal around a glioblastoma, which is the highest grade and most malignant astrocytoma. This particular glioblastoma is called a butterfly glioma because the white signal around the tumor forms the wings of the butterfly; it is caused by cerebral edema. On the T1-weighted scan (bottom), contrast outlines the edge of the tumor (ring enhancement). The edema appears as a darkened area (hypointensity) on T1.
Copyright: Images courtesy of William R. Shapiro, MD.

Title: Gonorrhea (Urethritis)
Description: This photo shows an inflamed glans and purulent urethral discharge in a patient with gonorrhea.

Title: Gonorrhea (Vaginitis)
Description: This photo shows a yellowish vaginal discharge in a child with a history of suspected sexual assault.

Title: Gottron Papules
Description: Gottron papules are scaly, erythematous to violaceous papules on extensor surfaces of proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints.

Title: Gout Crystals
Description: Brightly birefringent, needle-shaped, urate crystals aspirated from a gouty tophus can be seen in this image taken with a polarizing microscope and a red compensator filter. The negatively birefringent crystals appear yellow when they lie parallel to the optical axis of the compensator and blue when perpendicular to it.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Myers S: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Gout of the Middle Toe
Description: This photo shows a large tophus of the left third toe, which has broken down and released hardened uric acid. The x-ray on the right shows erosion of the middle phalanx and distal interphalangeal joint.
Copyright: Images courtesy of Brian F. Mandell, MD.

Title: Gram Stain (Escherichia coli)
Description: This image is a light micrograph of Gram-stained E. coli, rod-shaped, motile bacteria. Their red color indicates they are Gram-negative. Magnification is 400X at 35-mm size.

Title: Gram Stain (Streptococcus pneumoniae)
Description: This image is a light micrograph of Gram-stained S. pneumoniae (also known as S. pneumococcus), rounded bacteria (cocci) that usually occur in pairs and sometimes short chains. Their blue color indicates they are Gram-positive. Magnification is 1450X when printed 10-cm wide.

Title: Granuloma Annulare
Description: This photo shows the typical skin lesions of granuloma annulare. The lesions manifest as rings with central clearing.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Granuloma Annulare
Description: This image shows erythematous bumps arranged in a ring or circular pattern on the torso of a patient with diabetes.

Title: Granuloma Inguinale (Chronic Genital Lesions)
Description: Granuloma inguinale is a progressive ulcerative disease that is usually sexually transmitted and involves the skin and subcutaneous tissues in the anogenital and inguinal regions. The initial nodule slowly enlarges, erodes the surrounding tissues, and develops into a beefy, bulky, granulomatous mass.

Title: Granuloma Inguinale (Female)
Description: This photo shows genital granuloma inguinale.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Susan Lindsley via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Granuloma Inguinale (Male)
Description: This photo shows genital granuloma inguinale.

Title: Granuloma Inguinale (Perianal)
Description: This photo shows perianal granuloma inguinale.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Tabua via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Eye Findings)
Description: Proptosis and episcleritis in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). The CT view depicts the orbital infiltrate.

Title: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Pulmonary Lesion)
Description: Large cavitary lesion in right lung in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).

Title: Graves Disease (Enlarged Thyroid Gland)
Description: In this patient with Graves disease, the thyroid is visibly enlarged. Typically, the thyroid feels smooth, without discrete nodules, on palpation.

Title: Green-Nail Syndrome
Description: The photo on the left shows green-nail syndrome with onycholysis of the fourth fingernail and green discoloration due to the presence of pigments produced by Pseudomonas. The photo on the right shows the green discoloration of the nail bed after clipping off the detached nail plate.

Title: Greenstick Fracture of the Distal Radius
Description: This x-ray shows a greenstick fracture of the distal radius, visible as a discontinuity (step-off) in the radial aspect of the cortex (arrow).

Title: Group A Streptococci (Necrotizing Soft-Tissue Infection)
Description: This photo shows life-threatening infection of the subcutaneous fat and muscles by streptococci (group A), causing widespread necrosis involving the lower back.

Description: This photo shows life-threatening infection of the subcutaneous fat and muscles by streptococci (group A), causing widespread necrosis involving the lower back.

Description: This photo shows multiple plaques on the trunk of a 22-year-old man with guttate psoriasis.

Description: This photo shows enlarged brwww tissue in a male patient.

Title: Hairy Tongue
Description: The tongue is brownish and has a hairy appearance due to accumulation of keratin on the top of the tongue (papillae).
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Craig B. Fowler, DDS.

Title: Halo Nevus
Description: This photo shows a halo nevus surrounded by a ring of depigmented skin next to a nevus without a halo.

Title: Halo Ring
Description: A halo ring is an efficient way to apply cervical traction. Because the ring is attached to the skull with multiple pins, the load per pin is reduced; as a result, a large amount of traction can be applied for a long time.

Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Myers S: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Heberden Nodes (Osteoarthritis)
Description: This photo shows Heberden nodes, hard-tissue (bony) prominences of distal interphalangeal joints seen in patients with osteoarthritis.

Title: Heel Spur

Title: Heliotrope Rash
Description: This photo shows violaceous rash around the eyes and in the nasolabial folds and chin in a patient with dermatomyositis.

Title: Heliotrope Rash
Description: This photo shows violaceous rash around the eyes and in the nasolabial folds and chin in a patient with dermatomyositis.

Title: Hemochromatosis (Skin Hyperpigmentation)
Description: This photo shows a comparison of the hands of a healthy patient (far left and right) and a patient suffering from hemochromatosis with arthritic deformities (center).

Title: Hemorrhoids (External)
Description: This photo shows bulging and thrombosed external hemorrhoids.

Title: Hemothorax
Description: This photo shows a massive left hemothorax after a gunshot wound to the left chest.

Title: Hereditary Angioedema
Description: This photo shows acute swelling of the lips in a patient with hereditary angioedema.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Joe E, Soter N. In Current Dermatologic Diagnosis and Treatment, edited by I Freedberg, IM Freedberg, and MR Sanchez. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2001.

Title: Hereditary Angioedema
Description: This photo shows acute swelling of the lips in a patient with hereditary angioedema.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Joe E, Soter N. In Current Dermatologic Diagnosis and Treatment, edited by I Freedberg, IM Freedberg, and MR Sanchez. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2001.

Title: Hereditary Erythrocyte G6PD Deficiency
Description: The blood smear is from a 37-year-old man with hereditary G6PD deficiency. It shows many blister cells (red arrows) due to precipitation of damaged hemoglobin within the cells. It also shows spherocytes (blue arrows) with membrane damage due to binding by oxidized hemoglobin.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Jerry L. Spivak, MD.

Title: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
Description: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome) is an autosomal dominant disorder that manifests with widespread cutaneous, mucosal, and visceral telangiectases and arteriovenous malformations. Papular, punctate, and linear telangiectases occur predominantly on the tongue, lips, digit tips, perioral region, and trunk.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Deitcher S. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome)
Description: This photo shows a close-up of the face of a patient with multiple telangiectasias secondary to hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.

Title: Herniated Disk (MRI Scan)
Description: Comparison of normal (blue arrows) and herniated lumbar disk anatomy in a T2-weighted MRI scan. The herniated disk, located between the L4 and L5 vertebrae (red arrow), is pinching the spinal nerve extending from the spinal cord, resulting in localized or radiating pressure and pain.

Title: Herpangina
Description: Herpangina (caused by several different enteroviruses) appears as ulcerative lesions on the anterior tonsillar pillars, soft palate, tonsils, pharynx, and posterior buccal mucosa.

Title: Herpes Labialis (Lip)
Description: This photo is a close-up of a herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) lesion on the lower lip that shows clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Herrmann via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Herpes Labialis (Soft Palate and Tongue)
Description: These ulcerative lesions on the soft palate are caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Robert E. Sumpter via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Herpes Simplex (Dendritic Keratitis)
Description: This photo shows dendritic (epithelial) keratitis, characterized by a branched corneal epithelial defect resembling a branching tree. Note the thinness of the dendrite and the bulbs at the ends. It is best seen with fluorescein staining (green color). In this photo, the dendrite was also stained with another dye (rose bengal), coloring it red.

Title: Herpes Simplex Epithelial Keratitis (Dendritic Keratitis)
Description: This photo shows a dendritic (branching) ulcer (green) on a patient's cornea. The ulcer is green because it has been stained with fluorescein.

Title: Herpes Simplex Esophagitis
Description: Focal ulcerations are typical of herpes simplex virus esophagitis.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Herpes Stomatitis
Description: This photo shows blisters on the palate consistent with herpes stomatitis.

Title: Herpes Zoster (Lumbar Dermatome)
Description: This photo shows the dermatomal band of erythema with superimposed grouped and scattered vesicles due to herpes zoster infection.

Title: Herpes Zoster (Thoracic Dermatome)
Description: The cutaneous viral infection follows neural dermatomes and is accompanied by burning, erythema, blistering, and necrosis.

Title: Herpes Zoster (V1 Distribution of Trigeminal Nerve)
Description: The rash of herpes zoster usually shows up along the path of the nerve that is involved. In this picture, the path of the branches of part of the trigeminal nerve gives the rash a sharp boundary between where the vesicles (bumps) appear and where they do not. The appearance of a vesicle on the tip of the nose indicates that one of the small nerves that connects to the part of the eye may also be affected and indicates an increased risk of severe ocular involvement.

Description: This photo shows blisters (herpetic whitlow) on the fingers of a patient due to herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) infection.

Title: Herpetiform Lesions (Neonatal)
Description: Herpetiform lesions manifest as grouped papules or vesicles in a formation resembling those of a herpes simplex infection. This photo shows clusters of vesicles on erythematous bases that are highly characteristic.
