Title: Hirschsprung Disease
Description: This barium enema shows aganglionosis up to the splenic flexure. The aganglionic bowel is narrowed and spastic (right), whereas the normally innervated proximal bowel (top) is dilated and filled with fecal material.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Wald A: Gastroenterology and Hepatology: Colon, Rectum, and Anus. Edited by M Feldman (series editor) and CR Boland. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1996.

Title: Hirsutism
Description: This photo shows excessive facial hair in a female.

Title: Hirsutism
Description: This photo shows excessive facial hair in a female.

Title: Histiocytosis
Description: This image shows an erythematous papular rash resulting from skin manifestations of histiocytosis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Histiocytosis (Head CT)
Description: This image shows a soft-tissue lesion in the right frontal bone with associated osseous destruction and intracranial extension of soft tissue into the dural space (red arrow). Asymmetric overlying scalp soft tissue is present. Biopsy was diagnostic for LCH.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Carolyn Fein Levy, MD, and Jeffrey M. Lipton, MD, PhD.

Title: Histiocytosis (Pelvic Bone)
Description: This image shows a large aggressive lesion within the right iliac wing. An MRI revealed the mass was heterogenous on T2 and low T1 signal with heterogenous enhancement of the mass and surrounding musculature with deviation of the right psoas muscle medially, suggesting an aggressive bone lesion (left). A large lytic lesion within the anterior and lateral ala of the ileum extending anterior and inferior to the ischium was visible on x-ray (right). There are expanded cortex and cortical irregularities. Biopsy was diagnostic for LCH.
Copyright: Images courtesy of Carolyn Fein Levy, MD, and Jeffrey M. Lipton, MD, PhD.

Title: Histoplasmosis
Description: In patients with immunosuppression, histoplasmosis can disseminate to the skin, bone marrow, brain, liver, spleen, and lymphatic system. The oral lesion in this image mimics a chancre of primary syphilis, but testing yielded Histoplasma capsulatum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Susan Lindsley via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: HIV-Associated Nephropathy (Collapsing Glomerulopathy)
Description: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis with collapse of glomerular tufts and microcystic tubular changes is characteristic of HIV-associated nephropathy (Jones silver stain, ×100).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: HIV-Associated Nephropathy (Reticular Inclusions)
Description: HIV-associated nephropathy can be distinguished from focal segmental glomerulosclerosis by reticular inclusions in endothelial cell cytoplasm on transmission electron microscopy (×20,000). However, these reticular inclusions are now rare with use of highly active antiretroviral therapy.
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: HIV-Related Burkitt Lymphoma
Description: As in immunocompetent people, Burkitt lymphoma has a "starry-sky" appearance due to the numerous debris-containing macrophages (denoting rapid cell turnover). The tumor also has a high mitotic rate.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Banks P, et al. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004. Available at www.images.md.

Title: Hodgkin Lymphoma (Mediastinal Lymphadenopathy)
Description: Chest X-ray of a patient with Hodgkin lymphoma showing mediastinal lymphadenopathy.

Title: Holding the Lumbar Puncture Needle
Description: One way of holding the lumbar puncture needle involves using both hands and resting them against the back, as shown in the photo. This grip allows more precise control of the needle and better stabilization in case the patient moves.
Copyright: Image courtesy of John Greenlee, MD

Title: Honeybee
Copyright: Image courtesy of Justin Kaplan, MD.

Title: Hook Test
Description: The hook test is used to determine whether the patient has a torn distal biceps tendon. The flexed elbow is supinated, and the examiner attempts to hook the index finger under the biceps tendon from the lateral side. If the biceps tendon is torn (distal avulsion), there is no cordlike structure to palpate or hook.

Title: Hookworm Life Cycle
Description:
• 1. Eggs are passed in the stool, and if they are deposited in a warm, moist place on loose soil, larvae hatch in 1 to 2 days.

    • 2. The eggs release rhabditiform larvae, which grow in the feces or soil.

    • 3. After 5 to 10 days, the larvae become infective.

    • 4. When they come in contact with the human host, they penetrate the skin and are carried through the blood vessels to the heart and then to the lungs. They penetrate into pulmonary alveoli, ascend the bronchial tree to the pharynx, and are swallowed.

    • 5. The larvae reach the small intestine, where they mature into adults. Adult worms live in the lumen of the small intestine. They attach to the intestinal wall, feed on blood (resulting in blood loss by the host), and produce eggs.
Copyright: Image from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health, Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria.

Title: Hordeolum (External)
Description: This hordeolum (stye) is swollen, red, and inflamed and is slightly yellow in the center.

Title: Horner Syndrome
Description: This photo shows ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) and miosis (constricted pupil) of the left eye of a patient with Horner syndrome.

Title: Hutchinson Incisors
Description: This photo shows triangular shaped deformity of right upper and left lower incisors caused by congenital syphilis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Robert E. Sumpter via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Hydatidiform Mole
Description: This photo shows a gross clinical specimen of grape-like cysts from a hydatidiform mole.

Title: Hydrocephalus (Enlarged Skull)
Description: Hydrocephalus can cause an unusually enlarged skull due to pressure from excess fluid within cavities of the brain.

Title: Hyperoxaluria
Description: Calcium oxalate crystals precipitate in renal tubules and are easily visible as birefringent and fan- or sheaf-shaped crystals under polarized light (polarized hematoxylin-eosin stain, ×100).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Hyperpigmentation of Addison Disease
Description: Patients with Addison disease have diffuse hyperpigmentation as well as hyperpigmentation on extensor surfaces (here the elbows) as in the top left panel. In the top right panel, hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases is visible in a patient with Addison disease. In the bottom left panel, hyperpigmented macules of the gums are visible in this patient with Addison disease. Some patients with Addison disease have vitiligo and hyperpigmentation, as seen in the bottom right panel.

Title: Hypertelorism and Maxillary Hypoplasia
Description: This patient has ocular hypertelorism (widely spaced eyes) and maxillary hypoplasia (small upper mandible). She also has other facial deformities including flat nasal bridge, upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, low-set ears, and retrognathism.

Title: Hypertensive Retinopathy (Copper Wiring)
Description: This image shows retinal arteriolar narrowing due to thickening and opacification of arteriolar walls (copper wiring) caused by hypertensive arteriosclerosis.

Title: Hypertensive Retinopathy (Moderate)
Description: Moderate hypertensive retinopathy is characterized by thinned, straight arteries, intraretinal hemorrhages, and yellow hard exudates.
Copyright: RALPH C. EAGLE, JR./SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Hypertensive Retinopathy (Star-Shaped Exudates and Papilledema)
Description: The cardinal funduscopic feature of malignant hypertension is optic disk swelling, which appears as blurring and elevation of disk margins. The image also shows a characteristic star-shaped macular lesion caused by leaking retinal vessels.

Title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Apical Variant)
Description: This cardiac MRI shows apical hypertrophy variant (arrow) of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Echocardiogram)
Description: This echocardiogram shows severely thickened ventricular septum (VS) and posterior wall (PW) of the left ventricle in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Title: Hyphae and Spores in Candidal Vaginitis
Description: Potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount shows hyphae and spores; 10% KOH destroys epithelial cells, improving recognition of ywww and hyphae in candidal vulvovaginitis. Use of KOH increases sensitivity of the wet mount to 60 to 80% from 30 to 40% when saline is used.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Sobel JD. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Fungal Infections. Edited by GL Mandell and RD Diamond. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2000. Also from Sobel JD. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases. Edited by GL Mandell and MF Rein. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1996.

TopicLocations.Title: Hyphae and Spores in Candidal Vaginitis

Title: Hypoxic Ischemic Brain Injury and Cerebral Edema
Description: This image shows a noncontrast CT in a patient with hypoxic brain injury and cerebral edema. Note the loss of gray-white matter differentiation (circle), hypoxic-ischemic damage to the basal ganglia (arrows), and effacement of the sulci.

Title: Idiopathic Nonspecific Interstitial Pneumonia
Description: High-resolution CT shows predominantly subpleural and basilar ground-glass opacities. The relative sparing of the lung directly beneath the pleural surfaces is typical in nonspecific interstitial pneumonia.

Title: Idiopathic Pleuroparenchymal Fibroelastosis (CT Scan)

Title: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
Description: Subpleural honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis are present on high-resolution CT in a patient with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). Findings inconsistent with IPF, such as nodules, are absent. These CT findings are virtually diagnostic of IPF if clinical findings are compatible.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Harold R. Collard, MD.

Title: Iron Deficiency Anemia

In severe cases, cigar-shaped red blood cells and elliptocytes are characteristically present. Conversely, polychromasia (the Wright-Giemsa stain equivalent of reticulocytosis) and basophilic stippling are conspicuously absent.

Title: Ischemic Stroke in the Left Middle Cerebral Artery (CT)

Title: Kaposi Sarcoma (AIDS-Associated Type)
Description: AIDS-associated Kaposi Sarcoma is an aggressive, multicentric tumor that may involve the face, trunk, mucosal surfaces, lymphatics, or gastrointestinal tract. Lesions appear as bluish to violaceous macules, plaques, or tumors.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Sol Silverman, Jr., via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Kaposi Sarcoma (AIDS-Associated Type)
Description: AIDS-associated Kaposi Sarcoma is an aggressive, multicentric tumor that may involve the face, trunk, mucosal surfaces, lymphatics, or gastrointestinal tract. Lesions appear as bluish to violaceous macules, plaques, or tumors.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Sol Silverman, Jr., via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Kaposi Sarcoma (Classic Type)
Description: This photo shows a classic reddish purple vascular lesion of Kaposi sarcoma.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Kaposi Sarcoma (Classic Type)
Description: In classic Kaposi sarcoma, cutaneous lesions are asymptomatic purple, pink, or red macules that may coalesce into blue-violet to black plaques and nodules.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Kaposi Sarcoma (Early Stage)
Description: This photo shows purplish red nodules consistent with Kaposi sarcoma over the lower eyelid skin in a patient with HIV infection.

Title: Kaposi Sarcoma (Early Stage)
Description: This photo shows purplish red nodules consistent with Kaposi sarcoma over the lower eyelid skin in a patient with HIV infection.

Title: Kaposi Sarcoma (Shoulder)
Description: This photo shows disseminated oval plaques of Kaposi sarcoma on the shoulders of a patient infected with HIV.

Title: Kawasaki Disease (Exanthem)
Description: This photo shows a polymorphous, erythematous, macular rash over the lower trunk with accentuation in to the perineal region.

Title: Kayser-Fleischer Ring
Description: Kayser-Fleischer rings (indicated by the solid black arrow) are gold, greenish gold, golden brown, or brownish green rings in Descemet membrane in the limbic region of the cornea. The rings result from copper deposits in the cornea.

Title: Keloid
Description: A keloid is hypertrophied tissue that develops in an area of injury or spontaneously; keloids are shiny, smooth, often dome-shaped, and slightly pink or hyperpigmented.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Keloid Scars
Description: In distinction from hypertrophic scars, keloids extend beyond the borders of the original wound invading normal skin. The patient has multiple large keloid scars on the anterior abdominal wall, after intra-abdominal surgery.

Title: Keloids on the Ear and Face
Description: This photo shows keloids on the ear and beard area after dog-bite injuries.

TopicLocations.Title: Keloids on the Ear and Face

Title: Keratitis (Interstitial)
Description: Interstitial keratitis manifests with varying degrees of corneal opacification and neovascularization. The neovascularization appears as the faint, pink areas in the peripheral cornea from the 11 o'clock to the 1 o'clock position.

Title: Keratitis (Interstitial)
Description: Interstitial keratitis manifests with varying degrees of corneal opacification and neovascularization. The neovascularization appears as the faint, pink areas in the peripheral cornea from the 11 o'clock to the 1 o'clock position.

Title: Keratitis (Peripheral Ulcerative)
Description: Peripheral ulcerative keratitis starts as opacification (gray area from 6:30 to 9 o'clock) with white cell infiltrate in the corneal periphery, followed by ulceration.

Title: Keratoacanthoma
Description: A keratoacanthoma is a round, firm nodule with sharply sloping borders and a characteristic central crater.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum (Palm)
Description: This photo shows extensive psoriatic plaques, generalized erythema, and marked scaling on the palms in a patient with reactive arthritis.

Title: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum (Sole)
Description: This photo shows plaques, marked erythema, and scaling of the skin in a patient with reactive arthritis.

Title: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum in Chlamydial Reactive Arthritis
Description: A small number of patients with chlamydial reactive arthritis experience a syndrome of arthritis accompanied by skin changes on their feet (keratoderma blennorrhagicum), conjunctivitis, uveitis, urethritis, or balanitis in reaction to chlamydial infection.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Susan Lindsley via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

TopicLocations.Title: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum in Chlamydial Reactive Arthritis

Title: Keratosis Pilaris
Description: In keratosis pilaris, horny plugs fill the openings of hair follicles.

Title: Kerion on Dark Skin
Description: This photo shows a kerion, which is a large, boggy scalp mass caused by a severe inflammatory reaction to a scalp dermatophyte infection. Pustules and crusting are visible.

Title: Kerion on Light Skin
Description: This photo shows a kerion, which is a large, boggy scalp mass caused by a severe inflammatory reaction to a scalp dermatophyte infection. Pustules and crusting are visible.

Title: Kerley B Lines
Description: Kerley B lines (arrows) are horizontal lines in the lung periphery that extend to the pleural surface. They denote thickened, edematous interlobular septa often due to pulmonary edema.

Title: Kienböck Disease (Oblique X-Ray)
Description: This oblique x-ray of the right wrist shows Kienböck disease. Note the collapse and fragmentation of the lunate bone (arrow), which was not apparent on the posteroanterior view.

Title: Kienböck Disease (Posteroanterior X-Ray)
Description: This posteroanterior x-ray of the right wrist shows cysts and sclerosis of the lunate bone (arrow) typical of Kienböck disease. The metal plate is evidence of a radial shortening osteotomy that was done in an effort to unload the lunate and potentially treat this condition.
Copyright: X-ray courtesy of David R. Steinberg, MD.

Title: Klinefelter Syndrome
Description: This photo shows gynecomastia with small testes and penis in a patient with Klinefelter syndrome.

Description: This photo shows large-plaque parapsoriasis on the buttocks, characterized by thin, dull, pink, and slightly scaly patches.

Title: Larva Currens (Creeping Eruption)
Description: In this patient, larva currens appears as a linear lesion on the left lower back along the tract of a migrating larva. A central area of edema is surrounded by an erythematous, urticarial border.

Title: Laryngitis
Description: In this endoscopic view of the inflamed larynx of a patient suffering from laryngitis, the vocal cords (v-shaped, lower left) are swollen.

Title: Laryngitis (Chronic Effects)
Description: This endoscope view of the larynx of a patient shows leukoplakia (keratosis, white, center) of the vocal cords due to laryngitis. Leukoplakia is a thickening of the body tissues that develops in response to chronic irritation.

Title: Laryngocele

Title: Lateral Thoracic Ultrasound (Right)

Title: Lateral X-Ray of the Elbow
Description: The anterior humeral line and radiocapitellar line are normal. However, an anterior fat pad is present, suggesting a joint effusion.

Title: Left Coronal Craniosynostosis
Description: This photo shows an infant with left coronal craniosynostosis causing marked sagittal deviation, vertical dystopia, and severe right frontal bossing.

Title: Left Ventricular Hypertrophy on ECG

Title: Lentigo Maligna Melanoma
Description: This photo shows lentigo maligna melanoma of the left malar region characterized by multiple macules with irregular borders and heterogeneous color.

Title: Lentigo Maligna Melanoma
Description: The lesion in this photo is a lentigo maligna melanoma. Characteristic features seen in this lesion are an irregularly shaped flat lesion (macule or patch) and brown or black spots (some darker) that are scattered irregularly.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Gregory L. Wells, MD.

Title: Lentigo Simplex
Description: This photo shows lentigo simplex manifesting as multiple, small, hyperpigmented macules on the back.

Title: Lepromatous Leprosy

Title: Leser-Trélat Sign
Description: Leser-Trélat sign is the rapid onset of numerous seborrheic keratoses (benign, often pigmented skin lesions with a "stuck-on" appearance).

Title: Leser-Trélat Sign
Description: Leser-Trélat sign is the rapid onset of numerous seborrheic keratoses (benign, often pigmented skin lesions with a "stuck-on" appearance).

Title: Leukemia Cutis (Disseminated)

Title: Leukemia Cutis (Localized)
Description: Leukemia cutis manifesting as erythematous papules, some with eroded surfaces, in a patient with acute myeloid leukemia.

Title: Leukocoria in Infant With Retinoblastoma
Description: Leukocoria in retinoblastoma is most commonly caused by direct reflection from the chalky-white tumor.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Scott I, Warman R, Murray T: Atlas of Ophthalmology. Edited by RK Parrish II and TG Murray. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2000.

Title: Leukoplakia
Description: This photo shows a thick plaque of leukoplakia extending widely over the dorsum of the tongue.

Title: Leukoplakia and Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: Leukoplakia is a general term that can describe white hyperkeratotic plaques that develop in the mouth. The majority prove to be benign. However, in this image, squamous cell carcinoma is present in one of the leukoplakic lesions on the ventral surface of the tongue (arrow).
Copyright: Image provided by Jonathan A. Ship, DMD.

Title: Leukoplakia and Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: Leukoplakia is a general term that can describe white hyperkeratotic plaques that develop in the mouth. The majority prove to be benign. However, in this image, squamous cell carcinoma is present in one of the leukoplakic lesions on the ventral surface of the tongue (arrow).
Copyright: Image provided by Jonathan A. Ship, DMD.

Title: Lice (Head, Nits)
Description: Lice nits are ovoid, grayish white eggs fixed to the hair shafts (top); they have a distinctive appearance on low-power microscopy (bottom).
Copyright: Top image courtesy of Thomas Habif, MD. Bottom image courtesy of Dennis D. Juranek, MD, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Lice (Pubic)
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Lice on Eyelashes
Description: Pubic lice may spread to the eyelashes. This photo shows eyelashes infested with a louse and nits.

Title: Lichen Planus
Description: This image shows vesiculobullous lesions (some ruptured) resulting from lichen planus.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Lichen Planus (Arm)
Description: This photo shows papules and plaques of lichen planus. Violaceous flat-topped papules are visible on the dorsal arm. Erythema may look more purple or brown on dark skin.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Lichen Planus (Forearm)
Description: This image shows small papules with a sheen in cross-lighting typical of lichen planus.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Lichen Planus (Hand)
Description: This image shows violaceous flat-topped papules coalescing into plaques on the dorsal hand of a patient with lichen planus.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Lichen Planus (Oral)
Description: Lichen planus lesions can occur in the oral cavity. Reticulated, lacy, bluish white, linear lesions (Wickham striae, seen here on the sides of the tongue) are a hallmark of oral lichen planus, particularly on the buccal mucosa.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Lichen Planus (Outer Thigh)
Description: This image shows papules and plaques resulting from lichen planus.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Lichen Planus (Penis)
Description: Annular lesion on the glans of the penis is consistent with lichen planus.

Title: Lichen Planus of the Nail
Description: This photo shows longitudinal ridging of the thumbnail of a patient with lichen planus of the nail.

Title: Lichen Sclerosus
Description: This image shows atrophy, hypopigmentation, and hyperpigmentation of the labia (top) and atrophy and hypopigmentation of the glans of the penis (bottom) resulting from lichen sclerosus.
Copyright: Images courtesy of Joe Miller (top) and Brian Hill (bottom) via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Lichen Sclerosus (Atrophic)
Description: This image shows hypopigmented, porcelain white patches of lichen sclerosus.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Lichen Sclerosus (Labial Findings)
Description: This photo shows porcelain white patches and areas of purpura in the labia minora, as well as early labial fusion.
Copyright: Image provided by E. Laurie Tolman, MD.

Title: Lichen Sclerosus (Perianal Findings)
Description: This photo shows scarring, atrophy, and distorted anatomy in the perianal area.
Copyright: Image provided by E. Laurie Tolman, MD.

Title: Lichen Sclerosus (Vulvar and Perianal Findings)
Description: This photo shows atrophy and hypopigmentation in the vulvar and perianal areas.
Copyright: Image provided by E. Laurie Tolman, MD.

Title: Lichen Simplex Chronicus
Description: Lichen simplex chronicus is a thickening of the skin in response to repetitive scratching or rubbing. This affected skin is lichenified, scaling, and crusted.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Linea Nigra
Description: A linea nigra is a dark line that appears down the midabdomen during pregnancy.

Title: Linear Immunoglobulin A (IgA) Disease
Description: This photo shows a vesicular rash on the trunk of an adult with IgA disease.

Title: Lipodystrophy (Lipoatrophy) in HIV (1)
Description: These images show clinical signs of lipodystrophy and lipoatrophy. The left panel shows the accumulation of fat tissue in the posterior cervical areas known as “buffalo hump” (red arrow). The right panel shows increased abdominal fat. The abdominal fat gains that people living with HIV experience are deep inside the organ cavity (visceral fat). The right panel also shows the loss of fat under the skin in the arms and legs, known as lipoatrophy.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Edward R. Cachay.

Title: Lipodystrophy (Lipoatrophy) in HIV (2)
Description: With use of antiretroviral drugs, body fat can be redistributed from the face and extremities (left panel) to the trunk, brwwws, and abdomen (center panel) and neck (right panel).

Title: Lipoma
Description: This photo shows a lipoma on the extremity.

Title: Lisfranc Fractures
Description: This x-ray shows fractures at the base of the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th metatarsals. The tarsometatarsal joints are also disrupted.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP)
Description: In the loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), a thin wire loop that conducts an electrical current is used to remove a piece of tissue. LEEP can be used to obtain a sample of tissue for biopsy or to remove abnormal tissue and thus treat early-stage cancer, including cervical cancer.

Title: Lupus Nephritis—Diffuse (Class IV)
Description: Diffuse lupus nephritis is characterized by endocapillary proliferation caused by immune complex deposits involving > 50% of glomeruli in a biopsy specimen.

Title: Lupus Nephritis—Focal (Class III)

Title: Lupus Nephritis—Membranous (Class V)

Title: Lymphedema
Description: This photo shows the arms of a patient with lymphedema of the right (top) arm. Lymphedema is an accumulation of lymph fluid in the tissues that occurs when lymphatic vessels are blocked, removed, or damaged. Here, it is a result of surgery for brwww cancer.

Description: This photo shows the arms of a patient with lymphedema of the right (top) arm. Lymphedema is an accumulation of lymph fluid in the tissues that occurs when lymphatic vessels are blocked, removed, or damaged. Here, it is a result of surgery for brwww cancer.

Title: Maisonneuve Fracture (1)
Description: This x-ray shows a disruption (widening) of the medial mortise joint (blue arrow). Normally, the space of the mortise joint should be symmetric around the talus. With a concomitant proximal fibular fracture, this is known as a Maisonneuve fracture.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Maisonneuve Fracture (2)
Description: This x-ray shows a proximal fibula fracture. With a concomitant disruption (widening) of the medial mortise joint, this is known as a Maisonneuve fracture.

Description: This photo shows a major aphthous ulcer (whitish area) inside the lip.

Title: Makeshift Nasal Clip Using Tongue Depressors for Treating Epistaxis
Description: Four tongue depressors can be taped together to fashion a makeshift nasal clip to provide pressure to the nasal alae. This external pressure can compress the plexus of vessels in the anterior interior septum to treat anterior epistaxis.
Copyright: Copyright © 2023 Merck & Co., Inc., Rahway, NJ, USA and its affiliates. All rights reserved.

Title: Marfan Syndrome (Long Fingers)
Description: Marfan syndrome is characterized by abnormally long fingers. In this photo, the woman's thumb overlaps her index finger when her hand is wrapped around her wrist.

Title: Marfan Syndrome (Musculoskeletal Abnormalities)
Description: This patient with Marfan syndrome is taller than his family and his arm span exceeds his height.

Title: Marfan Syndrome (Thumb Sign)

Copyright: MEDICAL PHOTO NHS LOTHIAN/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Matles Test
Description: The purpose of the Matles test is to have the examiner look for natural plantar flexion in the foot with an intact Achilles and for the absence of plantar flexion (indicating a positive Matles test) in the injured ankle. In the Matles test, the patient lies prone with the knees flexed, and the examiner assesses how the foot lies. In this image, the foot in front shows absence of plantar flexion (ie, the foot falls completely flat (to the neutral position with 0° plantar flexion). This result is a positive Matles test. The foot in the background shows 20 to 30° plantar flexion, indicating that the Achilles tendon is not ruptured (ie, the Achilles tendon is intact).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Measles (Koplik Spots)
Description: Koplik spots are classically described as being bright red spots with white or bluish-white centers that may resemble grains of sand. They may occur anywhere in the mouth, often precede the generalized exanthem, and are pathognomonic for measles (rubeola).
Copyright: Images courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Measles (Macular Rash)
Description: Measles (rubeola) manifests as a diffuse macular rash that becomes confluent.

Description: Melanonychia striata are hyperpigmented bands in the nail plate caused by melanin. In this image, a line is most noticeable in the nail of the left ring finger (arrow).

Title: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis, Complement-Mediated
Description: In complement-mediated membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type II, C3 nephritic factor, an IgG autoantibody which functions like properdin by directly cleaving C3 to C3b, activates complement via the alternative pathway within glomerular capillary walls and mesangium. C3 deposits partially replace the basement membrane lamina densa, giving it a thickened and distinctive ribbon appearance (Jones silver stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis, Immunoglobulin-/Immune Complex–Mediated
Description: In immunoglobulin-/immune-complex-mediated membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, chronic immune complex deposition (predominantly C3 and IgG or IgM) activates complement via the classic pathway within glomerular capillary walls and mesangium. The result is mesangial proliferation, glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening, interposition of mesangial cell cytoplasm between the GBM and endothelial cell, and glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure. GBM thickening is manifest here by double contours (Jones silver stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Membranous Nephropathy (Basement Membrane Spikes)
Description: Spikes of basement membrane silver-staining material protrude from the basement membrane (high-power oil-immersion view, Jones silver stain, original magnification ×1000).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Membranous Nephropathy (Dense Deposits)
Description: Medium-sized subepithelial dense deposits are seen on transmission electron microscopy in late stage I disease (×10,200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Membranous Nephropathy (IgG Deposition)
Description: Diffuse coarsely granular IgG deposition along glomerular capillary walls (immunofluorescence with anti-IgG, original magnification ×100).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Copyright: Photo courtesy of Patrick O’Kane, MD.

Description: In metatarsus adductus, the foot turns inward.

Title: Metatarsus Varus
Description: In metatarsus varus, the plantar surface of the foot is turned inward with a raised arch.

Title: Microcephaly
Description: This child has microcephaly with a head circumference < 2 standard deviations for his age. He also has other deformities including sloping forehead, micrognathia, relatively large ears, and severe contractures of all limbs.

Title: Microphthalmia
Description: This photo shows a patient with bilateral microphthalmia (left greater than right).

Title: Microtia
Description: This photo shows unilateral microtia.

Title: Middle Cerebral Artery Infarct
Description: A large lucent infarction is seen in the area of brain supplied by the right middle cerebral artery.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Furie K, et al: Cerebrovascular disease. In Atlas of Clinical Neurology. Edited by RN Rosenberg. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Midshaft Femur Fracture (1)
Description: This image shows a comminuted, angulated, and shortened midshaft femur fracture.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Midshaft Femur Fracture (2)
Description: This lateral femur x-ray shows a midshaft femur fracture with soft tissue air and retained metallic density foreign bodies.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Mild Esophagitis
Description: This image shows grade B esophagitis.
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Mild Sunburn
Description: This photo shows reddened skin on the back and arms of a patient with mild sunburn.

Title: Milia
Description: This photo shows small, pearl-colored cysts commonly seen on the face of neonates.

Title: Miliaria Rubra (Prickly Heat)
Description: This photo shows irritated, pruritic papules (prickling) typical of prickly heat.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of David M. Pariser, MD.

Title: Miliary TB
Description: This chest x-ray show findings suggesting miliary tuberculosis (TB), including almost innumerable, tiny (eg, 2- to 3-mm), interstitial nodules distributed through both lungs.

Title: Milker's Nodule
Description: Milker’s nodule is a focal skin lesion caused by paravaccinia virus, a parapoxvirus that causes udder lesions in cows. The lesion passes through 6 stages; this image shows the stage in which a single red edematous papule develops from an initial macule.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.

Title: Minimal Change Disease
Description: Diffuse effacement of foot processes can be seen on transmission electron microscopy (×800).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Minor Aphthous Ulcer (Lip)
Description: This photo shows a minor aphthous ulcer (canker sore) on the inside of the lip. The ulcer depicted is larger than a typical minor aphthous ulcer.

Title: Mitral Valve Prolapse (Echocardiogram)
Description: This echocardiographic image shows prolapse of the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve into the left atrium (LA).

Title: Modified Blalock-Taussig-Thomas Shunt
Description: The modified Blalock-Taussig-Thomas shunt is connection of the subclavian and pulmonary arteries by a synthetic tube.

Title: Mole
Description: Moles are flesh- to brown-colored macules, papules, or nodules composed of nests of melanocytes or nevus cells. Moles develop on nearly everybody, and are significant primarily because they can become dysplastic or malignant and need to be differentiated from melanoma.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Molluscum Contagiosum (Torso)
Description: This image shows scattered lesions of molluscum contagiosum on the lateral torso of a toddler.
Copyright: Image courtesy of James G.H. Dinulos, MD.

Title: Molluscum Contagiosum in a Child With HIV Infection
Description: This photo shows very severe lesions on the face of a child with HIV infection. Giant molluscum indicates advanced immunodeficiency.

Title: Mönckeberg Arteriosclerosis
Description: This x-ray of the hand shows calcified arteries (arrows).

Title: Monteggia Fracture Dislocation (1)
Description: This x-ray shows proximal ulnar fracture (blue arrow) with associated radial head dislocation. The radial head (red arrow) is above the capitellum, its normal articulation.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Monteggia Fracture Dislocation (2)
Description: This x-ray shows proximal ulnar fracture with concomitant radial head dislocation (red arrow).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Morbiliform Rash
Description: This image shows a morbiliform eruption secondary to use of a drug.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Anar Mikailov, MD, FAAD.

Title: Morphea
Description: This image shows multiple sclerotic areas on the trunk typical of morphea.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Morpheaform Basal Cell Carcinoma
Description: This basal cell carcinoma appears as a flat, waxy, poorly demarcated plaque with prominent telangiectasia.

Title: Mpox
Description:
Mpox is clinically similar to smallpox. Prior to the 2022 outbreak, skin lesions on any part of the body shared the same stage of development.

    In the 2022 global outbreak, atypical clinical presentations include skin lesions starting in the genital, perianal, or oral regions, lesions localized to a specific anatomic site, and lesions being in different stages of progression on a specific anatomic site (eg, vesicles and pustules existing side-by-side).

    Unlike smallpox, lymphadenopathy is common in mpox.
Copyright: Image from NHS England High Consequence Infectious Disease Network.

Title: MRI (FLAIR) Multiple Sclerosis
Description: This image shows multiple hyperintense white matter lesions seen in a sagittal view of the brain of a patient with multiple sclerosis. This finding is sometimes called Dawson fingers.

Title: MRI Findings of Cardiac Sarcoidosis
Description: This cardiac MRI shows a late gadolinium patchy transmural enhancement pattern (arrow) characteristic of sarcoidosis, which may cause a dilated or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Title: MRI Findings of Myocardial Infarct
Description: This cardiac MRI shows the right ventricle (red arrow) and left ventricle (green arrow) separated by the septal myocardium (blue arrow). There is late gadolinium subendocardial enhancement characteristic of a small myocardial infarct in the lateral wall of the left ventricle (white arrow).

Title: MRI of Gonococcal Arthritis in the Wrist
Description: This T1-weighted coronal fat-suppressed MRI with gadolinium of a wrist with gonococcal septic arthritis shows diffuse synovial enhancement and erosions.

TopicLocations.Title: MRI of Gonococcal Arthritis in the Wrist

Title: MRI of Patient with Myocarditis and Pericardial Effusion
Description: Patchy mid wall (bottom white arrow) and epicardial (top white arrow) delayed enhancement on MRI is consistent with myocarditis. This patient also has a pericardial effusion (red arrow).

TopicLocations.Title: MRI of Patient with Myocarditis and Pericardial Effusion

Title: MRI of the Knee
Description: Sagittal proton density–weighted 3-tesla magnetic resonance image of the right knee shows meniscocapsular separation involving the medial meniscus posterior horn (arrows).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Mucopurulent Cervicitis
Description: The cervical os is red and inflamed and exudes a thick, yellow discharge.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Goldfarb A. In Atlas of Clinical Gynecology: Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology. Edited by M Stenchever (series editor) and AF Goldfarb. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1998.

Title: Mucosal Leishmaniasis
Description: This patient with mucosal leishmaniasis has significant erythema and nodularity of the nasal passage with accompanying erosion of the nasal septum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. A. Canese via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Mucosal Neuroma
Description: Mucosal neuromas may appear as small glistening bumps on the tongue.

Title: Mucus Retention Cyst (Mucocele, Mucus Extravasation Phenomenon)
Description: This photo shows a labial mucocele, a benign mass consisting of a swollen sac filled with mucus. Mucoceles are often fluctuant, although some can feel firmer to palpation.

TopicLocations.Title: Mucus Retention Cyst (Mucocele, Mucus Extravasation Phenomenon)

Title: Multilobar Pneumonia
Description: Consolidation of the right upper, middle, and lower lobes in a 64-year-old male with pneumococcal pneumonia.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Roberts R. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Pleuropulmonary and Bronchial Infections. Edited by GL Mandell (series editor) and MS Simberkoff. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1996.

Title: Multiple Atypical Nevi
Description: This image shows atypical nevi, with characteristic irregular borders and variable coloration.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Marie Schreiner, PA-C.

Title: Multiple Lipomas
Description: This picture shows multiple lipomas on the arms of an adult patient.

Title: Multiple Myeloma
Description: This skull x-ray shows multiple, punched-out lesions in the bone (arrows), which are typical of multiple myeloma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Multiple Myeloma
Description: This skull x-ray shows multiple, punched-out lesions in the bone (arrows), which are typical of multiple myeloma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Mumps
Description: This image shows a child with right-sided parotid swelling due to mumps parotitis, obscuring the angle of the mandible. Parotitis also characteristically causes lifting of the earlobe upward and outward, which is best viewed by standing behind the patient.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Sylvan Stool, MD.

Title: Mycetoma (Madura Foot)
Description: This photo shows chronic, nonhealing wounds with recurring episodes of drainage and ulceration (top) and advanced destruction of the entire bony architecture of the foot (bottom).

Title: Mycetoma (Nodular)
Description: This image shows multiple, infiltrated nodules on the foot of a patient with mycetoma.

Title: Mycetoma (Skin Rupture)
Description: This image shows multiple subcutaneous nodules and rupture to the skin surface.

Title: Mycosis Fungoides (Back)
Description: This photo shows red patches on the back of a patient with mycosis fungoides.

Title: Mycosis Fungoides (Buttocks)
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Mycosis Fungoides (Chest)
Description: Mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma) can be difficult to distinguish from nonmalignant chronic dermatoses. Accurate diagnosis can be made only by a detailed clinical history (no progression of nonmalignant lesions over time) and biopsy with microscopic evaluation.
Copyright: (Courtesy of Libby Edwards, MD, Charlotte, NC.) By permission of the publisher. From Banks P, et al. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004. Available at www.images.md.

Title: Mycosis Fungoides (Trunk and Leg)
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Mycosis Fungoides with Ulceration
Description: Ulcerations can sometimes develop in patients with mycosis fungoides.

Title: Myeloma Kidney
Description: Myeloma kidney refers to tubulointerstitial disease caused by light chain deposition and obstructive cast formation in renal tubules. Biopsy specimen demonstrates tubular casts with surrounding syncytial giant cell reaction, chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis with lymphocytic infiltrate, and fibrosis (periodic acid-Schiff stain, original magnification ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Myxedema in Hypothyroidism
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Burman K, Becker K, Cytryn A, et al. In Atlas of Clinical Endocrinology: Thyroid Diseases. Edited by SG Korenman (series editor) and MI Surks. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1999.

Title: Nail Bed Psoriasis With Onycholysis
Description: Nail bed psoriasis causes onycholysis (as evidenced by the white discoloration of the distal nails with erythematous border and absence of distal nail on the ring and little fingers). The underlying nail bed is hyperkeratotic.

Title: Nail Discoloration Due to Nail Polish
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Nail Discoloration Due to Nail Polish

Title: Nail Pits Caused by Psoriatic JIA
Description: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) or psoriasis can cause pits in the nails such as these.

TopicLocations.Title: Nail Pits Caused by Psoriatic JIA

Title: Nail Psoriasis With Pitting and Discoloration
Description: This photo shows irregular pits and areas of yellow-brown discoloration (oil spots) in a person with psoriasis.

TopicLocations.Title: Nail Psoriasis With Pitting and Discoloration
Nail Psoriasis With Pitting and Discoloration

Title: Nail Psoriasis With Thickening and Crumbling of the Nail Plate
Description: The photo on the left shows thickening and crumbling of the nail of the great toe. Pitting and onycholysis are visible on the hand (right), suggesting nail psoriasis as the diagnosis.

TopicLocations.Title: Nail Psoriasis With Thickening and Crumbling of the Nail Plate
Nail Psoriasis With Thickening and Crumbling of the Nail Plate

Title: Nasal Fracture
Description: Ecchymosis, deviation of the nasal bones, and a laceration characterize this open nasal fracture.

Title: Nasal Polyp
Description: A mature nasal polyp can resemble a peeled, seedless grape.
Copyright: Image provided by Bechara Ghorayeb, MD.

Title: Necrobiosis Lipoidica
Description: Necrobiosis lipoidica is characteristic but not diagnostic of diabetes. Lesions most often appear on the legs and begin as erythematous papules that develop into atrophic, waxy, and yellow or brown lesions.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Necrobiosis Lipoidica
Description: Necrobiosis lipoidica is characteristic but not diagnostic of diabetes. Lesions most often appear on the legs and begin as erythematous papules that develop into atrophic, waxy, and yellow or brown lesions.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Necrotizing Fasciitis
Description: The 1st photo on the left shows a preoperative image of the dorsal right arm with hemorrhagic bullae and cyanotic skin lesions. The 2nd photo from the left shows erupted vesicles on the medial arm. The 3rd and 4th photos show postoperative changes with extensive skin necrosis on the dorsal side and myonecrosis and cyanotic changes of underlying flexor muscles on the medial aspect.

Title: Necrotizing Subcutaneous Infection (X-Ray)
Description: In this artificially colored x-ray, the salient finding is the presence of soft-tissue gas, indicated by the highly radiolucent densities superior to the calcaneus and posterior to the tibia and fibula.

Title: Neonatal Herpes Simplex Virus Infection
Description: Clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base are characteristic and may be present on almost any part of the body.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Demmler G: Congenital and perinatal infections. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Pediatric Infectious Diseases. Edited by CM Wilfert. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1998.
TopicName: Neonatal Herpes Simplex Virus HSV Infection

TopicLocations.Title: Neonatal Herpes Simplex Virus Infection
TopicLocations.TopicName: Neonatal Herpes Simplex Virus HSV Infection

Title: Neonatal Tetanus
Description: Neonatal tetanus most commonly affects infants born to nonimmune mothers. Exotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani gains entry to the circulation when the infant's umbilical cord is cut or the umbilical stump is cleaned in a nonsterile fashion. Generalized rigidity and spasm affect the child in the first 2 weeks of life and may be fatal.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Neurocysticercosis
Description: This CT scan shows multifocal areas of calcification representing calcified cysts in a patient with neurocysticercosis.
Copyright: Courtesy of John E. Greenlee, MD.

Title: Neurofibromas
Description: This photo shows multiple neurofibromas (tan nodules) on a patient with neurofibromatosis.

Title: Neurofibromas and Café-au-Lait Spots
Description: This photo shows multiple neurofibromas (raised pink or tan nodules) and café-au-lait spots (flat brownish spots) on the back of a patient with neurofibromatosis.

Title: Neurofibromatosis (Lisch Nodules)
Description: Lisch nodules of the iris are hyperpigmented melanotic hamartomas.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Kotagal S, Bicknese A, Eswara M: Atlas of Clinical Neurology. Edited by RN Rosenberg. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Neurofibromatosis (Neurofibromas)
Description: The back and arms of this 69-year-old man are covered with small neurofibromas, and there is a café-au-lait spot just medial to his right scapula.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Bird T, Sumi S: Atlas of Clinical Neurology. Edited by RN Rosenberg. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Neurofibromatosis (Skeletal Anomalies)
Description: In this photo, the patient’s left arm has a plexiform neuroma extending from the deltoid proximal humerus to the hand. Her humerus is affected by multiple midshaft fractures associated with thinning of bone cortex and pseudoarthrosis. She also has scoliosis, short stature, and enlargement of the lumbar intraspinal canal caused by anterior meningocele.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Kotagal S, Bicknese A, Eswara M: Atlas of Clinical Neurology. Edited by RN Rosenberg. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Neurogenic Arthropathy of the Foot
Description: This x-ray shows neurogenic arthropathy of the foot (also known as Charcot foot). Destruction, deformities, and loss of joint spaces of the tarsal bones is extensive.

Title: Nevus Sebaceus
Description: This photo shows a nevus sebaceus (a type of birthmark that usually appears on the scalp). This benign congenital skin discoloration is due to pigmentation and is composed of sebaceous gland tissue.
Copyright: DR P. MARAZZI / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Nodular Basal Cell Carcinoma
Description: This lesion usually appears as a firm, pearly, dome-shaped nodule often displaying multiple telangiectatic vessels coursing over its borders.

Title: Nodular Basal Cell Carcinoma
Description: This photo shows a superficial, slowly growing, ulcerated nodule.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Nodular Melanoma
Description: The protuberance of this lesion is characteristic of nodular melanoma, which usually appears gray to black.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Gregory L. Wells, MD.

Title: Nodular Scabies
Description: Nodular scabies are shown in this photo as multiple brownish red papules on the axilla.

Title: Nodular Scleritis
Description: Nodular scleritis is characterized by a hyperemic, painful, edematous, and raised nodule.

Title: Noma (Gangrenous Stomatitis)
Description: This photo shows a child's face disfigured by severe gangrenous stomatitis or cancrum oris. This disease is an infective gangrene of the tissues of the cheek or mouth and occurs in undernourished children.

Title: Nonbullous Impetigo
Description: Nonbullous impetigo is a superficial skin infection that manifests as clusters of vesicles or pustules that rupture and develop a honey-colored crust.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Nonbullous Impetigo (Child)
Description: This image shows crusted perinasal plaques of impetigo on the face of a child.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Wingfield Rehmus, MD, MPH.

Title: Nonbullous Impetigo (Infant)
Description: This photo shows clusters of vesicles and pustules with developing honey-colored crust on the nose.

Title: Nonbullous Impetigo (Infant)
Description: This photo shows clusters of vesicles and pustules with developing honey-colored crust on the nose.

Title: Normal Optic Nerve
Description: The optic nerve is normally a slightly vertically elongated circle (disk) with a centrally located depression (cup). Optic nerve cells comprise the neuroretinal rim, the tissue between the cup and disk margins.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Douglas Rhee, MD

Title: Normal Pleural Line
Description: The pleural line is hyperechoic (red arrow). During respirations, rib sliding will cause the pleural line to shimmer and create an appearance of walking “ants on a log” when visualized in a real-time video (green arrows). A-lines (yellow arrow) appear because of artifactual reflection of the ultrasound waves.
Copyright: Copyright Hospital Procedures Consultants at www.hospitalprocedures.org.
TopicName: How To Do E FAST Examination

TopicLocations.Title: Normal Pleural Line
TopicLocations.TopicName: How To Do E FAST Examination

Title: Normal Retina
Description: This image shows the right retina of a patient without retinal disease. The macula appears darker than the surrounding retina because it has a higher density of retinal pigment epithelial cells.
Copyright: Image provided by Sunir Garg, MD.
TopicName: Age Related Macular Degeneration AMD or ARMD

TopicLocations.Title: Normal Retina
TopicLocations.TopicName: Age Related Macular Degeneration AMD or ARMD

Title: Normal Tympanic Membrane
Description: The normal right tympanic membrane is pearly in color and has visible, distinct landmarks.

Title: Normal Wrist: Lateral View
Description: This lateral view of a normal wrist demonstrates the normal interface between the radius and lunate (red line) and the lunate and capitate (yellow line).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Norwood Procedure
Description: In the Norwood procedure (stage 1), a source of pulmonary blood flow is established by inserting a right-sided modified Blalock-Taussig-Thomas shunt (top). The main pulmonary artery is divided, the distal vessel is closed with a patch, the hypoplastic aorta and proximal pulmonary artery are combined to create a neoaorta, and the ductus arteriosus is ligated (bottom).

Title: NSTEMI
Description: This ECG of a patient in NSTEMI shows sinus tachycardia with right bundle branch block and inferolateral ST depressions and T wave inversions.

Title: Nuclear Medicine Stress Test
Description: This composite set of images demonstrates a normal nuclear medicine stress test. Image rows or polar maps denoted Rst or RS are obtained before stress, and those denoted Str or ST are obtained during stress. There are no areas of decreased radionuclide uptake. There is similar uptake at rest and stress.

Title: Nummular Dermatitis
Description: This photo shows discoid, erythematous, and scaly lesions consistent with nummular dermatitis.

Title: Nummular Dermatitis (Hands)
Description: In this image, round erythematous patches are present on the dorsa of the hands and wrists.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health’s Occupational Dermatoses web site (www.cdc.gov/niosh/ocderm.html).

Title: Obstetric Ultrasound
Description: This photo shows an ultrasound image of a fetus.

Title: Ocular Burn (Chemical)
Description: This photo shows corneal degeneration and generalized conjunctival erythema after a burn to the eye caused by ammonia.

Title: Ocular Mucous Membrane Pemphigoid
Description: Ocular mucous membrane pemphigoid is an autoimmune disease (unrelated to bullous pemphigoid) in which autoantibodies cause chronic conjunctivitis, leading to conjunctival scarring (including adhesion of some palpebral conjunctiva to the bulbar conjunctiva—symblepharon; blue arrows) and shrinkage (loss of depth of the fornix also known as blunting; black arrow) with corneal keratinization and opacification. The image on the left is before treatment and the image on the right is after treatment.

Title: Ocular Rosacea
Description: This photo shows bilateral conjunctival redness with eyelid redness and swelling in a patient with ocular rosacea.

Title: Olecranon Bursitis
Description: This photo shows a patient with an inflamed elbow bursa.

TopicLocations.Title: Olecranon Bursitis
TopicLocations.TopicName: How To Aspirate or Inject an Olecranon Bursa

Title: Olecranon Fracture
Description: This lateral x-ray shows a displaced olecranon fracture (arrow).
Copyright: Credit line: ANTONIA REEVE/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Oligodendroglioma, Low-Grade
Description: This T2-FLAIR (fluid-attenuating inversion recovery) MRI scan shows a white signal, which may indicate a mass or edema. The left frontal signal is highly demarcated, suggesting a mass. Use of contrast does not enhance it. It is a low-grade (grade II) oligodendroglioma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of William R. Shapiro, MD.

Title: Omphalocele
Description: This photo shows a large omphalocele. Note the membranous covering and the umbilical cord at the base of the omphalocele. This patient also has other congenital abnormalities, such as cleft lip and palate and left anophthalmia and hydrocele (not seen in this photo).

Title: Onychogryphosis
Description: Onychogryphosis is thickening and curving of the nails.
Copyright: Image provided by Barbara A. Gilchrest, MD.

Title: Onycholysis
Description: Onycholysis (as evidenced by the white discoloration of the distal nail), as well as pitting, is visible in this patient with psoriasis.

Title: Onychomycosis
Description: Onychomycosis is fungal infection of the nail plate, nail bed, or both. Infection may be distal subungual, with nail thickening and yellowing and accumulation of keratin and debris underneath the nail (top); proximal subungual (not pictured); or white superficial, with spreading of chalky white scale beneath the nail surface (bottom).
Copyright: Images provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Onychomycosis of the Great Toes
Description: This photo shows onychomycosis of the great toenails. The right toenail shows classic distolateral (a distal subungual) onychomycosis (DLO), whereas the left toenail likely began as DLO and progressed to dermatophytoma (dense collection of hyphae that appears as a linear streak).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Edwin P. Ewing, Jr. via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Ophthalmia Neonatorum
Description: This image shows gonococcal ophthalmia. Symptoms and signs of eyelid edema, chemosis, and purulent discharge develop 2 to 5 days after delivery.

Title: Ophthalmia Neonatorum
Description: This image shows gonococcal ophthalmia. Symptoms and signs of eyelid edema, chemosis, and purulent discharge develop 2 to 5 days after delivery.

Title: Oral and Genital Lesions in Behçet Disease
Description: This image shows aphthous ulcers on the tongue (left) and on the penis (right) resulting from Behçet disease.

TopicLocations.Title: Oral and Genital Lesions in Behçet Disease

Title: Oral Candidiasis (Labial Mucosa)
Description: This photo shows oral candidiasis manifesting as a white exudate overlying a beefy, red, and raw mucosal surface of the labial mucosa.

Title: Oral Candidiasis Due to HIV
Description: This photo shows fluffy white exudate on the tongue of a child with HIV infection.

Title: Oral Hairy Leukoplakia
Description: Oral hairy leukoplakia appears as verrucous white outgrowths on the lateral margins of the tongue.
Copyright: Image courtesy of J.S. Greenspan, BDS, University of California, San Francisco and Sol Silverman, Jr., DDS via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Oral Hairy Leukoplakia
Description: Oral hairy leukoplakia appears as verrucous white outgrowths on the lateral margins of the tongue.
Copyright: Image courtesy of J.S. Greenspan, BDS, University of California, San Francisco and Sol Silverman, Jr., DDS via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Oral Hairy Leukoplakia
Description: Oral hairy leukoplakia appears as verrucous white outgrowths on the lateral margins of the tongue.
Copyright: Image courtesy of J.S. Greenspan, BDS, University of California, San Francisco and Sol Silverman, Jr., DDS via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: This photo shows a close-up of the inside of the mouth (the buccal mucosa) in a patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the oral mucosa.

Title: Oral Warts
Description: Verruca vulgaris (wart) of the anterior lingual gingiva. The lesion is whiter than surrounding tissue with prominent hair-like projections.

Title: Orbital Cellulitis
Description: Eyelid erythema and edema may occur with both preseptal and orbital cellulitis. However, marked proptosis, which is particularly visible in the overhead view (top), suggests orbital cellulitis.
Copyright: Photos courtesy of James Garrity, MD.

Title: Orbital Lymphoma
Description: In this image, the first coronal CT scan (left) shows a homogeneous mass conforming to the globe (red arrow). The second coronal CT scan (center) shows a well-demarcated mass in the right lacrimal gland fossa (blue arrow). The axial CT scan (right) shows a homogenous lacrimal fossa mass conforming to the right globe (yellow arrow).
Copyright: Images courtesy of James Garrity, MD.

Title: Osteoarthritis of the Hip
Description: This x-ray shows changes characteristic of osteoarthritis, including large femoral (red arrow) and acetabular (black arrow) osteophytes and some joint space narrowing.
Copyright: Image provided by Roy Altman, MD.

Title: Osteochondroma of the Knee
Description: This x-ray of the knee shows a bony outgrowth (arrow) from the femur above the knee joint that is consistent with an osteochondroma.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Osteogenesis Imperfecta (Blue Sclerae)
Description: This photo shows a close-up of the eye showing a blue sclera (normally white).

Title: Osteogenesis Imperfecta (Skeletal Findings)
Description: This photo shows a patient with severe osteogenesis imperfecta who has a barrel chest, spinal curvature, severe bone deformities, loose joints, and poor muscle development.

Title: Osteoid Osteoma
Description: Axial CT image of the proximal femur (adjacent bone is pelvic ramus) shows typical lucent nidus with central calcification (arrow) in child aged 6 with left hip pain. This CT shows the classic bullseye lesion.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Osteoid Osteoma of the Tibia (MRI)
Description: This axial T2-weighted fat-suppressed MRI shows an intracortical osteoid osteoma (arrow) and adjacent subtle intramedullary bone marrow edema.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Osteoid Osteoma of the Tibia (X-Ray)
Description: This lateral x-ray of the left tibia shows a lucent posterior osteoid osteoma (red arrow). Note the chronic-appearing, smooth periosteal thickening around the tumor (blue arrows).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Osteomyelitis
Description: This x-ray reveals osteomyelitis with an evident sequestrum noted in the left mandibular quadrant (arrow).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Byron (Pete) Benson, DDS, MS, Texas A&M University Baylor College of Dentistry.

Title: Osteomyelitis
Description: This x-ray reveals osteomyelitis with an evident sequestrum noted in the left mandibular quadrant (arrow).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Byron (Pete) Benson, DDS, MS, Texas A&M University Baylor College of Dentistry.

Title: Osteopoikilosis of the Pelvis
Description: The x-ray shows osteopoikilosis of the pelvis of a 55-year-old woman (obtained after a possible fall); densities could be mistaken for brwww blastic metastases (left). The bone scan shows no significant increased uptake (right).
Copyright: Images courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and David M. Joyce, MD.

Title: Osteoporotic Compression Fracture
Description: This x-ray shows a severe osteoporotic compression fracture of the first lumbar vertebra (L1; arrow).
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Marcy B. Bolster, MD.

Title: Osteosarcoma
Description: This x-ray of the knee shows a dense osteosarcoma in the femur above the knee.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Otitis Externa
Description: This image shows swelling, erythema, and dried discharge resulting from otitis externa.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Otitis Externa with Furuncle
Description: In patients with otitis externa, the ear canal is erythematous and swollen and may be littered with purulent debris. As shown in this image, a furuncle (arrow) can develop in the infected canal.
Copyright: Image provided by Bechara Ghorayeb, MD.

Title: Otomycosis
Description: This image shows otomycosis of the external ear canal, as indicated by fungal hyphae and conidiophores of Aspergillus niger.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Bradley Kesser, MD.

Title: Oval Macrocytes and Hypersegmented Neutrophils in Vitamin B12 Deficiency
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

TopicLocations.Title: Oval Macrocytes and Hypersegmented Neutrophils in Vitamin B12 Deficiency

Title: Paget Disease of the Nipple
Description: In Paget disease of the nipple, ductal carcinoma in situ extends over the nipple and areola and causes scaling, pruritus, and burning pain in the affected nipple.

Title: Paget Disease of the Nipple
Description: In Paget disease of the nipple, ductal carcinoma in situ extends over the nipple and areola and causes scaling, pruritus, and burning pain in the affected nipple.

Title: Palatal Salivary Gland Pleomorphic Adenoma
Description: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common intraoral benign neoplasm. The palatal mucosa is the most common site of occurrence.

Title: Palmar Warts
Description: This photo shows two warts (verrucas) on the palm of a hand.

Title: Palmoplantar Keratoderma
Description: This photo shows palmoplantar keratoderma characterized by well-demarcated, symmetric keratoderma of the soles in a patient with tylosis (thick calluses; also known as diffuse nonepidermolytic palmoplantar keratoderma).

Title: Palmoplantar Psoriasis (Palm)
Description: This photo shows hyperkeratotic discrete plaques on the palm of a patient with palmoplantar psoriasis.

Title: Palmoplantar Psoriasis (Sole)
Description: This photo shows hyperkeratotic discrete plaques on the sole of a patient with palmoplantar psoriasis.

Title: Palmoplantar Pustulosis
Description: This photo shows erythematous macules and pustules on the foot of a patient with pustular psoriasis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Panniculitis
Description: This photo shows violaceous infiltrated plaques of the anterior-medial part of the thighs.

Title: PAPA Syndrome (Pyogenic Arthritis, Pyoderma Gangrenosum, and Acne Syndrome)
Description: Pyoderma gangrenosum (necrotic tissue with deep ulceration) and nodulocystic acne are characteristic of PAPA syndrome.

TopicLocations.Title: PAPA Syndrome (Pyogenic Arthritis, Pyoderma Gangrenosum, and Acne Syndrome)

Title: Papilledema
Description: Funduscopic findings of papilledema include engorged and tortuous retinal veins, a hyperemic and swollen optic disk, and retinal hemorrhages around the disk. A swollen optic disk is suggested by disk elevation, loss of the optic cup, and obscuration of the fine vessels on the optic nerve surface.
Copyright: Image provided by James Garrity, MD.

Title: Papular-Purpuric Gloves-and-Socks Syndrome
Description: Papular, purpuric, or petechial lesions limited to the hands and feet can be seen in this image of parvovirus B19 infection.

Title: Paracoccidioidomycosis
Description: The person in this photo has left facial and auricular involvement. This photo shows two gray verrucous plaques on an erythematous base, erythematous nodules, and violaceous patches.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Paracoccidioidomycosis (Mucocutaneous Ulcers)
Description: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection becomes clinically apparent as mucocutaneous ulcers, especially around the nose (top) and mouth, including the tongue, pharynx, and gums (bottom).

Title: Paracoccidioidomycosis (Neck)
Description: In Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection, regional lymph nodes may become necrotic.

Title: Paraphimosis
Description: In paraphimosis, the pulled-back (retracted) foreskin is trapped, causing swelling of the glans.

Title: Parasympathetic Innervation
TopicName: Overview of the Autonomic Nervous System

TopicLocations.Title: Parasympathetic Innervation
TopicLocations.TopicName: Overview of the Autonomic Nervous System

Title: Parotid Salivary Gland Tumor
Description: This patient has a large right-sided parotid salivary gland tumor. The whitish papules on her skin are an incidental finding due to yaws (a chronic cutaneous infection caused by Treponema pallidum subspecies pertenue).
Copyright: Image courtesy of K. Mae Lennon and Clement Benjamin via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Parotid Tumor (Left)
Description: This photo shows a close-up of a parotid tumor on the left face.

Title: Partial-Thickness (2nd-Degree) Burn
Description: This partial-thickness burn shows bullae over the cheek and some redness. Redness is particularly obvious over the forehead, where a large bullous lesion has opened, draining its fluid.
Copyright: Image provided by Steven E. Wolf, MD.

Title: Patellar Dislocation
Description: Close-up comparing the normal right knee (left) and swollen left knee of a male patient following dislocation of the kneecap (patella) as a result of an injury.

Title: Patellar Dislocation (X-Ray)
Description: This anteroposterior view of the knee shows a patellar dislocation, characterized by extreme lateral displacement of the patella, outside its normal location between the femoral condyles.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Patellar Fracture
Description: A lateral knee x-ray shows a transverse fracture of the patella (arrow).

Title: Patellar Tendon Tear
Description: The superior displacement of the patella seen on this x-ray (well above the knee joint) suggests a tear of the patellar tendon, with unopposed contraction of the quadriceps muscle.

Title: Pearly Penile Papules and Penile Warts
Description: This patient has a ring of pearly lesions along the corona of the glans (from left to lower right) consistent with pearly penile papules. He also has penile warts (center) caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

TopicLocations.Title: Pearly Penile Papules and Penile Warts

Title: Peau d’Orange
Description: Sometimes in inflammatory brwww cancer and very advanced cancers, the brwww appears inflamed, and the skin appears thickened, resembling orange peel (peau d’orange).

Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Patient-with-inflammatory-brwww-cancer_fig2_234162338 [accessed 3 Oct, 2019].

Title: Pellagrous Glove
Description: This photo shows scaly, erythematous to brown plaques on the sun-exposed dorsal surface of both hands resulting from niacin deficiency.

Title: Pellagrous Skin Changes (Buttocks)
Description: This image shows hyperpigmented and hyperkeratotic skin changes characterized by pellagra (niacin deficiency).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pellagrous Skin Changes (Feet)
Description: This image shows hyperpigemented and hyperkerototic skin changes characterized by pellagra (niacin deficiency).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Description: This image shows hyperpigemented and hyperkerototic skin changes characterized by pellagra (niacin deficiency).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pelvic Abscess (CT Scan)
Description: This CT scan shows an abscess (red arrow) in the pelvis caused by appendicitis. Note the radio-opaque fecalith (white arrow).
Copyright: Image provided by Parswa Ansari, MD.

Title: Pelvic Fracture
Description: In this severe injury, disruption of the pelvic ring is clearly evident based on the widely separated pubic bone syndesmosis and the right-sided sacroiliac ligaments. Fracture lines are not as obvious.
Copyright: DU CANE MEDICAL IMAGING LTD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Pemphigoid Gestationis
Description: This photo shows the bullous pemphigoid-like eruption of pregnancy called pemphigoid gestationis. Vesicles and bullae are shown. Although the rash resembles the vesicobullous eruption of herpes simplex virus (hence the previous name herpes gestationis), the disorder is not an infection.

Title: Pemphigoid Gestationis (Abdominal Skin)
Description: Pemphigoid gestationis can cause erythematous, urticariform, annular plaques on the trunk. In this patient, the rash has the multiforme-like iris configuration and involves the periumbilical area.

Title: Pemphigus Foliaceus
Description: This photo shows scaled, crusted, superficial lesions resulting from pemphigus foliaceus.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pemphigus Foliaceus (Chest)
Description: This photo shows well-demarcated, scattered, crusted, erythematous lesions of pemphigus foliaceus.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pemphigus Vegetans
Description: This photo shows erosions and fungating vegetating plaques in the axilla resulting from pemphigus vegetans.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pemphigus Vulgaris
Description: This photo shows generalized flaccid, ruptured bullae with surrounding erythema characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Daniel M. Peraza, MD.

Title: Pemphigus Vulgaris (Flaccid Bullae)
Description: The primary lesions of pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid bullae.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pemphigus Vulgaris (Oral Mucosa)
Description: This photo shows bullae on the lips of a patient with pemphigus vulgaris.

Title: Pemphigus Vulgaris (Oral)
Description: Pemphigus lesions typically appear first in the mouth, where they rupture and remain as chronic, painful erosions for variable periods. Oral lesions often precede cutaneous lesions.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pemphigus Vulgaris (Shearing and Erosions)
Description: In pemphigus vulgaris, painful erosions on the skin and mucosa are common.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Penile Squamous Cell Carcinoma in Situ (Formerly Bowen Disease)
Description: This photo shows red, scaly lesions on the penis consistent with Bowen disease.

TopicLocations.Title: Penile Squamous Cell Carcinoma in Situ (Formerly Bowen Disease)

Title: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention
Description: Coronary angiogram showing stent (white mesh) in a coronary artery.

Title: Perichondritis With Abscess Formation
Description: Severe perichondritis with abscess formation is seen in this image. The infection was caused by an ear piercing.
Copyright: Image provided by Bechara Ghorayeb, MD.

Title: Perilunate Dislocation
Description: On a lateral view of a perilunate dislocation, the capitate does not articulate with the lunate.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Periocular Infantile Hemangioma
Description: Periocular hemangiomas are hemangiomas surrounding the eye.

Title: Periocular Infantile Hemangioma
Description: Periocular hemangiomas are hemangiomas surrounding the eye.

Title: Periodontitis
Description: This photo shows receding gums and a periodontal abscess (arrow) in a person who has periodontitis.

Title: Periodontitis (Loss of Supporting Tissues of the Tooth)
Description: This photo shows a close-up of tissue loss in a person with periodontal disease. Periodontal disease has caused a loss of gum tissue and bone around the teeth.

TopicLocations.Title: Periodontitis (Loss of Supporting Tissues of the Tooth)

Title: Perioral Dermatitis
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Shahbaz Janjua, MD.

Title: Peripheral Arterial Disease—Skin Changes
Description: The 4th toe is pale and cold in this patient with peripheral arterial disease.

Title: Peripheral Blood Blast Cell
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Chang K, Forman S. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Peripheral Blood Smear, Normal
Description: A drop of blood is applied against a glass slide that is subsequently stained with polychrome stains (Wright-Giemsa) to permit identification of the various cell types. These stains are mixtures of basic dyes (methylene blue) that stain as blue and acidic dyes (eosin) that stain as red. Thus, acid components of the cell (nucleus, cytoplasmic RNA, basophilic granules) stain blue or purple, and basic components of the cell (hemoglobin, eosinophilic granules) stain red or orange.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Peritonsillar Abscess
Description: This photo shows peritonsillar abscess with bulging and deviation of the uvula accompanying moderate trismus.
Copyright: Image provided by Clarence T. Sasaki, MD.

Title: Peritonsillar Abscess With Uvular Deviation
Description: In this patient, the uvula is pushed away from the midline by the swollen tonsillar area, suggesting peritonsillar abscess or cellulitis. There are crypts on the swollen side.

Title: Perlèche
Description: Perlèche is candidiasis at the corners of the mouth, causing tiny cracks and fissures.

Title: Pes Planus (Flat Feet)
Description: In pes planus (flat feet), the normal arch in the middle of the feet appears flattened.
TopicName: Talipes Equinovarus Clubfoot and Other Foot Abnormalities
