Title: Petechiae (Hard Palate)
Description: Petechiae are characterized by small red spots as seen here on the palate of this patient.

Title: Petechiae and Purpura Secondary to Meningococcemia
Description: Petechiae and purpura are visible on the child's face. Hemorrhagic return from the nasogastric tube is consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation, also secondary to meningococcemia.

TopicLocations.Title: Petechiae and Purpura Secondary to Meningococcemia

Title: Petechiae in Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP)
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Deitcher S. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Petechiae Secondary to Meningococcemia (Foot)
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pharyngeal Abscess
Description: This photo shows a child with cervical swelling down to the level of the hyoid bone caused by a pharyngeal abscess.
Copyright: Photo provided by Clarence T. Sasaki, MD.

Title: Phimosis
Description: This photo shows the penis of a young boy with phimosis.

Title: Photoaging
Description: Photoaged skin is characterized by fine and coarse wrinkling, irregular mottled pigmentation, lentigines (large frecklelike spots), roughness, and sallowness.
Copyright: Image provided by Barbara A. Gilchrest, MD.

Title: Photosensitivity (Hydrochlorothiazide)
Description: This image shows erythema caused by chemical photosensitivity to hydrochlorothiazide. The skin changes are similar to a sunburn.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Phytobezoar
Description: This photo shows a phytobezoar found in a patient with diabetic gastroparesis.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Pigmented Basal Cell Carcinoma
Description: Pigmented basal cell carcinoma is rare. These lesions are sometimes misdiagnosed as pigmented nevi or malignant melanomas.

Title: Pilonidal Cyst
Description: This photo shows a midline pilonidal cyst with three openings in the sacral region.

Title: Pincer Nails
Description: In this patient with hereditary pincer nails, the edges of the nails curve inwardly into the skin of the toes.

Title: Pinguecula
Description: This photo shows a pinguecula, a raised yellowish white mass, adjacent to the cornea. It is a benign conjunctival growth that does not affect vision. This pinguecula is inflamed, with localized dilated normal conjunctival blood vessels highlighting its appearance.

Title: Pituitary Microadenoma
Description: T2-weighted MRI scan (top) shows a pituitary microadenoma (red arrow). Contrast (bottom) normally enhances the pituitary (red arrow). The adenoma appears lighter.
Copyright: Images courtesy of William R. Shapiro, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Lichenoides
Description: This image shows widely scattered, round, erythematous papules on the trunk and extremities of this patient with pityriasis lichenoides et varioliformis acuta (PLEVA), an acute form of pityriasis lichenoides. Erythema can look more purple or brown on dark skin tones.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Rosea
Description: In pityriasis rosea, the initial herald patch is followed by centripetal eruption of oval papules and plaques with a slightly raised border, typically appearing along skin lines.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Rosea (Back)
Description: This image shows violaceous, scaly plaques on the back and arms of a patient with pityriasis rosea. Patches that appear more pink in patients with light skin appear violaceous and/or hyperpigmented in patients with dark skin.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Rosea (Head and Torso)
Description: This image shows erythematous and violaceous, ovoid, scaly papules coalescing into patches on the head and torso of a patient with pityriasis rosea.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Rosea (Herald Patch)
Description: Initially, most people develop one large scaly patch (herald patch; arrow), and within 1 to 2 weeks, smaller pink patches can occur on the trunk, arms, and legs.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Pityriasis Rosea on the Groin
Description: This photo shows atypical (inverse) pityriasis rosea characterized by oval scaly plaques in the inguinal creases.
Copyright: Image provided by E. Laurie Tolman, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (Foot)
Description: This image shows hyperkeratosis of the sole characteristic of pityriasis rubra pilaris.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (Hyperkeratotic Palms)
Description: Pityriasis rubra pilaris can manifest as hyperkeratotic yellowing of the palms and soles.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (Scaling Plaques)
Description: Pityriasis rubra pilaris can manifest as red follicular papules that coalesce to form red-orange scaling plaques and confluent areas of erythema with islands of normal skin between lesions.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Plague Bubo (Axillary)
Description: A bubo, an enlarged, tender, firm lymph node, is caused by Yersinia pestis (plague) infection. This image shows an axillary bubo.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Drs. Margaret Parsons and Karl F. Meyer via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Plague Bubo (Femoral)
Description: A bubo, an enlarged, tender, firm lymph node, is caused by Yersinia pestis (plague) infection. This image shows a femoral bubo.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Drs. Margaret Parsons and Karl F. Meyer via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Plague Bubo (Inguinal)
Description: A bubo, an enlarged, tender, firm lymph node, is caused by Yersinia pestis (plague) infection. This image shows a swollen inguinal bubo.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Plantar Warts
Description: This photo shows warts on the sole of a foot.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pleural Effusion—Large
Description: Large right-sided pleural effusion (arrow) in a patient with rheumatoid pleuritis.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Huggins J, Sahn S. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Pleural Effusions—Small
Description: Small bilateral pleural effusions in a patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Both costophrenic angles are blunted. The arrow points to widened mediastinum due to lymphoma.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Huggins J, Sahn S. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Pleural Mesothelioma
Description: Chest x-ray in a patient with pleural mesothelioma shows pleural thickening with nodular masses on the parietal pleura.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Huggins J, Sahn S. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Pneumoconiosis
Description: The dark lung fields show a mottled appearance with patches of white fibrous masses consistent with advanced coal worker pneumoconiosis.

Title: Pneumocystis Pneumonia
Description: Chest x-ray of an HIV-infected patient with Pneumocystispneumonia, revealing characteristic bilateral, diffuse, granular opacities.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Huang L, Piliero P. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Pneumomediastinum
Description: Note air in the mediastinum and in soft tissues of the neck.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Berman L. In Atlas of Anesthesia: Critical Care. Edited by R Miller (series editor) and RR Kirby. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1997.

Title: Pneumonia of the Right Lower Lobe
Description: This chest x-ray shows an infiltrate that does not obscure the right heart border (ie, there is no silhouette sign). Because the silhouette sign develops when 2 contiguous structures have a similar radiodensity, the part of the lung affected by this infiltrate is the part not contiguous with the right heart border; that part is the right lower lobe.
Copyright: LIVING ART ENTERPRISES, LLC/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

TopicLocations.Title: Pneumonia of the Right Lower Lobe

Title: Pneumonia of the Right Middle Lobe With Silhouette Sign
Description: This chest x-ray shows an infiltrate that appears to blend with the right heart border (silhouette sign). The silhouette sign indicates contiguous positioning of the 2 structures that have similar radiodensity; the part of the lung contiguous with the right heart border is the right middle lobe, so that is the part with the infiltrate and pneumonia.

TopicLocations.Title: Pneumonia of the Right Middle Lobe With Silhouette Sign

Title: Pneumonic Plague
Description: This chest x-ray shows rapidly progressing infiltrates in pneumonic plague.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Jack Poland via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Podagra
Description: Podagra, or acute pain in the 1st metatarsophalangeal joint that is accompanied by redness, tenderness, and swelling, is a common manifestation of acute gout.

Title: Poland Syndrome
Description: The chest muscles on the patient's right side are underdeveloped.

Description: This ultrasound scan of the kidney shows numerous fluid-filled cysts (dark areas).

Title: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
Description: Polycystic ovary syndrome is so named because multiple ovarian cysts are commonly present (shown here in the right ovary).

Title: Polydactyly
Description: This photo shows preaxial polydactyly of the left hand.

Title: Polymicrogyria with Septo-Optic Dysplasia
Description: This image shows an infant with left hemispheric polymicrogyria (leftward arrow) and absent septum pellucidum with abnormal ventricular configuration (vertical arrow) consistent with septo-optic dysplasia (optic nerve hypoplasia, absent or abnormal septum pellucidum, and pituitary hypoplasia).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Stephen J. Falchek, MD.

Title: Polymorphous Light Eruption
Description: This photo shows erythematous papules and plaques on the upper trunk.
Copyright: Image courtesy of E. Laurie Tolman, MD.

Title: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda
Description: Erythema, bullae, and milia over the dorsum of the hand of a man with porphyria cutanea tarda.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From White K, Soter N. In Current Dermatologic Diagnosis and Treatment. Edited by I Freedberg, IM Freedberg, and MR Sanchez. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2001.

Title: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (Earlobe)
Description: Porphyria cutanea tarda affects predominantly sun exposed areas including the earlobes in this patient.

Title: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (Finger)
Description: This image shows erythema and ruptured bullae on the fingers of a patient with porphyria cutanea tarda.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda With Scarring
Description: Atrophic scars have developed after rupture of bullae. Some bullae are hemorrhagic.

Title: Port-Wine Stain
Description: Port-wine stains are capillary vascular malformations that are present at birth and that manifest as flat, red to purple lesions that can appear anywhere on the body.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Postdilation Tear
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Posterior Ankle (Fibular) Fracture
Description: This lateral view of the ankle shows a fracture of the distal fibula.

Title: Posterior Elbow Dislocation
Copyright: DU CANE MEDICAL IMAGING LTD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Posterior Fat Pad
Description: A posterior fat pad is always abnormal. Also on this x-ray, the anterior humeral line does not transect the middle of the capitellum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Posterior Shoulder Dislocation: Anteroposterior and Y Views
Description: In the left image (anteroposterior view), the humeral head is internally rotated, resulting in the light bulb or ice cream cone sign (projections of the greater and lesser humeral tuberosities are not seen), which suggests a posterior dislocation. In the right image (Y view), the humeral head is posterior to the glenoid fossa, which demonstrates a posterior dislocation.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Posterior Shoulder Dislocation: Anteroposterior and Y Views

Title: Posterior Shoulder Dislocation: Y View
Description: In the Y view, lines drawn through the acromion (blue arrow), coracoid (black arrow), and scapular body (red arrow) intersect at the center of the glenoid fossa. In this x-ray, the humeral head is outside of and posterior to the glenoid fossa, indicating a posterior dislocation.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Posterior Urethral Valves
Description: This voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) image shows a dilated posterior urethra with distal obstruction due to posterior urethral valves.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Drs. Ronald Rabinowitz and Jimena Cubillos.

Title: Postinfectious Glomerulonephritis (Epithelial Crescents)
Description: Epithelial crescents are especially common when biopsy occurs late, after a failed response to treatment. The crescent has ruptured Bowman capsule (Jones silver stain, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Postinfectious Glomerulonephritis (Hypercellularity With Neutrophilic Infiltration)
Description: Endothelial and mesangial hypercellularity with neutrophilic infiltration (Jones silver stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Postinfectious Glomerulonephritis (Immune Complex Deposits)
Description: Hump-shaped immune complex deposits (dark gray) with extensive foot process effacement and endocapillary proliferation are seen on transmission electron micrograph (×11,250).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Postinfectious Glomerulonephritis (Immunofluorescent Staining)
Description: In the left image, immunofluorescent staining with anti-IgG demonstrates irregular IgG deposition in capillary loops (×400). In the right image, immunofluorescent staining with anti-C3 demonstrates scattered granular C3 deposition in capillary walls (×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Prepatellar Bursitis
Description: Signs of acute inflammation can be seen in and around the left knee. In some patients with septic bursitis, an overlying skin infection is present, which may be an infected laceration, abrasion, or, as in this image, cellulitis.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Gilliland B, Wener M: Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Skin, Soft Tissue, Bone and Joint Infections. Edited by G Mandell (series editor) and TP Bleck. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1995.

Title: Preseptal Cellulitis
Description: Preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis is characterized by swelling, tenderness, and erythema of the eyelid. Preseptal cellulitis differs from orbital cellulitis in that all the swelling is confined to the eyelid. Once the eyelid is open, examination shows that the globe is white, there is no proptosis, and vision and ocular motility are normal.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of James Garrity, MD.

Title: Pretibial Myxedema
Description: This photo shows a patient with pretibial myxedema characterized by non-pitting edema, thickened scaly skin, and hyperpigmentation.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pretibial Myxedema in a Patient With Graves Disease
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Burman K, Becker K, Cytryn A, et al. In Atlas of Clinical Endocrinology: Thyroid Diseases . Edited by SG Korenman (series editor) and MI Surks. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1999.

Title: Primary Lung Cancer
Description: Chest x-ray shows a left upper lobe non–small cell lung cancer with mediastinal and left hilar adenopathy. The primary tumor is cavitated and an air-fluid level is present.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Anne S. Tsao, MD.

Title: Primary Syphilis (Mouth Chancre)
Description: Syphilitic chancres may appear on or around the mouth.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Probe Placement Perpendicular to Ribs
Description: The probe should be placed perpendicular to the ribs. Also note that the probe orientation marker is pointed cephalad.

Title: Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy
Description: This T2-weighted MRI image shows multiple changes in white matter.
Copyright: Image provided by John E. Greenlee, MD.

Title: Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (MRI)
Description: This sagittal T2-FLAIR (fluid-attenuating inversion recovery) MRI scan shows typical findings in progressive supranuclear palsy (one of the Parkinson plus syndromes) with prominent midbrain atrophy, resulting in the hummingbird sign, in addition to atrophy of the upper tectal plate.

Title: Proptosis Due to Meningioma
Description: This photo shows a woman's slightly bulging left eye (proptosis), caused by a meningioma.

Title: Proximal Femoral Metastatic Disease with Failed Surgical Management
Description: This image shows a failed surgical management of a metastatic brwww lesion requiring a second operation.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and David M. Joyce, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Proximal Femoral Metastatic Disease with Failed Surgical Management

Title: Proximal Fibular Fracture
Description: The proximal fibula may be fractured (called a Maisonneuve fracture—shown here), when the medial malleolus is fractured, the ankle mortise (the joint between the tibia and the talus) is open, and the distal fibula is not fractured.

Title: Proximal Humerus Fracture
Description: This fracture involves the surgical neck. Because there is no significant displacement or angulation >45°, it is a one-part fracture.

Title: Proximal Hypospadias
Description: In this image, the arrow is pointing to the meatus.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Drs. Ronald Rabinowitz and Jimena Cubillos.

Title: Prune-Belly Syndrome
Description: This photo shows a patient who has prune-belly syndrome with the characteristic wrinkled appearance of the abdominal wall. A patent urachus is also shown at center.

Title: Pseudofolliculitis Barbae
Description: Pseudofolliculitis barbae is a foreign body reaction caused by skin penetration of hairs before they leave the hair follicle or after they leave the follicle and curve back into the skin. It is most noticeable, typically with papules and pustules around the beard and neck, and is primarily a condition of Black men.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pseudopolyps
Description: Pseudopolyps are areas of hyperplastic, inflamed mucosa that project above the mucosal surface.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Drs. Aaron E. Walfish and Rafael A. Ching Companioni.

Title: Pseudoxanthoma Elasticum (Angioid Streaks)
Description: Red retinal blood vessels are seen entering the retina from the yellow optic disc (center right). Beneath these blood vessels are dark, wavy, branching striae called angioid streaks (arrows).

Title: Pseudoxanthoma Elasticum (Skin Manifestations)
Description: This photo shows yellowish papules along the side of the neck in a patient with pseudoxanthoma elasticum, giving a "plucked chicken" appearance.

Title: Psoriasis (Dactylitis)
Description: This photo shows sausage-shaped deformities (dactylitis) of the fingers in a patient with psoriatic arthritis. Also apparent are pitting of the nails and salmon patches on the skin.

Title: Psoriasis (Elbows)
Description: This photo shows erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales on the extensor surface of the elbows. This appearance is typical of plaque psoriasis.

Title: Psoriasis (Elbows)
Description: This photo shows erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales on the extensor surface of the elbows. This appearance is typical of plaque psoriasis.

Title: Psoriasis (Fingers)
Description: This photo shows patches of scaly, erythematous, and thick skin, and discolored, crumbly nails.

Title: Psoriasis (Plaques)
Description: This image shows psoriatic plaques. Plaques may look violaceous in patients with dark skin tones, but key features such as scaling and distribution (eg, on extensor elbows, trunk, legs, and periumbilical area) are consistent across all skin tones.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Psoriasis (Scalp)
Description: This photo shows red, flaky, and thickened skin on the scalp of a patient with psoriasis.

Title: Psoriasis (Scalp)
Description: This photo shows red, flaky, and thickened skin on the scalp of a patient with psoriasis.

Title: Psoriasis Plaque
Description: Psoriasis typically manifests as plaques covered with thick, silvery, shiny scales. Plaques are elevated, palpable lesions > 10 mm in diameter.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pterygium
Description: A pterygium is a benign conjunctival lesion (here a triangular whitish/vascular growth) on the sclera that extends onto the cornea and can affect vision.

Title: Pterygium of the Nail
Description: This photo shows dorsal pterygium of several nails accompanied by atrophy of the nails.

Title: Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (Chest X-ray)
Description: Chest x-ray shows bilateral, predominantly basilar, opacities.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Lynch III J, Myers J. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (CT Scan)
Description: High-resolution CT shows ground-glass opacification and thickened intralobular structures and septa in polygonal shapes ("crazy-paving").
Copyright: Image courtesy of Talmadge E. King, MD.

Title: Pulmonary Edema
Description: This upright chest x-ray demonstrates several of the characteristic features of acute pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure, including cardiac dilatation, pulmonary congestion with interstitial edema, and vascular redistribution to the upper lobe vessels, as well as pleural effusions. LV = left ventricle.
Copyright: Courtesy of Wada T: Basic and Advanced Visual Cardiology. Illustrated Case Report Multi-Media Approach. Philadelphia, Lea & Febiger, 1991; with permission.) By permission of the publisher. From O'Connor C, Tuman K. In Atlas of Anesthesia: Cardiothoracic Anesthesia. Edited by R Miller (series editor) and JG Reeves. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1999.
TopicName: Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure AHRF, ARDS

TopicLocations.TopicName: Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure AHRF, ARDS

Title: Pulmonary Embolism (Chest CTA)
Description: The images show bilateral pulmonary embolism on chest computed tomographic angiography. The arrows point to the filling defects (emboli).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Victor F. Tapson, MD.

Title: Pulmonary Embolism (Ventilation-Perfusion Scan)
Description: The ventilation-perfusion scan demonstrates high probability for acute pulmonary embolism. The ventilation is relatively unaffected, while the perfusion images show large defects, particularly in the left lung.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Victor F. Tapson, MD.

Title: Pulmonary Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
Description: High-resolution CT through the upper lobes shows nodules and irregular air-density cysts, usually in the upper and mid-lung regions. These findings are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis in a patient with a history of smoking.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Harold R. Collard, MD.

Title: Pulmonary Pseudotumor
Description: Opacity in the right lower lung field (arrow) resembles a solid mass but was caused by fluid in the major fissure in a patient with heart failure.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Huggins J, Sahn S. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Punctum Plug
Description: Plugging of the nasolacrimal punctum (arrow) is one strategy for decreasing tear drainage off the eye surface as a treatment for keratoconjunctivitis sicca.

Title: Pustular Psoriasis (Feet)
Description: This image shoes widespread pustules on the soles of a patient with erythrodermic pustular psoriasis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pyknodysostosis (Hands)
Description: This photo shows short, broad hands and dysplasia of terminal phalanges (particularly of the thumbs) in a man with pyknodysostosis.

Title: Pyknodysostosis (Receding Chin)
Description: This photo shows a receding chin in a boy with pyknodysostosis.

Title: Pyoderma Faciale (Pregnancy-Related)
Description: This image shows pyoderma faciale with erythematous plaques, papules, and pustules that occurred during pregnancy.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Pyoderma Faciale (Rosacea Fulminans)
Description: This photo shows pyoderma faciale with erythematous plaques, papules, pustules, and confluent nodules.

Title: Pyoderma Gangrenosum Bullous (Atypical) Subtype
Description: This photo shows multiple eroded bullae forming superficial lesions on a patient's arm.

Title: Pyoderma Gangrenosum Ulcerative (Classic) Subtype
Description: This photo shows an ulcerated lesion with a necrotic base and raised dusky to violaceous border on the leg.

Title: Pyoderma Gangrenosum Vegetative (Superficial Granulomatous Pyoderma) Subtype
Description: This photo shows a single superficial ulcer without raised borders or necrotic base.

TopicLocations.Title: Pyoderma Gangrenosum Vegetative (Superficial Granulomatous Pyoderma) Subtype

Title: Pyogenic Granuloma (Lip)
Description: This photo shows an erythematous rounded lesion consistent with pyogenic granuloma.

Title: Pyogenic Granuloma (Nail)
Description: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign growth.

Title: Pyogenic Granuloma (Palm)
Description: A pyogenic granuloma manifests as a scarlet nodule composed of proliferating capillaries in an edematous stroma. The lesion tends to be friable and bleeds easily. It probably represents a vascular and fibrous response to injury.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Pyogenic Granuloma (Shoulder)
Description: This image shows recurrent, fleshy, scarlet, vascular nodules of pyogenic granulomas.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Radial Head Fracture
Description: The fracture line (marked in red here) is subtle and could be easily missed.
Copyright: DU CANE MEDICAL IMAGING LTD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Radial Ray Deficiency
Description: In the most severe form of radial ray deficiency, the radius is absent, as in this patient. The hand is angulated and deformed.

Title: Radiologic Features of Necrotizing Enterocolitis
Description: This image shows pneumatosis intestinalis (top, arrowheads) and portal vein gas (bottom, arrow).
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Langer J: Gastroenterology and Hepatology: Pediatric Gastrointestinal Problems. Edited by M Feldman (series editor) and PE Hyman. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1997.

Title: Ranula
Description: This photo shows a close-up of a ranula (center) in a person's mouth. Ranulas are mucoceles that occur in the floor of the mouth (generally larger than mucoceles that occur elsewhere in the oral cavity). The source of mucin content in ranulas is usually the sublingual gland (also occasionally from the submandibular gland duct).

Title: Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (Pauci-Immune)
Description: Pauci-immune disease is characterized by crescent formation with fibrinoid necrosis and negative immunofluorescence staining (Jones silver stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Raynaud Syndrome With Cyanosis
Description: Multiple fingertips are cyanotic.

Title: Raynaud Syndrome With Cyanosis
Description: Multiple fingertips are cyanotic.

Title: Raynaud Syndrome With Digital Gangrene
Description: Ulceration and gangrene affect the 2nd finger in this patient who had Raynaud syndrome secondary to systemic sclerosis.

Title: Raynaud Syndrome With Pallor
Description: Pallor develops irregularly in the fingers.

Title: Raynaud Syndrome With Pallor
Description: Pallor develops irregularly in the fingers.

Title: Reactive Arthritis (Nails)
Description: This image shows dystrophic nail changes resulting from reactive arthritis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Rectal Prolapse
Description: The rectum (center) has prolapsed through the anus.

Title: Recurrent Aspergilloma
Description: This CT scan shows the lungs of a person with a history of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis in the setting of asthma. After left upper lobectomy for aspergilloma, recurrent mycetoma developed at the left lung apex (arrow).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Paschalis Vergidis, MD, MSc.

Title: Red Blood Cell Clumping in Cold Agglutinin Disease
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

TopicLocations.Title: Red Blood Cell Clumping in Cold Agglutinin Disease

Title: Reflux Esophagitis
Description: Gastroesophageal reflux may cause esophagitis to manifest as distal esophageal erosions and ulcerations (arrows). Scarring may eventually lead to stricture.
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

Title: Reflux Nephropathy (Voiding Cystourethrogram)
Description: Voiding cystourethrography is performed by filling the bladder with radiocontrast material and observing for reflux under fluoroscopy, either during the phase of bladder filling or during micturition.

Title: Relapsing Polychondritis (Ear)
Description: The cartilaginous portion (pinna) of the ear is purplish red and swollen.

Title: Relatively Healthy Gums and Teeth
Description: The relatively healthy mouth depicted here shows some stain and calculus, but the gingivae are healthy: firm, tightly adapted to the teeth, and contoured to form fine interdental papillae.

Title: Renal Artery Stenosis (Digital Subtraction Angiography)
Description: The left image shows 90% stenosis at the origin of the left main renal artery on digital subtraction angiography. The right image shows complete resolution of stenosis after stent placement.
Copyright: Image provided by Jan N. Basile, MD.

Title: Renal Artery Stenosis (Digital Subtraction Angiography)
Description: The left image shows 90% stenosis at the origin of the left main renal artery on digital subtraction angiography. The right image shows complete resolution of stenosis after stent placement.
Copyright: Image provided by Jan N. Basile, MD.

Title: Renal Atheroembolism
Description: Renal atheroemboli dissolve during tissue fixation, leaving biconcave needle-shaped clefts in vessels 100 to 200 microns in diameter (Jones silver stain, ×200).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Renal Cell Carcinoma (Contrast CT Scan)
Description: This image shows an example of a renal cell carcinoma of the right kidney (arrow) showing a poorly enhancing tumor.

Title: Renal Cortical Necrosis
Description: Renal cortical necrosis is characterized histologically by necrosis of glomeruli and tubules. Necrosis in this biopsy specimen is manifest by small nuclei and ghostlike outlines of cells (periodic acid-Schiff stain, ×400).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Renovascular Hypertension (Magnetic Resonance Angiography)
Description: Magnetic resonance angiography demonstrates severe stenosis at the origin of the left main renal artery.
Copyright: Image provided by Jan N. Basile, MD.

Title: Retinal Detachment
Description: The area of retinal detachment in this photo is seen at the center. Symptoms include blurry vision, light flashes (photopsias), and floaters.

Title: Retinitis (CMV)
Description: Features of cytomegalovirus retinitis include cotton wool spots, intraretinal hemorrhage, retinal infarction, and arteritis. The diagnosis is presumptive based on characteristic retinal findings in an immunosuppressed patient.

Title: Retinitis (HSV)
Description: Acute retinal necrosis results from a herpes virus infection. It causes a rapidly progressive retinal necrosis (areas of whitening) with an occlusive vasculitis. Without prompt treatment, it results in severe vision loss over days.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Sunir Garg, MD.

Title: Retinitis (Toxoplasmosis)
Description: This image shows a retinal scar (upper center) caused by toxoplasmosis infection.

Title: Retinitis (Toxoplasmosis)
Description: This image shows a retinal scar (upper center) caused by toxoplasmosis infection.

Title: Retinitis Pigmentosa
Description: The most characteristic funduscopic finding in retinitis pigmentosa is hyperpigmentation in a bone-spicule configuration. Other findings may include arteriolar narrowing, cystoid macular edema, and a waxy yellow disk surface.

Title: Retracted Nipple
Description: This photo shows a close-up of a retracted or inverted nipple of the brwww in an adult female patient. This condition may be a clue to brwww cancer, or it may not be due to any underlying disease.

Title: Retropharyngeal Abscess
Description: This lateral x-ray of a child shows marked swelling anterior to the cervical vertebrae caused by a retropharyngeal abscess.
Copyright: Image provided by Clarence T. Sasaki, MD.

Title: Rheumatoid Nodule (Hand)
Description: This photo shows a rheumatoid nodule over the metacarpal joint of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis.

Title: Rheumatoid Nodules (Foot)
Description: This photo shows rheumatoid nodules on the sole of the foot in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis.

Title: Rheumatoid Nodules (Ulna)
Description: Subcutaneous rheumatoid nodules (arrow) commonly form over pressure points as in this patient with olecranon bursitis. The nodules may be within subcutaneous tissue overlying the bursae or may be subperiosteal to the extensor surface of the ulna.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Matteson E, Mason T: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis
Description: This photo shows tissue necrosis of the orbit in this person with rhinocerebral mucormycosis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Thomas F. Sellers, Emory University, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Rhinophyma of Rosacea
Description: This photo shows rhinophyma, characterized by thickened skin, nodules, and anatomical enlargement, in a patient with rosacea.

Title: Rib Anatomy
Description: The neurovascular bundle located at the lower edge of the rib includes the intercostal vein, artery, and nerve.

Title: Rib Fractures
Description: This x-ray of the chest shows multiple fractures to the right ribs (seen on left).

Title: Rib Fractures in an Infant
Description: This x-ray shows rib fractures (highlighted in red) in an infant, suggestive of child abuse.

Title: Ring Sideroblasts in Sideroblastic Anemia
Description: In sideroblastic anemia, ring sideroblasts are seen in bone marrow. Ring sideroblasts are erythroid precursors whose mitochondria (located around the nucleus) are loaded with nonheme iron.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Rings and Strictures in Eosinophilic Esophagitis
Copyright: Image provided by Kristle Lynch, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Rings and Strictures in Eosinophilic Esophagitis

Title: Rocker-Bottom Feet in Trisomy 18
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Public Health Image Library.

Title: Rocket Launcher Technique
Description: For the rocket launcher technique, the practitioner stands on the side of the affected hip and faces the patient's feet. The dislocated hip and knee are flexed to 90°. The patient's hips are typically held down by a sheet or by a second practitioner. The practitioner squats, and the patient's knee is placed on the practitioner's shoulder. The patient's hip is adducted by pressing inward on the knee and is internally rotated by turning the foot out; the practitioner then gently applies traction to the femur by standing from the squat and pulling down on the patient's foot, using the practitioner's shoulder as a fulcrum.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
Description: Rocky Mountain spotted fever initially manifests as a blanching macular rash on the palms, wrists, soles, and ankles, then progresses proximally to the neck, face, buttocks, and trunk. The lesions darken and become maculopapular and then petechial.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Romaña Sign
Description: This image shows Romaña sign in a child who has Chagas disease.
Copyright: CDC image courtesy of the WHO/TDR Image Library.

Title: Rosacea
Description: Rosacea is characterized by facial skin changes, including flushing, telangiectasias, erythema, papules, pustules, and, in severe cases, rhinophyma.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Roseola Infantum (Rash)
Description: This photo shows a maculopapular exanthem on the chest, abdomen, face, and extremities after defervescence in an infant with roseola infantum.

Title: Rubella
Description: Rubella manifests as a diffuse rash comprising discrete, pinpoint macules that do not coalesce.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
TopicName: Overview of Rickettsial and Related Infections

Title: Rubella (Lymphadenopathy)
Description: This image shows enlarged posterior auricular lymph nodes, which are commonly seen in rubella infection.

Title: Rubella (Rash Distribution)
Description: The rash of rubella is similar in distribution to that of measles (rubeola) but it is less intensely red and confluent.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Saber Shins
Description: Osteoperiostitis of the tibia leads to characteristic saber shins in this patient with congenital syphilis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Robert Sumpter via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Saccular Aneurysm
Description: This magnetic resonance angiogram shows a small saccular aneurysm of the horizontal right middle cerebral artery (arrow).
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Ritter A, Hayman L, Charletta D. In Atlas of Cerebrovascular Disease. Edited by PB Gorelick and MA Sloan. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1996.

Title: Saddle Nose Deformity in Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
Description: This photo shows collapse of the nasal bridge due to nasal chondritis.

Title: Sagittal Craniosynostosis
Description: This photo shows an infant with sagittal craniosynostosis causing a narrow and long skull (dolichocephaly).

Title: Salmonella (Skin Lesion)
Description: Osteomyelitis can be caused by Salmonella. The infection shown occurred in a patient with sickle cell disease.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Thomas F. Sellers, Emory University, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Dacryocystitis)
Description: This image shows dacryocystitis manifesting as inflammation of the palpebral lobe of the lacrimal glands in both upper eyelids in a patient with sarcoidosis.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Histopathology)
Description: In this image, a lung biopsy of a patient with sarcoidosis shows granulomas along the bronchovascular bundle (hematoxylin and eosin stain, low magnification; left) and sarcoid granuloma with giant multinucleated giant cells in center of granulomas (high magnification; right).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Birendra P. Sah, MD, FCCP.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Iris Granuloma)
Description: This photo shows iris granulomas (visible as white spots), which are also called papillary margin nodules or Koeppe nodules.

Description: This photo shows violaceous plaques on the nose of a patient with sarcoidosis.

Description: This image shows skin nodules in a patient with sarcoidosis.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Papular)
Description: This image shows multiple papules on the lips of a patient with sarcoidosis.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Skin Findings)
Description: This photo shows erythematous facial plaques in a patient with sarcoidosis.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Stage I)
Description: Bilateral hilar adenopathy in stage I sarcoidosis.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tanoue L, Elias J. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Stage II)
Description: Bilateral hilar adenopathy with interstitial opacities in stage II sarcoidosis.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tanoue L, Elias J. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Stage III)
Description: Diffuse interstitial opacities without hilar adenopathy in stage III sarcoidosis.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tanoue L, Elias J. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Sarcoidosis (Stage IV)
Description: Severe, diffuse fibrosis with hilar adenopathy and cystic changes of the upper lobes in stage IV sarcoidosis.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From: Tanoue L, Elias J. In Bone's Atlas of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. Edited by J Crapo. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Scabies
Description: The child in this photo has excoriations and crusted lesions clustered around the flexor crease of the wrist. These findings are typical of scabies. Burrows are present as 3- to 4-mm crusted lesions in the wrist creases and elsewhere.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Scaphoid Fracture
Description: This scaphoid fracture is visible as a lucency on plain x-ray.

Title: Scarlet Fever
Description: The classic scarlet fever rash initially appears as tiny red papules on the chest and abdomen. Papules may then spread over the body. The rash resembles sunburn, feels like rough sandpaper, and lasts about 2 to 5 days.

Title: Schistocytes (Red Blood Cell Fragments)
Description: Schistocytes (see arrows) are damaged red blood cells, which may occur in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (including disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura/hemolytic-uremic syndrome, and valvular hemolysis).
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Scleritis (Necrotizing)
Description: Necrotizing scleritis is characterized by conjunctival ulceration with scleral necrosis. The blue to grayish area is the choroid, visible where there has been severe scleral loss. The smaller, white, triangular area is an avascular area that has not thinned.

Title: Sclerosing Panniculitis
Description: This photo shows painful inflammation of the subcutaneous fat in the lower extremity resulting from lipodermatosclerosis, which can be confused with cellulitis.

Title: Sclerosteosis (Head and Facial Features)
Description: This photo shows a patient's grossly deformed head with macrocephaly, hypertelorism, a broad, flat nasal bridge with saddle nose deformity, and prominent mandibles.

Title: Sclerosteosis (X-Ray)
Description: This x-ray shows marked thickening and sclerosis of the skull and whole facial bones.

Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Copyright: Image courtesy of Zubair Malik, MD.

Description: Images courtesy of Drs. Ronald Rabinowitz and Jimena Cubillos.

Title: Scrub Typhus
Description: Scrub typhus (tsutsugamushi disease) manifests as an eschar at the site of a chigger bite (top). A diffuse macular rash follows the appearance of the eschar (bottom).
Copyright: Images courtesy of Yoshiki Taniguchi, MD. From Taniguchi, Y: Eschar, fever, and rash in a 43-year-old man. Dermatology Online Journal 3(2), 1997.

Title: Seborrheic Keratosis
Description: Seborrheic keratoses are benign pigmented lesions. Cause is unknown. They tend to develop in older adults and have a stuck-on appearance with a verrucous, velvety, waxy, scaly, or crusted surface.

Title: Secondary Herpes Simplex
Description: This is a close-up of a herpes simplex lesion (also known as a cold sore or fever blister) of the lower lip.

Title: Senile Purpura
Description: Senile purpura is a bruised area of the skin that usually occurs on the arms and hands.

Description: This coronal CT scan shows deviation of the nasal septum to the left (arrow).

Title: Serous Otitis Media

Title: Skin Lesion (Bullae)
Description: Bullae are fluid-filled blisters > 10 mm in diameter. Bullous pemphigoid (pictured) is characterized by eruptions of tense bullae on normal-appearing or erythematous skin in older adults.

Title: Skin Lesion (Lichenification)
Description: Lichenification is thickening of the skin with accentuation of normal skin markings; it is a result of chronic scratching or rubbing, which in this patient occurred during the chronic phase of atopic dermatitis.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Skin Lesion (Papule)
Description: Papules are elevated, usually palpable lesions < 10 mm in diameter. Lichen planus (pictured) may manifest with a papular rash.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Skin Lesion (Pustule)
Description: Pustules are elevated, usually yellow-topped lesions that contain pus. Scattered pustules appear on the face of this person with acne.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Skin Lesion (Scales)
Description: Scales are heaped-up accumulations of horny epithelium. Scaling is a characteristic feature of many dermatophytoses, including tinea capitis, resulting in the large bald patches. In this image, scale is especially noticeable at the nape of the neck.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Skin Lesion (Urticaria)
Description: Urticaria (wheals or hives) are migratory, elevated, pruritic, erythematous lesions caused by local dermal edema.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Skin Lesion (Vesicle)
Description: Vesicles are small fluid-filled blisters < 10 mm in diameter. Dermatitis herpetiformis (pictured) typically manifests as crops of vesicles.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Skin Manifestations in Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1)
Description: This photo shows axillary freckle-like macules in NF1.

Title: Skin Tags
Description: Skin tags are the multiple flesh-colored and pedunculated lesions on the neck.

Title: Skull Fracture
Description: This x-ray of the skull shows a fracture of the lambdoid suture.
Copyright: Living Art Enterprises, LLC /SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE)
Description: Klein lines are drawn on the superior border of the femoral neck in this patient with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) of the right hip. Note that the femoral head is below the Klein line on the affected right side, whereas a significant portion of the femoral head is above the Klein line on the unaffected left side.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Campbell R Jr: Current Orthopedic Diagnosis and Treatment. Edited by JD Heckman, RC Schenck, and A Agarwal. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2002.

Title: Small-Bowel Follow-Through of Crohn Disease Showing String Sign
Description: The left image shows the spasm obliterates the cobblestone pattern of the terminal ileum, which is best seen in double contrast in the right image.

TopicLocations.Title: Small-Bowel Follow-Through of Crohn Disease Showing String Sign

Title: Small-Bowel Obstruction (CT Scan)
Description: In this CT scan, the small bowel is dilated and filled with air and fluid. Oral contrast is seen in some of the loops but has not traveled down to the distal small bowel. Note the collapsed cecum and sigmoid colon (arrows). A specific point of obstruction (transition point) cannot always be seen on CT, but the dilated proximal bowel and collapsed distal bowel are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.
Copyright: Image provided by Parswa Ansari, MD.

Title: Small-Bowel Obstruction (Supine X-Ray)
Description: This supine abdominal x-ray shows obstruction of the small bowel. Note the dilated loops of small bowel.
Copyright: Image provided by Parswa Ansari, MD.

Title: Small-Bowel Obstruction (Upright X-Ray)
Description: This upright abdominal x-ray shows obstruction of the small bowel. Note the multiple air-fluid levels.
Copyright: Image provided by Parswa Ansari, MD.

Title: Small-Plaque Parapsoriasis
Description: This image shows small-plaque parapsoriasis (lesions < 5 cm in diameter), which is benign.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Susan Lindsley via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Smallpox
Description: Smallpox (variola) causes diffusely distributed vesiculopustular lesions. Lesions are usually denser on the face and extremities than on the trunk. Unlike chickenpox, smallpox lesions are all at a similar stage of development on a given body part and are deeply embedded.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Snakebite Wound
Description: A blood-filled blister caused by a cottonmouth (water moccasin) bite.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Thomas Arnold, MD.

Title: Solar Urticaria
Description: This photo shows solar urticaria in a woman who had been wearing a tank top. These hives appear within minutes of sun exposure.

Title: Somatostatin Receptor Scintigraphy (Octreotide Scan) Showing Gastrinoma Primary Tumor Site and Metastasis
Description: This image shows very intense uptake of primary tumor (arrow) and liver metastasis (1) of a pancreas carcinoid. 2 = spleen; 3 = kidney; 4 = liver.

TopicLocations.Title: Somatostatin Receptor Scintigraphy (Octreotide Scan) Showing Gastrinoma Primary Tumor Site and Metastasis

Title: Southern Copperhead
Copyright: Image courtesy of CDC/James Gathany via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: SPECT in Recent-Onset Angina
Description: Stress and rest images from single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) of a 52-year-old man with recent-onset angina. Images obtained during stress (rows of images or polar maps denoted Str or Stress) show a large area of ischemia in the territory fed by the left anterior descending (LAD) artery that is absent at rest (rows of images or polar maps denoted Rst or Rest). Angiography confirmed a 95 to 99% occlusion involving the bifurcation of the LAD at the first diagonal branch. The stress images show less uptake (more purple or dull) than the bright areas at rest.
Copyright: Image provided by James R. Corbett, MD.

Title: Speculum Examination in Bacterial Vaginosis
Description: Bacterial vaginosis has a characteristic gray discharge.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Spitzer M, Mann M. In Atlas of Clinical Gynecology: Gynecologic Pathology. Edited by M Stenchever (series editor) and B Goff. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1998.

Title: Speculum Examination in Vaginitis
Description: Normal findings, trichomonal vaginitis with frothy discharge, and candidal vaginitis with thick, white discharge are shown (left to right).
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Spitzer M, Mann M. In Atlas of Clinical Gynecology: Gynecologic Pathology. Edited by M Stenchever (series editor) and B Goff. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1998. (Courtesy of the International Society for the Study of Vulvar Disease, from the collection of the late Dr. Herman Gardner.)

Title: Spherocytes
Description: The presence of abundant spherocytes in the peripheral blood smear suggests either hereditary spherocytosis (HS) or autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Spherocytes are spherical red blood cells without an area of central pallor and are usually slightly smaller in size than the average red cell. Spherocytes have increased osmotic fragility (because of decreased distensibility associated with reduced surface membrane area) in hypotonic saline, and this test (osmotic fragility test) is positive in HS and in AIHA. The direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test distinguishes between them; the result is positive in AIHA and negative in HS.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Spider Angioma
Description: Spider angiomas (nevus araneus) are small, bright red spots that are surrounded by tiny blood vessels (capillaries), which resemble spider legs. After releasing pressure sufficient to blanch them, they refill from the central area. They are normal in many healthy people. They commonly develop in women who are pregnant or use oral contraceptives and in people who have cirrhosis of the liver.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Spider Angioma
Description: Spider angiomas (nevus araneus) are small, bright red spots that are surrounded by tiny blood vessels (capillaries), which resemble spider legs. After releasing pressure sufficient to blanch them, they refill from the central area. They are normal in many healthy people. They commonly develop in women who are pregnant or use oral contraceptives and in people who have cirrhosis of the liver.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Spiral Fracture of the Distal Femur
Description: This x-ray of the distal femur shows a lucency with a component parallel to the long axis of the bone, indicating a spiral fracture.

TopicLocations.Title: Spiral Fracture of the Distal Femur

Title: Splinter Hemorrhage
Description: Splinter hemorrhages are small linear hemorrhages under the fingernails.
Copyright: Image courtesy of CDC/Dr. Thomas F. Sellers via the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Public Health Image Library.

Title: Spondylolisthesis
Description: This x-ray shows grade 1 spondylolisthesis of L5 on S1. The black arrow shows the posterior border of L5, which subluxes anterior to S1. The red arrow points to the spondylolysis (defect in the pars interarticularis).

Title: Sporotrichosis
Description: This photo shows cutaneous nodules in a lymphangitic (sporotrichoid) distribution over the dorsum of the right hand.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Sporotrichosis (Abscess)
Description: Sporotrichosis starts as a small papule or subcutaneous nodule that may ulcerate or necrose. The infection spreads lymphatically. If untreated, diffuse erythema, ulcers, and abscesses may develop as is seen in this example of severe bacterial superinfection.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Lucille Georg via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Sporotrichosis (Nodules)
Description: Sporotrichosis starts as a small papule or subcutaneous nodule that may ulcerate or necrose.

Title: Sporotrichosis (Papule)
Description: Sporotrichosis starts as a small papule or subcutaneous nodule that may ulcerate or necrose.

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: This erythematous, irregular plaque on an extremity was diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma on biopsy.

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: This photo shows a hyperkeratotic skin-colored nodule arising on a sun-exposed area consistent with cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: This squamous cell carcinoma on the lip is highly keratinized; not all squamous cell carcinomas of the lip are as highly keratinized.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Gregory L. Wells, MD.

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Description: The appearance of squamous cell carcinoma is variable. These hyperpigmented, scaly lesions on the earlobe were diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma on biopsy.

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Gingival Lesions)
Description: Gingival examination of this patient showed evidence of squamous cell carcinoma. Imaging studies showed invasion of the mandible.

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma in Situ (Multiple Lesions)
Description: This photo shows lesions on the legs of a female patient with squamous cell carcinoma in situ.

TopicLocations.Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma in Situ (Multiple Lesions)

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma in Situ (Shin)
Description: This photo shows a reddish-brown and scaly lesion consistent with squamous cell carcinoma in situ.

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
Description: Squamous cell carcinoma typically manifests as an ulcerated, ragged mass compromising the lumen of the esophagus.
Copyright: Images provided by David M. Martin, MD.

TopicLocations.Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus

Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Mandible
Description: This image of a mandible invaded by squamous cell carcinoma shows a soft tissue mass (arrowhead) and bone destruction (arrow).

TopicLocations.Title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Mandible

Title: Squamous Papilloma – Ordinary Wart
Description: This example of an oral squamous papilloma is an ordinary wart (verruca vulgaris), appearing as a raised, rounded, flesh-colored lesion on the surface of the tongue.

Title: Squamous Papilloma of the Tongue
Description: This photo shows a wart appearing as a pedunculated papilloma (exophytic growth, cauliflower-like) on the underside of the tongue. HPV can be a cause.

Title: Stage 1 Pressure Injury (Buttocks)
Description: This photo of a stage 1 pressure injury shows nonblanchable redness but no break in the skin.
Copyright: Photo from Gordian Medical, Inc. dba American Medical Technologies; used with permission.

Title: Stage 2 Pressure Injury
Description: This patient has a stage 2 pressure injury on the upper right buttock (arrow). There is loss of epidermis and an erythematous base. Subcutaneous tissue is not exposed. Note surrounding areas of stage 1 pressure injury (for an example, see arrowhead) with nonblanching erythema over intact epidermis.

Title: Stage 3 Pressure Injury (Base of Spine)
Description: This photo of a stage 3 pressure injury shows subcutaneous tissue but no muscle or bone.

Title: Stage 3 Pressure Injury (Foot)
Description: This photo of a stage 3 pressure injury shows full thickness skin loss but no exposure of muscle or bone.

Title: Stage 4 Pressure Injury (Knee)
Description: This photo of a stage 4 pressure injury shows visible deep structures, such as tendon and joint.
Copyright: Photo from Gordian Medical, Inc. dba American Medical Technologies; used with permission.

Title: Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (Adult)
Description: This image shows staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome with superficial skin blistering caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection. This syndrome is rare in adults but can occur in people who are immunocompromised or who have renal failure or another chronic disease.

Title: Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (Infant)
Description: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is epidermolysis caused by a staphylococcal toxin. Findings include erythema with overlying desquamation in sheets, particularly in the intertriginous area of the groin and axillae. Often there is also perioral peeling.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (Infant)
Description: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is epidermolysis caused by a staphylococcal toxin. Findings include erythema with overlying desquamation in sheets, particularly in the intertriginous area of the groin and axillae. Often there is also perioral peeling.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (Leg)
Description: This photo shows the leg of a patient with all three stages of the infection: erythema (at center), bullae (left), and desquamation (right).

Title: Staphylococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome
Description: Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome causes a diffuse erythematous rash. Later in the course of the disease, the rash desquamates, especially on the palms and soles.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Stasis Dermatitis (Chronic Changes)
Description: Chronic stasis dermatitis may appear as fibrotic skin thickening and hyperpigmentation. The changes are characteristic in both light-skinned (top) and dark-skinned (bottom) people, here appearing more pronounced in the bottom photo.
Copyright: Images provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Description: This photo shows a child with esotropia where the child's left eye turns medially towards the right eye.

Title: Strawberry Tongue
Description: This tongue is erythematous. Characteristics of strawberry tongue are sloughing of the filiform papillae (caused by the systemic inflammatory process) and persistence of the fungiform papillae, which appear as the seeds of the strawberry. Strawberry tongue is not specific to Kawasaki disease and multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C); it may also be present in streptococcal and staphylococcal toxin-mediated disease.

Title: Strawberry Tongue (Child)
Description: This tongue is erythematous with prominent papillation.

Title: Strawberry Tongue (Child)
Description: This tongue is erythematous with prominent papillation.

Title: Strep Pharyngitis
Description: Hyperemia and tonsillar exudate in a patient diagnosed with sore throat. Sore throat, fever, and tender cervical adenitis were also present in this patient.

Title: Streptococcal Cellulitis
Description: This photo shows the focal erythema and swelling, usually accompanied by warmth and tenderness, characteristic of focal cellulitis. Note the clinician has marked the border of the cellulitis with a pen, to facilitate recognition of spread or resolution.

The clinician has marked the border of the cellulitis with a pen, to facilitate recognition of spread or resolution. Note the line of redness extending up the thigh due to lymphangitis.

Description: This photo shows a superficial spreading melanoma with features of asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, and raised, darker regions with black and blue spots.

Description: Swan neck deformity is characterized by extension at proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion at distal interphalangeal joint.

Title: Synovial Chondromatosis
Description: This x-ray of the knee shows multiple calcified joint bodies both in front of and in back of the joint (arrows), which is typical of synovial chondromatosis.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Syphilis (Gumma)
Description: This photo shows a gumma on the leg of a patient with tertiary (late) syphilis. A gumma is a mass of inflamed tissue.

Title: Syphilis—Secondary (Back)
Description: Secondary syphilis mimics many other dermatoses, causing a diffuse rash that may be macular, papular, or pustular, with discrete or confluent lesions.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Syphilis—Secondary (Body)
Description: Secondary syphilis mimics many other dermatoses, causing a diffuse rash that may be macular, papular, or pustular, with discrete or confluent lesions.

Title: Syphilis—Secondary (Soles)

Title: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (Malar Rash)
Description: This raised, erythematous, acute malar rash manifests in light-exposed areas (photosensitive distribution). This butterfly pattern includes the bridge of the nose, the malar areas, and the sun-exposed areas over the eyebrows. Importantly, the nasolabial folds are spared.

Title: Systemic Sclerosis of the Chest and Shoulders
Description: In this image, bound-down taut skin throughout the chest also extends over the shoulders bilaterally, leading to a loss of range of movement of the shoulders.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Marder W, Lath V, Crofford L, Lowe L, McCune WJ: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: Target Cells
Description: Target cells (thin RBCs with a central dot of hemoglobin; arrow) are due to an imbalance between the volume of the cell and its hemoglobin content and characterize thalassemia, other hemoglobinopathies (eg, hemoglobin C disease and hemoglobin S-C disease) but may also occur after splenectomy and in liver disease.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

Title: Target Lesions
Description: Target lesions (sometimes called iris lesions) manifest as annular lesions with a violaceous center and pink halo separated by a pale ring. Such lesions, which are typical of erythema multiforme, are distributed symmetrically.
Copyright: Photo provided by Robert MacNeal, MD.

Title: Tarsal Tunnel 1
Description: This intraoperative photograph of the right medial ankle shows the surgical dissection exposing the flexor retinaculum which overlays the tibial nerve and posterior tibial artery within the tarsal tunnel.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of James C. Connors, DPM.

Title: Tarsal Tunnel 2
Description: This intraoperative photograph of the right medial ankle shows the surgical dissection through the flexor retinaculum exposing the tibial nerve in the tarsal tunnel.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of James C. Connors, DPM.

Title: Tay-Sachs Disease (Cherry-Red Spot)
Description: All patients with Tay-Sachs disease have a cherry-red spot, easily observable by a physician using an ophthalmoscope, in the back of their eyes.
Copyright: RALPH C. EAGLE, JR./SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY
TopicName: Tay Sachs Disease and Sandhoff Disease

Title: Telangiectasia on the Face
Description: Although telangiectasias are usually asymptomatic, many people consider even the smallest telangiectasias cosmetically unacceptable.

Title: Telangiectasias
Description: Telangiectasias are small, dilated blood vessels; they are most often idiopathic.
Copyright: Photo provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Tendon Xanthomas
Description: Tendon xanthomas (arrow) are diagnostic of familial hypercholesterolemia.

Title: Tenosynovial Giant Cell Tumor
Description: This MRI of the knee shows tenosynovial giant cell tumor in the lining of knee joint (arrows).
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael J. Joyce, MD, and Hakan Ilaslan, MD.

Title: Tension Pneumothorax
Description: In this image, a pneumothorax is visible in the right hemithorax, where, in the periphery, there are no lung markings. A shift of the heart and mediastinum toward the left side can cause tension pneumothorax physiology. Tension pneumothorax, however, should be diagnosed clinically and not await radiographic confirmation.
Copyright: DU CANE MEDICAL IMAGING LTD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Tension Pneumothorax
Description: In this image, a pneumothorax is visible in the right hemithorax, where, in the periphery, there are no lung markings. A shift of the heart and mediastinum toward the left side can cause tension pneumothorax physiology. Tension pneumothorax, however, should be diagnosed clinically and not await radiographic confirmation.
Copyright: DU CANE MEDICAL IMAGING LTD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Terry Nails
Description: In this image of Terry nails, almost all of the nail is opaque white except for a narrow brown-to-pink band at the distal edge of the nail.

Title: Testicular Cancer
Description: This photo shows the enlarged, painless left testis of a male patient with a seminoma.

Title: Tests for Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip
Description: These illustrations show the Barlow maneuver (right) and Ortolani maneuver (left), which are used to diagnose developmental dysplasia of the hip in infants. If the hip can be dislocated using the Barlow maneuver, the test is considered positive. The Ortolani maneuver is positive if an already dislocated hip can be reduced using the maneuver.

Title: Thalamic Intracerebral Hemorrhage
Description: This CT scan shows a hemorrhage in the thalamus. Intracerebral hemorrhages commonly occur in the thalamus and within the basal ganglia.

Title: Thin Basement Membrane Lesion
Description: Diffuse attenuation of the glomerular basement membrane (thickness < 250 nm) is seen on transmission electron microscopy (×3000).
Copyright: Image provided by Agnes Fogo, MD, and the American Journal of Kidney Diseases' Atlas of Renal Pathology (see www.ajkd.org).

Title: Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm
Description: This CT scan shows a descending thoracic aorta aneurysm (white arrow).

Title: Thoracic Aortic Dissection (Stanford Type B)
Description: Axial image of dissection flap (white arrow) in descending thoracic aorta.

Title: Thrush
Description: Creamy white patches are seen inside the mouth and may bleed when scraped off. This finding is typical of thrush, which is caused by infection with Candida.

Title: Thyroid Eye Disease (CT Scans)
Description: In this image, axial and coronal CT scans show findings in thyroid eye disease. Bottom: The axial CT scan shows tendon-sparing enlargement of the medial rectus muscle, bilaterally. Top: The coronal CT scan shows enlargement of the inferior, superior, and medial rectus muscles more on the right than left.

Title: Tophaceous Gout in Fingers
Description: The top photo shows firm nodules, swelling, and serous drainage in the finger caused by tophaceous gout. The bottom photo shows tophaceous gout with flexion deformities in the hands, which can also be accompanied by destructive erosions of bone and cartilage in multiple joints.

Title: Tophi
Description: This image shows prominent tophaceous deposits in the prepatellar bursa of the right knee.

Title: Tophus with Erosion
Description: This photo shows large erosions caused by tophi involving the distal metatarsal and proximal phalanx of the great toe.

Title: Torus Fracture of the Finger
Description: Torus fractures may be visible only as subtle irregularities in bone cortex.

Description: A benign growth of the lingual aspect of the mandible is visible here on the left side of the patient's mouth.

Description: A benign growth of the lingual aspect of the mandible is visible here on the left side of the patient's mouth.

Title: Torus Palatinus
Description: Torus palatinus is a common bony hard mass that occurs along the midline of the hard palate (often bilaterally, as is visible here).

Title: Traction Diverticulum
Description: Traction diverticula are midesophageal outpouchings of mucosa and submucosa caused by motility disorders or by traction resulting from mediastinal processes. In this image, the diverticulum is to the right of the esophagus and gives the appearance of a double lumen.

Title: Tularemia
Description: In ulceroglandular tularemia, an inflamed papule appears on the finger or hand (top); it then rapidly becomes pustular and ulcerates, producing a clean ulcer crater with scanty, thin, colorless exudates (bottom).
Copyright: Images courtesy of CDC/Dr. Brachman (top) and CDC/Emory Univ.; Dr. Sellers (bottom) via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Turner Syndrome
Description: This image shows a 13-year-old girl with typical physical characteristics of Turner syndrome such as short stature, stocky build, broad chest with widely spaced nipples and lack of brwww development, and cubitus valgus.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Shulman D, Bercu B: Atlas of Clinical Endocrinology: Neuroendocrinology and Pituitary Disease. Edited by S Korenman (series editor) and ME Molitch. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2000.

Title: Typhoid Fever (Rose Spots)
Description: In about 10 to 20% of patients with typhoid fever, rose spots (discrete, pink, blanching lesions; arrows) appear in crops on the chest and abdomen, usually during the 2nd week of infection.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Charles N. Farmer, Armed Forces Institute of Pathology, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Tzanck Test
Description: With Tzanck testing, the base and sides of a vesicle are scraped with a scalpel, and the material is stained with Wright or Giemsa stain. Multinucleated giant cells are a sign of herpes simplex or herpes zoster infection.
Copyright: Photo courtesy of Joe Miller via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Ulcer of the Ileum in Crohn Disease
Description: This photo shows video capsule endoscopy of a characteristic aphthous ulcer of Crohn disease. The ulcer (arrow) is a small, central, white depression with a slightly elevated and erythematous border.

Title: Ulcerative Colitis
Description: The colonoscopic findings in ulcerative colitis shown here include edema, loss of vascularity, friable mucosa, and ulcers.

Title: Ultrasound of a Benign Ovarian Mass
Description: Ultrasound characteristics of this ovarian mass (indicated by an asterisk) suggest that the mass is benign. The mass is anechoic (suggesting absence of solid components), regular, well-circumscribed, and without wall thickening or excrescences.

Title: Ultrasound of a Brwww Lump (Cyst)

Title: Ultrasound of a Malignant Ovarian Mass
Description: In this ovarian mass, malignancy is suggested by the presence of echogenic solid components (indicated by arrows) within an otherwise anechoic cystic mass. A Doppler study shows flow within these solid components, confirming that they represent solid malignant components.

Title: Uveitis (Anterior)
Description: Anterior uveitis can cause redness, keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium (shown), as well as white blood cells and flare (protein) in the anterior chamber.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Sunir Garg, MD.

Title: Uveitis (Intermediate)
Description: In intermediate uveitis, aggregates of inflammatory cells may condense over the pars plana and look like snowballs; confluence of the so-called snowballs causes a classic snowbank appearance, visible (in this image, the white lining at the bottom) with an indirect ophthalmoscope.

Title: Vaccinia—Generalized
Description: Generalized vaccinia is diffusely distributed vaccinial lesions caused by hematogenous spread of the vaccinia virus after vaccination. Despite a possibly severe appearance, generalized vaccinia is usually benign.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Allen W. Mathies of the Immunization Branch of the California Emergency Preparedness Office (Calif/EPO) via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Vaccinia—Progressive (Deep Tissue Involvement)
Description: Progressive vaccinia is a nonhealing vesicular lesion that develops after smallpox vaccination and spreads broadly to involve skin other than the immunization site and deeply to involve bones and viscera. It occurs almost exclusively in vaccine recipients with an underlying defect in cell-mediated immunity.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Allen W. Mathies of the Immunization Branch of the California Emergency Preparedness Office (Calif/EPO) via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Vaccinia—Progressive (Skin Involvement Described as Vaccinia Necrosum)
Description: Progressive vaccinia is a nonhealing vesicular lesion that develops after smallpox vaccination and spreads broadly to involve skin other than the immunization site and deeply to involve bones and viscera. It occurs almost exclusively in vaccine recipients with an underlying defect in cell-mediated immunity.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Allen W. Mathies of the Immunization Branch of the California Emergency Preparedness Office (Calif/EPO) via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: VACTERL (Lower Extremity Limb Abnormalities)

Title: VACTERL (Upper Extremity Limb Abnormalities)

Copyright: Image courtesy of CDC/Dr. James W. Hanson via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: VACTERL (X-Ray Anomalies)
Description: This x-ray shows anomalies associated with VACTERL (vertebral anomalies, anal atresia, cardiac malformations, tracheoesophageal fistula, esophageal atresia, renal anomalies and radial aplasia, and limb anomalies) syndrome. Note the vertebral segmentation anomaly (white arrowhead), enteric tube coiled in the atretic proximal esophagus (black arrowhead), gas in the bowel consistent with esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula, and deformity of the left upper extremity.

Title: Vaginal Inclusion Cyst
Description: Vaginal inclusion cysts are usually small and asymptomatic.

Title: Ventriculography (LV Gram)
Description: A catheter (center) is inserted into the left ventricle (LV). Contrast is then injected into the LV under fluoroscopy and the ejection fraction is visually estimated.

Title: Vernal Conjunctivitis
Description: This photo shows vernal conjunctivitis, a form of allergic conjunctivitis in which hard, flat, closely packed, pale pink to grayish cobblestone papillae (arrow) develop in the upper tarsal conjunctiva.

Title: Vertebral Compression Fracture (X-Ray)
Description: This lateral spine x-ray shows loss of height and anterior wedging due to a vertebral compression fracture.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Viral Conjunctivitis
Description: This photo shows bilateral conjunctival erythema (more in the left eye) in a patient with viral conjunctivitis. A discharge may also be present, typically clear. Itching is not usually a feature.

Title: Vitiligo (Hands and Arms)
Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Vitiligo Accentuated Under a Wood Light
Description: In this photo, vitiligo is accentuated under a Wood light (right).

Title: Vitiligo Accentuated Under a Wood Light
Description: Vitiligo is accentuated under a Wood light (right).
