Copyright: Image courtesy of Karen McKoy, MD.

Title: Vitiligo on the Foot
Description: This photo shows focal vitiligo of the foot.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Vitiligo With Hair Depigmentation
Description: Hair in vitiliginous areas is usually white.

Title: Vocal Cord Granulomas
Description: Vocal cord granulomas occur in the posterior glottis adjacent to the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilage .
Copyright: Image provided by Eiji Yanagisawa, MD.

Description: Vocal cord nodules manifest bilaterally at junction of anterior and middle third of the vocal cords.

Title: Vocal Cord Paralysis
Description: This endoscope view of the larynx (voice box) shows a paralyzed right vocal cord (gray, center left).

Title: Vocal Cord Polyp
Description: A vocal cord polyp usually appears unilaterally and larger than a nodule.

Title: Volar Finger Dislocation
Description: The middle phalanx is dislocated volar to the proximal phalanx.

Title: Volvulus
Description: Volvulus is a twisting of the colon around itself, sometimes causing strangulation with ischemia and necrosis. Occasionally, the rotation can be reduced noninvasively with an endoscope. This image shows an endoscopic view of a sigmoid volvulus; twisting of the colonic folds is visible.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Vulvar Epidermal Inclusion Cysts
Description: Multiple, bilateral vulvar epidermal inclusion cysts, previously referred to as sebaceous cysts, are shown.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Kaufman R, Brown D. In Atlas of Clinical Gynecology: Gynecologic Pathology. Edited by M Stenchever (series editor) and B Goff. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1998.

Title: Vulvar Malignant Melanoma
Description: This photo shows malignant melanoma of the vulva with focal extension to the urethral orifice.

Title: Vulvovaginal Candidiasis
Description: Characteristic findings in vulvovaginal candidiasis include a white discharge and vulvar erythema.

Title: Walking Boot
Copyright: Image courtesy of Danielle Campagne, MD.

Title: Warthin-Starry Stain (Bartonella henselae)
Description: This image shows a light micrograph of Warthin-Starry silver–stained B. henselae bacteria. With Warthin-Starry stain, they appear as small, black-curved organisms either singly or in clusters as in the center of the micrograph. They usually are found in areas of necrosis and in blood vessels.

Title: Warthin-Starry Stain (Borrelia burgdorferi)
Description: This image is a light micrograph of Warthin-Starry–stained B. burgdorferi bacteria (arrows) in a sample of heart tissue.
Copyright: CDC/Sherif Zaki, M.D. Ph.D.; DVBD/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Title: Wasp Sting Reaction
Description: The venom in wasp stings causes swelling, pain, itching, and redness.

Title: W-Dermatitis
Description: This photo shows irritant diaper dermatitis (“W-dermatitis”).
TopicName: Rash in Infants and Young Children

TopicLocations.Title: W-Dermatitis
TopicLocations.TopicName: Rash in Infants and Young Children

Title: Wet Mount (Normal)
Description: Wet mount examination using saline shows large nucleated vaginal squamous epithelial cells, small bacteria that are barely visible, and intermediate-sized white blood cells. Magnification is 400X.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Hillier S. In Atlas of Infectious Diseases: Sexually Transmitted Diseases. Edited by G Mandell (series editor) and MF Rein. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 1996.

Title: White Spot on the Nail
Description: This image shows punctate leukonychia due to minor injury to the nail.

Title: Widened Mediastinum
Description: This x-ray shows widened mediastinum in a patient with known thoracic aortic aneurysm.

Title: Widespread Rash Secondary to Meningococcemia
Description: Petechiae and purpura secondary to meningococcemia are widespread. Lesions tend to be common on the trunk and lower extremities.

Title: Wimberger Sign
Description: This photo shows lytic lesions in the medial aspect of proximal tibia (arrows).

Title: Wood Tick
Description: The wood tick is a vector of Rocky Mountain spotted fever.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Christopher Paddock via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Wound Myiasis
Description: This maggot is adjacent to an ulcerated wound.

Title: Wright-Giemsa Stain of Peripheral Blood Smear
Description: Wright-Giemsa stains are mixtures of basic dyes (methylene blue) that stain as blue and acidic dyes (eosin) that stain as red. Thus, acid components of the cell (nucleus, cytoplasmic RNA, basophilic granules) stain blue or purple, and basic components of the cell (hemoglobin, eosinophilic granules) stain red or orange.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Tefferi A, Li C. In Atlas of Clinical Hematology. Edited by JO Armitage. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2004.

TopicLocations.Title: Wright-Giemsa Stain of Peripheral Blood Smear

Title: Xanthelasma
Description: A xanthelasma is a slightly raised, yellow-white, well-circumscribed plaque that typically appears along the nasal aspect of one or both eyelids.
Copyright: Image provided by Thomas Habif, MD.

Title: Xanthelasma of the Eyelid
Description: This photo shows yellow-white plaques on the upper medial eyelids in a patient with hypercholesterolemia. Xanthelasma are not specific for familial hypercholesterolemia.

Title: Xanthelasma of the Eyelid
Description: This photo shows yellow-white plaques on the upper medial eyelids in a patient with hypercholesterolemia. Xanthelasma are not specific for familial hypercholesterolemia.

Title: Xanthelasma of the Eyelid
Description: This photo shows yellow-white plaques on the lateral eyelids and underneath the medial inner corner of the eye in a patient with hypercholesterolemia. Xanthelasma are not specific for familial hypercholesterolemia.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Michael H. Davidson, MD.

Title: Xeroderma (Xerosis) of the Hands
Description: The hands in this photo are profoundly dry, with roughness and fissuring.

Title: Xerophthalmia
Description: This photo shows chronic dryness of the conjunctival membrane with keratinized patches known as Bitot spots.
Copyright: Image courtesy of the Nutrition Program via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Xerosis
Description: This photo shows xerosis in a patient with chronic kidney disease. The skin is very rough and dry.

Title: Xerosis
Description: This photo shows xerosis in a patient with chronic kidney disease. The skin is very rough and dry.

Title: X-Ray Features of Early Rheumatoid Arthritis
Description: Features of aggressive, early rheumatoid arthritis, as seen in this x-ray of a 61-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis for 1 year, include evidence of soft-tissue swelling of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints, periarticular osteoporosis, symmetric joint space narrowing of several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of both hands, and subtle erosions of the right 3rd and right and left 4th metacarpophalangeal joints.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Matteson E, Mason T: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Title: X-Ray of the Chest
Description: Posteroanterior x-ray of the chest shows left upper lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia (arrows).

Title: X-Ray of the Knee in Osteoarthritis
Description: This x-ray, taken while the patient is standing, shows that the tibiofemoral joint space in the medial compartment of both knees is narrow, particularly on the left. Marginal osteophytes are visible. There is attrition of the left medial tibial plateau.
Copyright: By permission of the publisher. From Myers S: Atlas of Rheumatology. Edited by G Hunder. Philadelphia, Current Medicine, 2005.

Description: Anteroposterior x-ray of the left wrist shows a minimally displaced intra-articular fracture of the distal radius (white arrows) and ulnar styloid avulsion (black arrow).

Title: X-Ray of the Pelvis in Paget Disease
Description: The pelvic bones in this x-ray have a mottled appearance due to their increased porosity.

Title: X-Ray of the Skull in Paget Disease
Description: A typical mosaic pattern of areas of increased sclerosis and lucency is seen in this x-ray. These cotton-wool patches result from thickening of the calvarium.

Title: Yaws—Primary
Description: Primary yaws manifests as a large yellow papule or papillomata at the site of inoculation. Papules are highly infectious (top). This image shows the buttocks of a girl with primary yaws. Primary yaws lesions may also develop a crusted surface (bottom).
Copyright: Top image courtesy of Dr. Peter Perine via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Bottom image courtesy of K McLennon, Tulane University Medical School, via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Yaws—Secondary
Description: After the lesion of primary yaws heals, a generalized eruption of soft granulomata on the face, extremities (top), or buttocks occurs. Another feature of secondary yaws is soft, keratotic, tumor-like masses that develop on the soles of the feet (bottom). The masses force patients to walk on the sides of their feet, giving rise to the nickname crab yaws.
Copyright: Top image courtesy of Dr. Peter Perine via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Bottom image courtesy of Dr. Susan Lindsley via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Yaws—Tertiary
Description: About 10% of untreated patients develop tertiary yaws, which causes disfiguring bone and soft-tissue lesions.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Peter Perine via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Yellow Dog Tick
Description: The yellow dog tick is a vector of Rocky Mountain spotted fever.
Copyright: Image courtesy of Dr. Christopher Paddock via the Public Health Image Library of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Title: Yellow Nail Syndrome
Description: This image shows yellow nails with increased thickening and hypercurvature characteristic of yellow nail syndrome.

Title: Zenker Diverticulum
Description: Zenker diverticula are posterior outpouchings of mucosa and submucosa through the cricopharyngeal muscle. In this image, the diverticulum is on the left, next to the triangular opening of the trachea formed by the vocal cords.
Copyright: Image provided by David M. Martin, MD.

Title: Ziehl-Neelsen Stain (Mycobacterium leprae)
Description: This image is a light micrograph of modified Ziehl-Neelsen–stained (Wade-Fite stain) M. leprae in a skin biopsy from a person with lepromatous leprosy. The mycobacteria appear red and are present in large numbers, singly as well as in clusters (globi). Magnification is 20X when printed at 10-cm wide.
